item.title: Through the Ages of SRM
item.dc:creator: chelseablues
item.description: By TopCoder Member nhzp339 Not as productive as applications or components competitions, not as magnificent as the TopCoder Open or TopCoder Collegiate Challenge, the Single Round Match is more like a quiet river which accompanies the whole history of TopCoder. … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
By TopCoder Member nhzp339

Not as productive as applications or components competitions, not as magnificent as the TopCoder Open or TopCoder Collegiate Challenge, the Single Round Match is more like a quiet river which accompanies the whole history of TopCoder. It defines the culture of the community and the daily life of the members and witnesses the changes of the times in the TopCoder algorithm competition world. Open the historical scroll, and you will find all kinds of legendary stories of the kings, heroes, geniuses and people, and realize how time flies and what a great ‘world’ we are in.

Year 2001（SRM1-53）The Ancient BIG 4

The first SRM was born on May, 8th, 2001. Most competitors who didn’t experience that ancient age will envy those who did. Cash prizes were provided for each match and the frequency of matches was pretty high. You often had three chances to compete in a week, and in July 9 matches were provided in the single month. The problems looked pretty easy from the perspective of nowadays, but some were indeed pretty hard in that age. SRM 17 generated the first problem that was not solved by a single person in the competition. Some basic improvements to the rules were made in this age. From SRM 3 on, competitors were divided into 2 divisions so there wouldn’t be too much ability variance among the coders in the same room. This convention is still followed today. Starting with SRM 26, the challenge gain/punishment was changed from +100/-100 to +50/-50, which is a more reasonable amount that balances the relationships between coding and challenge, between ability and luck.

The world in that age was ruled by the ancient BIG 4. jonmac, the champion of the 2001 TopCoder Invitational, won 5 of the first 9 SRMs. dmwright took 11 SRM wins through the whole year and malpt took 8. From SRM 39 to 41, NGBronson made the first 3 consecutive Division I SRM wins in our history. None of the BIG 4 compete nowadays, but their impressive performances in that age are still remembered by some veterans.

Year 2002（SRM54-126）SnapDragon’s Rising

The matches attracted more and more powerful coders across the world. SRM 65 is the first match in which the participants count passed 500. From SRM 67, the two divisions started using different problems, and that successfully solved the problem for those persons who thought the set was too easy or too hard. However, from SRM 102, TopCoder no longer provided cash prizes for competitors. The instant effect of that decision was greatly reflected in the declining participant count in the following several matches, but thanks to the more comfortable competition environment provided, competitors’ enthusiasm was restored quickly, and more importantly, the most addicted coders were not affected by this change too much.

When SRM 72 Division II was won by a first time competitor called SnapDragon, some competitors who were familiar with him already realized what would happen in the future, and for those who didn’t at that time, it didn’t take them too much time to realize it. Although he lost to John Dethridge in a controversial way in 2002 at the TopCoder Invitational, (which is not the topic of this article), SnapDragon took 10 SRM Division I wins during the rest of that year, beat ZorbaTHut’s 8 and redeye’s 6 to become the most successful SRM competitor in that period. The PK between him and radeye (finally SnapDragon won by 4:3) from SRM 100 to 106 is one of the most exciting series in SRM history,

Year 2003（SRM127-177）SnapDragon’s Reign

Starting this year, the frequency of SRMs decreased to about one per week, but the participant count was increasing steadily. Yarin won 5 of the 6 matches from SRM 131-136, but that didn’t stop SnapDragon from consolidating his dominance. Including the 6 wins from SRM 148 to 155, SnapDragon took an incredible 16 SRM wins throughout the year. This long standing and glittering record is still unbroken to this day.

However, this is also a year in which SnapDragon was not able to conduct a coronation at the 2002 TopCoder Invitational, since from SRM 146, his reign was threatened seriously by the Polish genius called tomek. At the year’s end high-point, the TCO 2003 was overrun by the Polish cavalry. A storm from Continental Europe was coming.

Year 2004（SRM178-225）“Go Poland!”

Starting from SRM 221, a deeply significant rules change was made. The punishment for an unsuccessful challenge became -25 instead of -50. Along with this encouragement, more and more competitors became good challengers and blind challenges had become a widely used strategy.

At the same time, the unprecedented internationalization trend of TopCoder can be directly reflected from SRM’s competitors/winners distribution. Europeans took 24 SRM wins in the whole year. The elites of the European ‘army’ were Polish, the handpicked men led by Eryx, Yarin and Monsoon, who galloped in the fertile ground and executed the sole command from their king tomek – “Go Poland!”

In terms of SRM performances, tomek’s 7 SRM wins in that year were still second to SnapDragon’s impressive 10, however, with wins at the TCCC and TCO in 2004, plus the TCO03 champion title he got at the end of the last year, he became almost a semi god in that period. As written in the official report of TCO 2004, a lot of people in that age had the question in their mind “Does this guy ever lose?”

Year 2005（SRM226-280）Petr the Great Comes on the Stage of History

The base of SRM competitors became more and more solid. With SRM 248, extra energy was injected as TopCoder restored the prize money for certain matches. Almost at the same time, a sealed record was broken. In SRM 246, Norway wizard Im2Good solved 3 problems within 40 minutes and then made use of the rest of his time to make 12 successful challenges. 1972.53! A score never achieved even in the ancient age, when the problems were quite easy and a successful challenge gave 100 points.

Competitors active in this year all became witnesses to a changes of dynasties. In SRM 274, ACRush, called hierarch Lou by Chinese competitors, started his SRM journey. He should have had many chances to build his legacy in the following several years… if the sphere of influence belonging to Petr the Great didn’t also appear at this time. Starting by winning his first and sole Division II match in SRM235, Petr showed his unrivalled power in this field. After the 4 : 2 win of the series between him and tomek from SRM 270 to 275, by the end of the year Petr had collected 11 Division I SRM wins. Although tomek’s 8 and misof’s 6 were also memorable, almost everybody had already realized Petr would build an empire in the near future.

Year 2006（SRM281-332）All-Conquering Petr

Along with the arrival of powerful coders into this word, the problems also became more difficult. In SRM 294, the participant count in a single match passed the 1,000 threshold. In SRM 327, we were provided with a Division I problem set of the highest difficulty in SRM history. No one solved the hard problem, the medium problem only had 2 successful submissions, and even for the easy the passing rate was below a third. Ying won the match simply by being the only coder to successfully solve two problems. The competitors of that match should indeed feel lucky rather than gloomy since no one knows when such a wonderful scene will ever be repeated, if ever.

For those who think our history is always one of cold-hearted competition, SRM 324 is a living lesson from which they should learn. This was a special match to memorialize a highly respected TopCoder member victor_lxd, who passed away in an accident. Most prize winners of this match donated their winnings to Victor’s family, there were also extra donations from TopCoder and volunteers,(also, for those interested, nowadays each year’s TopCoder Open establishes the Spirit Award named for him) This match may probably be the most touching one in SRM history.

This was also a memorable year for young coders. In the summer, the first SRM for TopCoder High School was held, and subsequent history gradually proves the significance of such an event. Many high school heroes use this new area as their landing point and bring their extra vigor to this world.

However, the real theme of that year was Petr’s domination. His 12 SRM wins along with double championships in that year’s TCO and TCCC made him the all-conquering monarch for the new age.

Year 2007（SRM333-385) Rebellion from the Hierarchy

SRM 366 may have been a normal match for most coders, but for the community, it was a very special milestone. Swetko, TopCoder’s first Iron Man, gave his 100th consecutive appearance in rated SRMs. Encouraged by his spirit, there are already 7 members reaching this number nowadays, but as the first one to make the record, he most exactly defines the love we have for this sport.

The disappointment of being runner up in TCCC 2006 didn’t stop ACRush from leading the rebellion under Petr’s reign. In 2007, he took 7 SRM wins, the most among all his TopCoder years. However, after a stretch of 4 of 5 match wins from SRM 348 to 352, Petr the Great’s political power became quite solid, and by the end of the year his 11 SRM wins plus the winning of the TCCC 2007 marked the suppression of the rebellion.

Year 2008（SRM386-431）The Road from the Great to the Greatest

The population of this world kept increasing, by SRM 405 the participant count in a single match reached over 1,500. At the same time, competitors found that stronger ability was necessary to live in the world. The problems were not only more difficult, but also trickier. In SRM 413, quite a few Division I coders had a challenge feast by making 10+ successful challenges in a single match.

ACRush’s 6 wins during this year didn’t keep Petr from running in the road from the great to the greatest. In SRM 399 to 402, he achieved the unique 4 consecutive Division I SRM wins in history, his 3890 rating after SRM 401 even made the creation of the first purple (rating 4000+) coder seem quite possible. In SRM 415, his 44th Division I SRM wins made him surpass SnapDragon on the total-SRM-wins leaderboard. For the whole year, Petr’s 15 SRM wins were not only his best record ever, but also helped him keep this number at double digits for the 4th consecutive year. Besides his performances in matches, Petr started to post his SRM screencasts in the forum, which was a great contribution to the whole community.

However, he still had less than half a minute to reach the end point of this road that year, and that was the the legendary story between him and the old king tomek in the TCO 2008 final, which, although not the topic of this article, is worthy to be known by every TopCoder fan. History proves it again that only pities make things perfect.

Year 2009（SRM432-456）Twilight Struggle

In the shadow of the global economic crisis, the frequency of SRMs dropped to two per month in this year. Needless to say, two is too few for algorithm competition geeks, so a new concept “Member SRM” was conceived at that time, to provide extra and flexible matches without putting too much economic pressure on the company. From a certain angle, this was an age that members used enthusiasm with which to save the world of SRMs.

During this difficult period, ACRush raised his competitive power to almost the same level with Petr, making the battle between the two ‘giants’ the theme of this year. Starting from the end of the last year, each of them made a very long consecutive string of room wins. For the whole year 2009, ACRush took 6 match wins and Petr 7. The fact that two persons took over about half of SRM Division I wins marked this year as the period of bipolar structure.

Year 2010（SRM457-492）One Superpower and Multi Powers

Thanks to the great enthusiasm of our members, the plan of Member SRM continued smoothly, until this year the SRM frequency had been restored to three per month, and more or less lightened coders’ pain. The quality and difficulty of problems were still kept at a quite high level, SRM 483, the challenge feast for Division II coders, explained how tricky problems could be in modern times, even if only a Division II medium.

Petr’s 7 wins made his 6th consecutive most SRM wins in a single year, actually, this title never has never belonged to any other since he came into this world. However, ACRush, who created TopCoder’s historical highest rating of 3902 in SRM 482, was no longer the only rebellious power. neal_wu, and the champion of TCO 2010 rng_58, all made 3+ SRM wins in this year, exposing their ambitions for the throne.

Year 2011（SRM493-Now）Who Can Make the Revolution?

Petr’s lightning war wins 4 of the first 5 SRMs for him in the new year, have strongly expressed his determination to defend the kingship. Although unable to get win the championship from TCO 2007 to 2010, no one can deny that he is still the best one in the world. The only differences for the past several years is how many pursuers are close to him, and just how close they are.

When the ancient BIGs are no longer active, when SnapDragon feels lucky just by still being a target, when tomek no longer shouts “Go Poland!” but only wants to “have fun”, who will be the new hero to change dynasties?

Everyone is the History Maker

Although formal history lives in the book, the vivid one lives in people’s hearts. When looking back over the past 10 years, we remember not only monarchs’ conquest and significant events, but everything changing or accompanying our lives.

We have witnessed the moments when Olexiy/brett1479/ivan_metelsky/Ibackstrum/timmac became OlexiyO/AdminBrett/mystic_tc/lars2520/t-mac, as well as the moment when TheFaxman said GoodBye to us.

We feel lucky for how productive our problem setters are such as dgoodman, as well as how dedicated our problem testers are such as PabloGilberto.

We appreciate how the plugins provided by kawigi, Pops, etc. help us during a match, as well as how the tools provided by MB__, ahmed_aly, etc. facilitate our demands after a match.

We extract every character out from SnapDragon’s code, as well as from misof’s articles.

We learn what talent is from crazyb0y’s story, as well as what diligence is from exod40’s rating curve.

We look forward to every further match of Larry, as well as every consecutive further match of dcp.

We ask writer1 who he is, as well as ask natori what the challenge case is.

We pursue why Eryx loves comments, as well as why John Dethridge hates indentations

Although the vivid history lives in people’s hearts, the real one lives everywhere. Whether recorded or remembered, as every word and behavior of us form the real-life history, every thought in our minds and every byte we enter form the history of SRM. Accompanied with the coming of the milestone SRM 500, we will further make the history together which belongs to ourselves.

item.title: Congratulations to the February Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: The February coders and designers of the month have been picked and congratulations to: Algorithm: arshuaz Design: saarixx Development: Yeung Studio: systic Algorithm: arshuaz What was your favorite Algorithm problem in February and why? FoxStones in SRM498 is my favorite … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The February coders and designers of the month have been picked and congratulations to:

Algorithm: arshuaz
Design: saarixx
Development: Yeung
Studio: systic

Algorithm: arshuaz

What was your favorite Algorithm problem in February and why?
FoxStones in SRM498 is my favorite problem. It needs no special knowledge. But I think,
meet many problems for solving this problem.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what keeps you busy?
I practice programming with my friends in algorithm club at Ajou University.

If you had to give some advice to a new TopCoder member, what would you share with them?
To meet a good mentor is very important. My mentor is libe. He introduced TopCoder to me,
and taught coding know-how, algorithms, and what to know all about.

If you want to meet someone like him, observe your neighborhood. You will meet your mentor in the
near future.

Design: saarixx

What was your favorite Design contest in February and why?
February was a very quiet month in the design track, so I have not so many contests to choose from. I competed in the design contests for all components from Hera Auto Dealer Network Partner architecture during 5 days. I liked it since doing a lot of work during such limited period of time is always challenging. And in such cases you always need to correctly distribute your work time among all the active contests not to fail any of them.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what keeps you busy?
I try to spend a free time with my family, especially with my 3-month old son. If my son falls asleep for a while, I can watch one of my favorite TV series: The Big Bang Theory, Two and a Half Man, Chuck, Desperate Housewives, Futurama or Simpsons.

If you had to give some advice to a new TopCoder member, what would you share with them?
Very often I receive messages from TopCoder members asking to show them some document or article that will allow them to win design competitions as I do. Sure, I answer that such document doesn’t exist and the best way to start is to check existing components from the catalog and to begin competing in the competitions. I want to make clear for new TopCoder members that a lot of TopCoder rules and standards really exists. And knowing them really can make you win almost any design competition. But the problem is that these rules are not written anywhere. They are hidden in the minds of TopCoder community members who review submissions. Don’t waste your time by contacting these members and asking them to share all their secrets.

The rules they keep in mind cost a lot since they are a result of huge experience. So don’t expect to easily get all the secrets from someone that will allow you to become one of the best designers at once.

Instead you have a clear way to make other members share their experience with you – try to submit something and you will get their feedback as review comments. Then you need just to systematize all the comments, and not to make the same mistakes twice. This approach will allow you for sure to become one of the best designers. Go ahead and good luck!

Development: Yeung

What was your favorite Development contest in February and why?
Hera series. Why? I am .Net guy. Less .Net contests except Hera in Feb. When I found out I am coder of month in Feb, it surprised me.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what keeps you busy?
Movies, Travel, and Sleep.

If you had to give some advice to a new TopCoder member, what would you share with them?
Failure is the mother of success.

And to some new members, please open your contact link when you contact other people. Or leave your reply address in contact message.

Studio: systic

What was your favorite Studio contest in February and why?
Favorite contest was Tree Auto MyTree Business Center Wireframe because almost all the submissions were looking perfect and had no idea that i would win.

When you’re not designing, what keeps you busy?
I play games, read, sleep, dream about my future ..etc.

If you had to give some advice to a new Studio member, what would you share with them?
Never lose hope if you lose a contest….Keep submitting the good work…one day your work will be recognized!

item.title: Voices from the Arena: The Past and Present of Single Round Matches
item.dc:creator: chelseablues
item.description: To mark SRM 500, we asked members of our community to provide a retrospective on the ten year history of Single Round Matches – the timelines, people and events that over the years have made SRMs such an important part … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
To mark SRM 500, we asked members of our community to provide a retrospective on the ten year history of Single Round Matches – the timelines, people and events that over the years have made SRMs such an important part of so many members’ lives. Here is the first in a four part series of member-written articles. Enjoy!

By Eeyore
TopCoder Member

Here be dragons

I remember how nervous I was during my first Single Round Match. The breeze of a late summer day came in through my open window, and I could hear the shouts from a football game across the street. I was inside my dorm room, staring at green and white characters scrolling down a black background. It reminded me of the Matrix movies, but I wasn’t Keanu Reeves and I didn’t feel ready for battle. I was trying to keep myself from rocking back and forth in my chair. I wanted my fingers to stop trembling so that I could start to peck out some code on the keyboard.

Two weeks later when I took part in my second SRM, I had a bad case of nerves again. It wasn’t until I had a dozen SRMs behind me that I could calmly read through the problem statement and begin typing with a steady hand. I find it difficult to explain to people who don’t take part in algorithmic programming competitions why I was ever so nervous. When I take part in an SRM, I am nearly anonymous. I am represented by a brief string of characters on a computer screen. I rank near the bottom of Division 1, and no one is all that interested in how well I do. I am the opposite of someone like SnapDragon.

In the fall of 2002, SnapDragon was a recent graduate of the University of Waterloo, where I was a grad student. He worked at a bioinformatics firm during the day and came to the university two or three nights a week to help train the school’s ACM programming team. I first saw him at a workstation in my lab during a practice contest. His name was at the top of the scoreboard, comfortably ahead of all the teams from Waterloo and elsewhere. I asked the coach how often a solitary SnapDragon was able to beat the three-person teams.

“Almost always,” he said.

I marveled at the sight and the sound of SnapDragon attacking the keyboard. He hammered away at the keys like a concert pianist performing one of Beethoven’s more frenzied passages, but the noise was like that of a machine gun. On his screen, the text cursor was churning out dense blocks of cryptic code, seemingly all brackets and single-letter variable names. It was nothing like any code I had ever written. I had seen SnapDragon‘s name at the head of the TopCoder rankings, but that was my first glimpse of a top coder in action.

Later that winter I had a memorable conversation with SnapDragon after a training session. Fueled by countless cans of soda from the lab fridge, we talked into the early morning hours about programming competitions and about computer gaming, his other great passion. He owned all the major game consoles and played them for hours every day. I asked him if gaming didn’t interfere with his programming pursuits.

“Games actually make you smarter,” he said. “But they also make you lazier.”

We discussed how the Arena compared to other types of programming contests. He said that one of the virtues of TopCoder’s format was how rigorously the problem constraints were specified. And then there was the cash to be made from SRMs. SnapDragon told me that for a while he was winning hundreds of dollars a week in the Arena, which was pretty sweet for a few hours of playful problem solving.

The financial picture for TopCoder and for the world was very different then. It was two years since the dot-com bubble had burst, and the tech industry was on an upswing. Web 2.0 was on its way. Silicon Valley was hiring at a rapid pace. TopCoder was busy marketing its employment services to companies looking for the kind of programmers who excelled at algorithm contests. Sponsors funded two SRMs a week, with substantial cash prizes for top placements in each room of the Arena.

As TopCoder diversified its activities from recruitment to software development, the algorithm competitions diminished in frequency and in financial reward. SRMs were no longer very lucrative, yet they remained a vital fixture on the TopCoder calendar, and the Arena grew as a gathering place for algorithmic problem solvers from around the world.

From the Arena to the workplace

A member whose name I recognized without having met him was radeye, who participated in SRMs frequently from 2002 to 2005. I knew of him from the LaTeX software stack, which is used throughout the academic world to typeset technical papers. Because radeye is the author of dvips, the popular DVI-to-PostScript compiler, I had seen his name many times on the command line while preparing documents for printing.

I wrote to him recently to ask why his participation in SRMs has been so sparse compared to earlier years.

“The cash prizes provided a significant incentive to compete,” he told me. “But primarily, I’ve been too distracted by other pursuits.”

His recent exploits in recreational programming include an exhaustive exploration of the states of the Rubik’s Cube, showing that it can always be solved in twenty moves or less. There is plenty to occupy radeye, but he still competes on TopCoder occasionally, and he holds the quality of SRMs in high regard.

“TopCoder provides excellent, well-tested problems,” he says. “I believe they do a better job of this than anyone else.”

Although he has never competed in TopCoder’s software design and development contests, radeye has applied lessons from algorithmic programming competitions to real-life software projects. He says that he has applied “tools, tricks and APIs [that he has] learned from other competitors” in his own work.

“I know TopCoder has improved my programming,” says radeye.

I recently asked dangelo, another elite competitor in the early years of TopCoder, about the correlation between success in algorithm contests and proficiency in software engineering. From 2002 to 2005, dangelo competed in 77 TopCoder matches as a way of spending “a lot of extra energy that wasn’t being taken up by [his] coursework at Caltech.” Today dangelo is a well-known Silicon Valley entrepreneur. He was the Chief Technology Officer of Facebook before leaving to found Quora, a social question-and-answer website.

In dangelo‘s experience, the ability to work with large data sets at an Internet company depends on many factors, “including writing good code, reading code, building good abstractions, systems knowledge, applying and designing algorithms, documentation and communication, experience and working hard,” he says.

“Programming contests mainly build skill at applying and designing algorithms quickly,” he told me. “As an engineer, having this background can be a big advantage, but the other skills are equally important and need to be developed.”

I asked dangelo if he could recall specific cases where he had applied something he had learned in algorithmic programming competitions.

“This happens all the time,” he replied.

While dangelo was coding the first version of Quora, these were some of the challenges in which his competition background helped him: “Designing the data structures and algorithms for our question search service. Writing the algorithm to compute the difference between two rich text blocks (after someone edits an answer or other content). Structuring the abstraction for some of our real-time update infrastructure. Optimizing various parts of our code that operate on large datasets.”

So if you come across people who believe that the mathematical tricks and puzzles we encounter in SRMs are divorced from the realities of software engineering, you can tell them to think again.

The crème de la crème

The Arena is just one of many venues for algorithmic competition while you’re a student. There are the USACO and IOI contests in high school, and university undergraduates can take part in ACM competitions at the local, regional, and global levels. Of course you can compete in SRMs at the same time, as many collegiate competitors do.

When you’ve graduated out of the realm of ACM competition, the Arena is still there for you. TopCoder functions as the major league of the competitive programming world. This was underlined recently in the final online round of the Facebook Hacker Cup, an algorithmic programming contest that was open to everyone on Facebook. All 25 of the top 25 finishers were TopCoder members, two of them rated yellow and the rest rated red.

Red is the highest color in TopCoder’s rating rainbow. At the top of that narrow red band are the brightest stars in the coding firmament. Like in any sports league, there is a small group of phenomenal talents whose names are known to the masses. No two contestants are better known or more feared in the Arena than Petr and ACRush.

Upon his debut in March 2005, Petr spent a single round as a yellow-rated coder before zooming up to red. At the time I am writing this, just after SRM 498, over 85% of his Level Three solutions have passed the system tests. Those are the hardest problems on TopCoder. His passing rates on the Level Two and Level One problems are 93% and 96% respectively. Close to perfect: that’s the level of performance it has taken Petr to rank number one in 136 of his last 230 rounds (not adjusted for unrated matches).

ACRush took part in his first SRM eight months after Petr, and rocketed on a similarly steep trajectory toward the peak of the algorithm charts. He has held the top spot 30 times out of the 79 rounds since he first became number one. ACRush and Petr have reached similar heights of success along quite different paths. Petr‘s ACM teams took second place at the World Finals on two occasions, whereas ACRush has won the TopCoder Open and the Google Code Jam. And they have very distinct coding styles; ACRush‘s solutions tend to be more compact and more arcane than Petr‘s.

These two formidable competitors may dispute the mastery of the Arena, yet they have nothing but warm words for each other. When I contacted ACRush recently, he said that he was “very happy” to have Petr as a rival and that he never worries about how their rankings compare to each other.

ACRush says that he normally practices about five hours a week. Before a major tournament like the TopCoder Open, he will buckle down for about 30 hours of extra training. Despite the hours of preparation, ACRush likes to emphasize the recreational aspect of the TopCoder Arena.

“The SRM is the favorite game in my life,” he told me.

ACRush says that winning does not increase his enjoyment of an SRM. What counts for him is the quality of the problems. It’s “more fun if we have a nice problem set,” he says.

Life in the trenches

Despite the competitive nature of SRMs, they are not elitist events. Coders in all echelons take part in them with great enthusiasm. Surely one of the most dedicated Arena warriors is dcp, who has completed 201 matches since his debut in April 2006. His rating color remained gray, the lowest in the TopCoder spectrum, until January 2007. It took 137 rounds before dcp broke into Division 1 in April 2009, three years after his first SRM.

What has enabled dcp to persevere? He told me recently that he tries to avoid setting goals of a kind where he can’t control the outcome, such as earning a yellow rating or placing in the top 50 in an SRM.

“I prefer to set goals that I have control over,” says dcp. “I might set a goal to solve 5 or 6 problems in a week. Those types of goals are totally in my control, because either I put the time into it or I don’t.”

He spends about three or four hours a week practicing for SRMs. Like ACRush, he puts great emphasis on the fun factor.

“As long as you enjoy competing in SRMs, then that’s what really counts,” he says. “Don’t worry about the rating too much.”

Unlike most of the passionate algorithm competitors, dcp is also active in TopCoder’s component competitions, which award healthy cash prizes to the winners. Although SRMs are not a source of income for him, dcp finds them profoundly useful, saying that through them he has learned many things that he would not have learned otherwise. For example, by studying the code of elite problem solvers, he recently learned about the inclusion-exclusion principle.

“I enjoy the challenges and I like to learn new things,” says dcp. “SRMs are like ‘mind exercise’ for me, and it’s always exhilarating.”

How long can we keep at the game? Will SRMs always be worth doing? Minilek, who started doing TopCoder in his third year of undergraduate studies at MIT and is now close to finishing his PhD there, says that he is optimistic.

“I think SRMs are still as fun as they were in the past, and I’m optimistic that they’ll stay that way for a while longer,” Minilek says.

He is glad that the problems have gotten harder because his “ability has only improved over time and it’s fun to keep things challenging.” He does note that “it might make modern SRMs harder for a newcomer.”

Minilek says that competitive programming used to be his “most enjoyable hobby” and is still among his favorite pastimes. It has also benefited him in job interviews.

“Interviewers liked to ask coding puzzle questions,” he says, “and after having played TopCoder a bit they all seemed easy.”

Minilek has completed 193 rounds in the Arena. In the course of the first 151 of those, he improved gradually from green to red. His enjoyment of SRMs has been essential to his progress. He says that it’s best not to force yourself to do something unless you find it enjoyable.

“If you enjoy what you’re doing,” he says, “you’ll do it a lot and naturally improve, and it won’t seem like work; it’ll feel like fun all along.”

Behind the scenes

What is the machinery that makes the fun happen? Who are the people responsible for creating those exhilarating SRM experiences? I turned to Olexiy for his perspective on the operations that take place in the basement (or perhaps the dungeon) of the Arena.

Olexiy was the head problem writer for TopCoder’s algorithm competitions from August 2005 until February 2009, when he handed the reins to ivan_metelsky. He has seen SRMs from both sides, having competed in them before and after his tenure as Algorithm Coordinator. Olexiy has been among the coders who ask the admins when the system tests are finally going to finish, and many times he has had that question asked of him.

Olexiy started contributing problem sets before he became the head writer. He claims that his predecessor in the post, lbackstrom, wanted him to stop writing because one of his problem sets went “so terribly wrong.” But a few months later, when lbackstrom was in a pinch, Olexiy happened to have some problems ready to go. His affairs continued so well that Olexiy rose to the chief position “about six months after being banned as a writer,” as he tells it.

If you’re one of the veteran algorithm competitors who feels that SRM problems have gotten harder over the years, Olexiy agrees with you.

“The biggest change [has been] the difficulty of the problems,” he said when I asked how SRMs have changed.

Sometimes a problem set is too tricky by accident, because the writer doesn’t see the challenges posed by his own problems. After all, he has “usually [spent] dozens of hours thinking about them.”

Olexiy relates that when Petr wrote his second SRM, he was confident that the problems were quite easy and that there would be “at least 20 people with all three problems solved.” It turned out to be a massacre: “two coders had the medium and nobody came within a mile of the hard.”

But Olexiy points out that the SRMs have also had to become more challenging in order to meet the rising level of skill among the TopCoder membership. In Olexiy‘s estimation, anyone ranked within the top 200 today would be able to breeze through the 2003 or 2004 TopCoder Open final problems in 45 minutes. He adds that the problem writers have tried to keep the difficulty of Division 2 “at the same level,” but that the difficulty of Division 1 has grown “tremendously.”

When I asked Olexiy about the highs and lows of running an SRM, he quoted TheFaxman on the experience of going through an Arena meltdown: “Being admin at such events is like skydiving, but without most of the fun.”

The greatest satisfaction that Olexiy gets from an SRM is when someone likes a problem of his. After a highly ranked coder told him that “TakeBus was one of the best problems he had ever seen”, Olexiy says, “I was truly happy.”

The road ahead

I’m not sure if happiness is the right word for what Rustyoldman, my favorite TopCoder curmudgeon, experiences in the Arena. He does say that SRMs are an important pastime of his: “If there is an SRM going on, everything else is dropped, except work and sleep.”

He grumbles that “the participant base for SRMs has moved far away from my time zone.” Then he brightens at an idea: “I guess I could move to Europe in order to participate in TopCoder more.”

Although I don’t believe Rustyoldman‘s claim that he is 154 years old, he is certainly among the older cohort on TopCoder. “I try to get other old farts to do contests,” he told me, but “mostly they [say that] they don’t have the time.”

Rustyoldman takes a relaxed attitude toward training. He estimates that he spends an average of three hours a week helping to make problem sets for SRMs in which he is not competing, but “near zero hours per week preparing for participation.” He concedes, “Zero is probably too little.”

As I look back at my own history in SRMs, I can see several bouts of intensive participation separated by long spans of time in which I was a stranger to the Arena. At the start of this year I returned to regular SRM participation once again. What’s new for me this time is a clear sense of how my training in algorithmic problem solving has contributed to my abilities in software development. I’m convinced that the more time I devote to SRMs, the more efficiently I’ll be able to do my work.

In my recent correspondence with Johan.de.Ruiter, who has competed in 96 rounds since 2006, I gained more insight into my relationship with the Arena. He describes the initial urge to compete in SRMs as an addiction.

“I used to compete in SRMs while sitting in the doorstep of the electrical closet,” he told me, “often at 3 o’clock in the morning. I didn’t have a longer cable, and I didn’t need sleep as much as I needed my fix of competitive algorithmic problem solving.”

SRMs took a back seat when Johan.de.Ruiter became more involved in coaching his university’s ACM teams and in developing his puzzle website, but he is eager to make a comeback in the TopCoder Arena.

“Recently I have found more time and I am still as excited about SRMs as I ever was,” he says. “I certainly hope to be a regular in the Arena once again in 2011.”

It struck home for me when Johan.de.Ruiter, in describing his early experiences with the Arena, put it this way: “My rating became part of my identity.”

The identification with my rating explains some of the anxiety I felt during my first few SRMs, and the pride I take today in my renewed participation. I know that my TopCoder algorithm rating doesn’t wholly define my programming abilities. Nonetheless, my capacity to solve algorithmic problems under pressure is a crucial part of my identity as a software developer. It is evidence of the time I have spent studying some of the deeper mysteries of my craft. My sole regret is that I’ve only taken part in about a quarter of the first five hundred SRMs. I am determined to improve my rate of participation, and my rating, over the next five hundred.

item.title: SRM 500 Will Offer $5,000 in Cash Prizes
item.dc:creator: chelseablues
item.description: In light of the upcoming SRM 500 on Saturday, March 19th, TopCoder will be staking $5,000 in cash prizes as our way of recognizing this most remarkable milestone! Ten years in the making, we’re treating this as a celebration for the community! So get ready to take part in what will be one of the most prestigious TopCoder SRMs in years and give yourself a chance at some cash prizes and becoming a part of history! Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
In light of the upcoming SRM 500 on Saturday, March 19th, TopCoder will be staking $5,000 in cash prizes as our way of recognizing this most remarkable milestone! Ten years in the making, we’re treating this as a celebration for the community! So get ready to take part in what will be one of the most prestigious TopCoder SRMs in years and give yourself a chance at some cash prizes and becoming a part of history!SRM 500 begins at 12:00 noon EDST (GMT-4) with registration opening 3 hours prior to match time. Participation will be limited to the first 2,100 registrants.

Single Round Match 500 Prize Distribution Description

· Competitors with a rating of 1200 or higher at the start of the match will be placed into a division one room. All other competitors, including non-rated competitors, will be placed into a division two room.

· Room assignments within each division will performed randomly, with prizes distributed evenly among all rooms in each division.

· 70% of the total purse will be awarded to division one competitors, and 30% to division two competitors.

· Approximately 20 competitors will be assigned to each room.

· The first, second, and third place coders in each division one room will receive 50%, 30%, and 20% of the room award, respectively.

· The first and second place competitors in each division two room will receive 60% and 40% of the room award, respectively.

· In the event of a tie for any prize winning position, the sum of the awards of the tied competitors will be distributed evenly. (For example, if five coders tie for second place in a division one room, each will receive (30%+20%)/5 or 10% of the room award.)

item.title: 2011 Doris PHP Contests

item.description: If you are a hotshot object-oriented PHP developer, TopCoder is calling! The DVP3 PHP System Skeleton Assembly is a chance to start getting involved in Doris’ world-class PHP development efforts. Following this contest are scheduled 15 PHP development contests, each … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: If you are a hotshot object-oriented PHP developer, TopCoder is calling! The DVP3 PHP System Skeleton Assembly is a chance to start getting involved in Doris’ world-class PHP development efforts. Following this contest are scheduled 15 PHP development contests, each building on, and into, this skeleton application. Even better, absolutely no proprietary technologies are required to submit on this initial DVP3 PHP System Skeleton Assembly.

item.title: Meet the January Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the January Coders and Designers of the Month! Check out their interviews. Algorithm: komaki Design: MiG-29 with 6 wins Development: cyberjag with 4 wins Studio: selvia_ettine won $1,700 in 3 contestsCongratulations to the January Coders and Designers of … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the January Coders and Designers of the Month! Check out their interviews.

Algorithm: komaki
Design: MiG-29 with 6 wins
Development: cyberjag with 4 wins
Studio: selvia_ettine won $1,700 in 3 contestsCongratulations to the January Coders and Designers of the Month! Check out their interviews.

Algorithm: komaki


komaki’s home town.

What was your favorite Algorithm problem in January and why?
KnightsOut in SRM494 is my favorite problem. It looks to have so many cells, which decide whether the board can be a solution, that I can’t use bitmap or other methods to solve it. But there is a miracle one. Even though everyone knows the method, it is hard to notice it. It is the reason why KnightsOut is my favorite problem.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what keeps you busy?
Watching anime and reading manga.

If you had to give some advice to a new TopCoder member, what would you share with them?
I am not such a great coder now.

Design: MiG-29


MiG-29 with his daughters in one of numerous parks on St. Petersburg, Russia.

What was your favorite Design contest in January and why?
All CS-STEM specifications and conceptualization contests were my favorites in January. Designing a new community for educating mid-high school students is a challenging and very interesting task.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what keeps you busy?
Taking care on family and children keeps me busy even when I am competing at TopCoder. In my free time I like to read books.

If you had to give some advice to a new TopCoder member, what would you share with them?
Please attend TCO’2011 – you have real chances to win a free trip to the on-site final rounds. Many of newcomers have won previous TCO trips from the first attempt.

Studio: selvia_ettine

What was your favorite Studio contest in January and why?
I’d say my favorite was TC Press-Room Redesign Wireframe.
I’m usually not so good at managing pages that have many elements/content in them, but I got it right in this contest (finally!). So, I’m very glad.

When you’re not designing, what keeps you busy?
I read, play video games, and sleep.

If you had to give some advice to a new Studio member, what would you share with them?
Make sure to submit at least 30 minutes before the deadline. Seriously, you don’t want to miss the deadline after all that hard work!

item.title: New Competition Type: Content Creation
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: Starting now, Content Creation competitions are available for everyone to participate in. Content Creation competitions are used to produce virtually any type of content. Unlike software contests such as Architecture, Component Development, Assembly, etc., these contests are often non-technical in … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Starting now, Content Creation competitions are available for everyone to participate in. Content Creation competitions are used to produce virtually any type of content. Unlike software contests such as Architecture, Component Development, Assembly, etc., these contests are often non-technical in nature and aim at tapping into your creativity.

The deliverables varies depending on the requirements. For example, a competition may ask competitors to produce help documentation for a web site, write tutorials, write feature articles, write blog posts, create videos, improve merchandise descriptions in a product catalog, etc. The format of the content is really unlimited.

The first competition is live and more are quickly getting scheduled.

To start creating content, click here!.

item.title: Save-the-Date for the TCO11!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: It’s official! New dates and a new location! We are excited to announce the 2011 TopCoder Open! The TCO11 will take place September 25 – 28, 2011 at the Westin Diplomat Resort & Spa, Hollywood, Florida, USA. More details about … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
It’s official! New dates and a new location!

We are excited to announce the 2011 TopCoder Open! The TCO11 will take place September 25 – 28, 2011 at the Westin Diplomat Resort & Spa, Hollywood, Florida, USA. More details about this awesome event to come in March. So if you went to compete, better start practicing now!

item.title: Announcing 2011 Doris Contests!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: TopCoder is proud to announce the beginning of Doris contests in 2011. Registration is now open for the DVP3 System Architecture contest to build a public-facing web-site for a globally recognized brand. Many more contests are planned as we proceed … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: TopCoder is proud to announce the beginning of Doris contests in 2011. Registration is now open for the DVP3 System Architecture contest to build a public-facing web-site for a globally recognized brand. Many more contests are planned as we proceed through DVP3 and other projects. Use of LAMP (PHP), and Java mean you will be working with the popular technologies, and be contributing to an evolving platform on which other Doris projects will also be built. To compete on Doris contests, you must have agreed to the Competition Confidentiality Agreement (CCA), and signed and returned a Doris Subcontractor Services Agreement. Once you have agreed to the CCA, you may request an SSA of us. Come, join the Doris team today!

item.description: TopCoder is seeking a quick learner with a passion for algorithms and a strong technical understanding of software to help meet the increasing needs of our customers to incorporate algorithm competitions into their innovation strategies. This position will involve successfully … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder is seeking a quick learner with a passion for algorithms and a strong technical understanding of software to help meet the increasing needs of our customers to incorporate algorithm competitions into their innovation strategies. This position will involve successfully understanding the algorithmic needs of enterprise customers in order to execute TopCoder competitions that deliver the capability of the TopCoder community to those customers.

Read the rest of this job description and apply here.

item.title: Two weeks left in the PayPal Mobile App Challenges – Registration extended!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: We are only two weeks away from the end of the submission for the PayPal Mobile App Challenges and to encourage everyone to participate, we’ve extended registration – all the way up to the submission deadline! The PayPal Mobile App … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
We are only two weeks away from the end of the submission for the PayPal Mobile App Challenges and to encourage everyone to participate, we’ve extended registration – all the way up to the submission deadline!

The PayPal Mobile App Challenges is looking for the best iPhone & the best Android app that utilizes the PayPal Mobile Payments Library – and each one gets $5,000! We are also running the PayPal Mobile Libraries Developer Experience Bug Hunt to help PayPal find issues and bugs. Find them and win! Get all your details here.

Don’t have access to the Apple Developer license? We can help! TopCoder is granting access to it’s Apple Developer license to qualified members – see the wiki for rules & eligibility.

item.title: Announcing the PayPal Mobile App Challenge and TopCoder Apple Developer Access Program!
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: PayPal and TopCoder have launched the PayPal Mobile App Challenges, a pair of contests where the top Android and top iPhone app that utilize the PayPal Mobile Payment Libraries each win $5000! You can develop a full-functioning app or just … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
PayPal and TopCoder have launched the PayPal Mobile App Challenges, a pair of contests where the top Android and top iPhone app that utilize the PayPal Mobile Payment Libraries each win $5000! You can develop a full-functioning app or just a really cool prototype – you just must implement at least a simple payment with the PayPal library and your submission can win! Here are the contests:

  • PayPal Mobile App iPhone Challenge
  • PayPal Mobile App Android Challenge

There’s other ways to get paid too. We’re also running, in concert, the PayPal Mobile Libraries Developer Experience Bug Hunt contest. Find bugs and get paid even more!

  • PayPal Mobile Libraries Developer Experience Bug Hunt

Want to compete but don’t have access to the iOS Developer Program? TopCoder is pleased to announce that it will now offer access to the iOS Developer SDK via the TopCoder license to qualified members for selected contests. The PayPal Mobile App iPhone Challenge is the inaugural contest. For more information and to apply for the program, see the contest forum. Note: this program is limited to rated members.

item.title: More Copilot Functionality
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: The utilization of copilots in the TopCoder Platform is increasing. We are excited about it and are introducing more functionality aimed at increasing collaboration between customers and copilots, PM’s and copilots, copilots and copilots, etc. The next step has been … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: The utilization of copilots in the TopCoder Platform is increasing. We are excited about it and are introducing more functionality aimed at increasing collaboration between customers and copilots, PM’s and copilots, copilots and copilots, etc. The next step has been released. You can now post opportunities to copilots, view incoming submissions from copilots, select your copilot and manage copilot assignments to projects – All from the convenience of Cockpit.

item.title: Ideas Wanted for New TopCoder Program with Shirts and Cash!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: At TopCoder, we boast about having the best and brightest members from around the world as part of our community. That is why we need your help. If you have not heard, TopCoder has been engaged by DARPA (Defense Advanced … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
At TopCoder, we boast about having the best and brightest members from around the world as part of our community.

That is why we need your help. If you have not heard, TopCoder has been engaged by DARPA (Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency) to build a program that will attract students to topics in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math, with an emphasis on Computer Science. Learn more about that program here.

Before we can do that, we need your ideas. Right now we have an Idea Generation contest going on looking for game ideas. We need cool, talented, and smart people like our TopCoder members to give us ideas that we can potentially build to be a part of this new site (which we’re calling NoNameSite.com).

Help us by taking your ideas and submitting them for this contest. There will be 15 winners; the top five will win $300, and each of the top 15 will win a limited edition NoNameSite.com t-shirt. Registration ends on December 17 at 17:00 UTC -5. Learn more about the contest here.

item.title: PayPal X Chat Session before SRM 490 plus a Giveaway!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Participate in SRM 490 and get the chance to win a TopCoder t-shirt and an SD eye-fi Card for your camera! All you have to do is be a registered member of the PayPal X/TopCoder Community and you’re automatically entered … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Participate in SRM 490 and get the chance to win a TopCoder t-shirt and an SD eye-fi Card for your camera! All you have to do is be a registered member of the PayPal X/TopCoder Community and you’re automatically entered into the drawing! Join here: http://paypalx.topcoder.com

One hour before the SRM, join Rasesh Shah, a Developer Evangelist for the PayPal Developer Network, in the competition arena. Hear about the latest features PayPal has added – such as micropayments, PayPal Apps, and embedded payment – to its payments platform. Learn about powerful capabilities PayPal has in mobile, the fast growing segment of the payments market. And get a first glimpse at upcoming opportunities for TopCoder member to earn money working with PayPal.

Join Rasesh and Andrew Abbott, TopCoder Platform Manager for PayPal, to hear about all that PayPal has to offer!

item.title: Fast PHP Development on Telco Protocols
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Alctel-Lucent is running a few $500 bug races this weekend to expose their Telco APIs as RESTful services. The services are defined and the protocol clients and endpoints are available. The task is to create the RESTful service using the … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: Alctel-Lucent is running a few $500 bug races this weekend to expose their Telco APIs as RESTful services. The services are defined and the protocol clients and endpoints are available. The task is to create the RESTful service using the recess PHP framework and by calling the protocol clients. We need these done quickly so the copilot is available to answer any questions. Good luck!

item.title: Are you one of the 100 in the $165,000 100 Apps in 100 Days Contest?
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Our 100 Days are almost up. Have you submitted one of the 100 Apps? Because we have BREAKING NEWS on the 100 Apps in 100 Days front! The first 100 apps submitted will also win a bonus prize! For 100 … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Our 100 Days are almost up. Have you submitted one of the 100 Apps?

Because we have BREAKING NEWS on the 100 Apps in 100 Days front!

The first 100 apps submitted will also win a bonus prize!

For 100 awesome apps, we want to reward you even more! If your app is in the first 100 to be submitted, add $50 to your wallet. Plus not only will you win a cool t-shirt, but a cool t-shirt that has your handle on it.

And do we even have to remind you of the grand prize? A trip to Mobile World Congress 2011; and not just a plane ticket but lodging and entrance into the conference taking place in Barcelona, Spain!

Submit your app that uses Alcatel-Lucent’s APIs and that also uses some other API(s) from ProgrammableWeb.com.

It’s a great time of year to earn bonus prizes. So reward yourself for your good ideas but submitting your apps.

But be quick, we don’t call it 100 Apps in 100 Days for no reason. Submit now to be in the first 100!

Read more here: http://topcoder.com/home/alcatel/100-apps-in-100-days/

item.title: Meet the October Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the October coders and designers of the month: Algorithm: fushar Design: gevak, 8 first places and 4 second places Development: live_world, 8 first places and 1 second place Studio: vcsenge won $2,050 TopCoder interviewed our winners so check … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the October coders and designers of the month:

Algorithm: fushar
Design: gevak, 8 first places and 4 second places
Development: live_world, 8 first places and 1 second place
Studio: vcsenge won $2,050

TopCoder interviewed our winners so check it out!

Algorithm: fushar


Fushar (wearing Batik) when awarded his silver medal at IOI 2010, Canada.

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
I think TopCoder SRMs are the most exciting online competitions. I learn alot of types of problems in SRMs and cool coding styles by looking at other people’s solutions.

I also meet new friends in the Arena chat room, and we often chat before SRM begins.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Last month I was struggling to move away from my shaky blue-yellow rating performance. I felt very happy when I was quite far from that rating boundary. My next project is working hard to reach the red rating

My team and I were also practicing a lot for the upcoming ICPC Asia Jakarta Regional Contest. It is our first year in university, and we would like to do well in our first ICPC regional.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
Probably no specific career or place. However, I always dream I could travel around the world as a good coder.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
I usually don’t eat while competing, but when I am out of ideas during the coding phase I like to drink some cold tea.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Playing table tennis with college friends and reading good puzzle books.

What is your lucky charm when competing?
I don’t believe in lucky charms. I usually take a bath minutes before the SRM to make my body and mind fresh, prepare pen and paper, and pray seconds before it starts.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
rng_58. I often read his solutions because his code is concise and elegant. The problemsets he wrote for SRMs were very nice, too. When I heard that he won the TCO Algorithm Final, I was very happy.

Design: gevak


The university gevak graduated from.

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
The pleasure to prove to myself that I can do it well and earn money using my head.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Definitely the TC direct update architecture, it was huge.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
Hard to say, my interests change very often, unfortunately I hardly can keep motivation for the same project for a long time.

For me, one of the largest advantages of TC freelancing is having new projects every week.

Four years ago the job of my dreams would be a TC algorithm coordinator. Nowadays I’m very happy with full-timing designs and architectures. It’s very exciting and allows to earn more if you work more.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
No, it takes too much effort, time and risk of damaging the laptop.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Between contests – eating and sleeping only

Instead of contests – watching TV, movies, etc, having fun with friends, playing poker, in the summer – walking and sometimes playing football. I also like traveling and swimming (preferable in a warm clean sea).

What is your lucky charm when competing?
Nothing. Though I probably should find some since, IMO, I was unlucky in last DR.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
SnapDragon is awesome, I’ve learned his “doit()” and instantly became red. His code is an art

Among designers, argolite is a brilliant example of professionalism and inhuman workability.

Hard to say about admins, didn’t worked with them very close, but what I’ve noticed and like
is how WishingBone writes RS’s – they give quite a lot of freedom for designer and usually allow to make enhancements and get higher scores.

Studio: vcsenge


vcsenge’s favourite thing in Budapest is that they have a hill in the middle of the city.

What is the major return you get from Studio competitions?
I can learn how to design something the client likes. It is really special in these competitions because usually in other competitions we need to design something really new, fresh, trendy, extreme… but matter of fact this is not what a simple, useable user interface should be. So through these competitions I have learned much about the clean, self-understanding, useable UIs – this is very useful in the case of every “real life project”.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Collaboration Portal Design. I really like these competitions where we design something from nothing.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
I would like to design new applications and services for mobile devices.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while designing?
I usually forget to eat at all when working but I drink tea all the time.

When you’re not competing at Studio, what can we find you doing?
I am still studying at the university, so it takes all my time. I can do TopCoder only in those few hours I can spare.

What is your lucky charm when designing?
My giant bear named Szörpamacs.

Who is your favorite Studio member or admin and why?
Jess (Jessica Williams) She has helped me so many times… If I have any question she answers in a few minutes. I would like to thank her again.

item.title: Request a Copilot
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: TopCoder customers can now use Cockpit to reach out the the TopCoder Community for leadership in managing contests and projects. Customers post their project needs/goals/etc. via Cockpit and the TopCoder Copilots can opt to propose how they will deliver your … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: TopCoder customers can now use Cockpit to reach out the the TopCoder Community for leadership in managing contests and projects. Customers post their project needs/goals/etc. via Cockpit and the TopCoder Copilots can opt to propose how they will deliver your project using the TopCoder Platform. The Copilot with the winning “proposal” will become your Copilot and will immediately begin working with you and the TopCoder Community to deliver your project.

You may have already noticed some new pages in Cockpit. The views are aimed at giving the user an aggregate view of the health of their projects, platform usage stats vs. market stats and a heads up display for making decisions about live contests.

You can currently use the Enterprise and Contest Dashboard views. The Project Health dashboard is due to release at the end of this week, so keep a lookout for it.

item.title: Introducing the September Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the September coders and designers of the month. Algorithm: Shato Design: tomaM Development: utlovey Studio: djackmania Algorithm: Shato What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions? TopCoder competitions help me to code as fast as possible … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the September coders and designers of the month.

Algorithm: Shato
Design: tomaM
Development: utlovey
Studio: djackmania

Algorithm: Shato

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
TopCoder competitions help me to code as fast as possible and without bugs. I guess that is the major return.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Last month, we organized the Turkey Local Contest. There was an unsolved problem in the problem set, about Computational Geometry. That was one of the hardest problems I worked last month.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
As a career, after Master’s degree I plan to do PhD. After PhD, I would work in some “research and development company” related with my research area.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
During SRM’s, usually I don’t eat, but periodically I drink some water. I think, water is the best way to ‘refresh’ the mind.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Going out with friends, playing tennis and soccer.

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
My laptop

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
My favourite member is Vasyl[alphacom]. He had a great effort for our ACM training camp in Turkey, in June 2010. My ‘real’ trainings for contests started after that camp. It was a pleasure to have such a trainer.

Moreover, as many of the TopCoder members do, I admire Petr. I hope that, someday I will have an oportunity to be his student.

Design: tomaM


People’s palace building. If you ever go to Bucharest you have to see it. It’s the 2nd largest building in the world by surface area.

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
First it would be a lot of adrenalin and sometimes close to a heart attack when I see reviews. The rest is a nice combination of experience and money.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Studio Replatforming project. It had two modules and the second one was very large and required lots of research. Never read this much code in a week.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
I would be a presenter for a TV show like TopGear or racing team driver. I love cars, own and ride daily a Honda Shadow bike that I almost tear down into pieces and built it back up. Whenever I feel down, I just go for a ride.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
I find myself forgetting to eat while competing. Then the night falls and I have to chose between sleep and food. I usually chose sleep but the next morning I would eat 3 meals for breakfast.
Drinking is another story, and I’m drinking various kinds of tea. I love tea and we have lots of flavors over here.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Riding my bike, hanging out with friends, reading a good book, listening to music. The usual.

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
I don’t believe in lucky charms.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
I have lots of project managers that helped me over time. I also like the work copilots are doing now and I’ve worked well with Ghostar, Indemar and lmmortal. They’re very responsive and any issue you have with the projects they manage, they will get out of their way to help you.

Development: utlovey

Studio: djackmania


djackmania and family at Borobudur, the world heritage

What is the major return you get from Studio competitions?
upgraded skill and time management and off course the earned price

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I think the ipad project, since this is new to studio.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
an astronout and become a mayor of the moon

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while designing?
No meals while designing

When you’re not competing at Studio, what can we find you doing?
playing with my kids

What is your lucky charm when designing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
No ideas, my long hair?

Who is your favorite Studio member or admin and why?
Jess, adam & chris, because they have been taking care Studio until like now as a pleasant place to work.

item.title: TCO10 Begins!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: It’s October 11 and the start of the 2010 TopCoder Open! This premier, annual event started in March and the culmination four of the competition tracks begin tomorrow in Las Vegas, Nevada. Even if you can’t make it to the … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
It’s October 11 and the start of the 2010 TopCoder Open! This premier, annual event started in March and the culmination four of the competition tracks begin tomorrow in Las Vegas, Nevada.

Even if you can’t make it to the onsite event, we have many ways to keep you up-to-date on the action. We’ve got photos, movies, blogs, tweets, and even comics! Keep following the event as we count down to crowning the next TopCoder Champions!

Good luck to all the finalists!

item.title: Alcatel Lucent launches 100 Apps in 100 Days with $165K Prizes
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: TopCoder is proud to announce the official launching of PayPal X Contests powered by TopCoder; a community for developers interested in developing and competing with PayPal X technologies! PayPal X is the only global payments platform open to third-party developers, … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder is proud to announce the official launching of PayPal X Contests powered by TopCoder; a community for developers interested in developing and competing with PayPal X technologies!

PayPal X is the only global payments platform open to third-party developers, and they want to tap into the minds of TopCoder’s best and brightest to compete! PayPal will be launching contests for all sorts of cool projects – from designing and building new apps, to testing, reviewing and working on their SDK’s. There will even be contests working on their mobile libraries and products!

Compete, get paid, and build up your skills developing on the Platform that can allow you to tap into the world’s most-loved way to pay and get paid – PayPal!

Join at http://paypalx.topcoder.com. Good luck!

item.content:encoded: Announcing the Alcatel-Lucent Web Mashup Challenge! Another one? That’s right, your favorite open challenge sponsor is bringing another $40,000 to the table to see what you can do mashing up their Web Client Framework APIs with Facebook. Due to the timing of this challenge, you can submit your application to the 100 Apps in 100 Days Challenge too! But you need to hurry, you have only 18 days to earn yourself the $15,000 grand prize. See the full challenge requirements here.

item.title: Ilium Weekly Release Assembly Contests
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: We are pleased and happy to announce that the Ilium project, with the help of many of our members, has made its way to production and is bringing in revenue for our client. We are now engaged in resolving outstanding … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: We are pleased and happy to announce that the Ilium project, with the help of many of our members, has made its way to production and is bringing in revenue for our client. We are now engaged in resolving outstanding issues and optimizing the site for both user experience and digital marketing. Please keep watch for our Release Assembly contests that are to start soon. These contests are being run on a fixed weekly schedule, and will follow the exact same schedule each week. You can even check the ILIUM Jira project to get insight into the kinds of issues that we will be working on in future weeks. Good luck!

item.title: Congratulations to the August Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congrats to the Coders and Designers for the month of August; Algorithm: ir5, Design: caru, Development: tmlshirley, Studio: iamtong. TopCoder did some exclusive interviews with the winners, enjoy! Algorithm: ir5 This is the photo ir5 took at Kinkaku-ji(Temple of the … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congrats to the Coders and Designers for the month of August; Algorithm: ir5, Design: caru, Development: tmlshirley, Studio: iamtong. TopCoder did some exclusive interviews with the winners, enjoy!

Algorithm: ir5


This is the photo ir5 took at Kinkaku-ji(Temple of the Golden Pavilion), one of tourist spot in Kyoto (ir5′s hometown).

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
Of course, participating competitions will enhance my insight of math and algorithm, and also I enjoy them like on-line-game.

SRMs, where hundreds of people participate and compete at the same time, are exciting by itself, and I would be happy when I get good outcome. In addition, it is also attractive that SRMs are relatively frequently put on.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
The hardst problem I worked on is Old Memories, the problem used for ACM/ICPC Japan domestic contest of this year.

In this problem coding a program that runs in acceptable time at the worst case is very hard.
I thought much but I have not solved it yet!!

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
Well, I have no idea… But if I could be anything, I would like to be a scientist or something.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
I drink much tea when I cannot find a solution and I get upset.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Lately I solve some problems at Online Judge for practice of ACM/ICPC and other contests. This online judge covers many problems that was used for domestic contests, so I solve them intriguingly.

What is your lucky charm when competing?
I put a red cute stuffed cat on my desk.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
I respect many TopCoder members, but my favorite coders are rng_58, (iwi), wata, LayCurse, yasuh.
I often learn fron their algorithm and solution.

Design: caru


caru’s home town, Livigno, seen from the top of a mountain.

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
Flexibility of working place and schedule.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I don’t think there was a particularly hard project.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
I would be the owner of a web/software company, like TopCoder.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
Almost everything.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Mountain biking, snowboarding, reading, hiking, coding, sky-watching, juggling, singing.

What is your lucky charm when competing?
No lucky charms.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
argolite, because in my opinion he is the most determined and strong competitor in the Design side of TopCoder software, especially in the long run, like in the current TCO.

Studio: iamtong

What is the major return you get from Studio competitions?
Well, this place makes me become stronger on both design skill and mentality.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
It was the Doja Chat application storyboard design, there were no guidelines or any references.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
A Chef, of course in my own restaurant

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while designing?
Cups of coffee!

When you’re not competing at Studio, what can we find you doing?
Hanging out at my favorite coffee shop.

What is your lucky charm when designing?
I don’t have any, but I always avoid 4 – column layout, never been successful with it, not even get the milestone prizes (I’ve tried it about 4 times).

Who is your favorite Studio member or admin and why?
I’ve got a lot here are some of them….
gh3ablo is a quick and energetic bug racer/ designer, I’ve always been impressed by oninkxronda’s designs, idblack also shows a lot of potential, new members such as gando, brandonWind have good attitude, invisiblepilot always provided such detailed/helpful feedback, adroc loves questions – he always seems nervous when members don’t ask
