item.title: Announcing TCO10 Champions and Finalists!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: TopCoder is proud to announce the Design and Development Champions of the 2010 TopCoder Open! Congratulations to the Design Champion, argolite, from Canada! Read more about the competition here. Congratulations to the Development Champion, Yeung, from China! Yeung also qualified … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder is proud to announce the Design and Development Champions of the 2010 TopCoder Open!

Congratulations to the Design Champion, argolite, from Canada!

Read more about the competition here.

Congratulations to the Development Champion, Yeung, from China! Yeung also qualified as a Mod Dash finalist as well!

Read more about the competition here.

Congratulations also goes to the Semifinalists and Finalists for the Algorithm Competition, Marathon Competition, Mod Dash Competition, and Studio Design Competition!A special congratulations goes out to ACRush and wata for being finalists in the Algorithm Competition as well as the Marathon Competition!

View them here:
Algorithm Semifinalists
Marathon Finalists
Mod Dash Finalists
Studio Design Semifinalists

Read more here.

These past few months have been pure madness with so many competitions and so many TCO10 points. Congratulations to each and every participant for taking part in this premier event!

We would also like to thank our bloggers, Nickolas, Ghostar, and connect4 for dedicating their time to keep you all up to date on the latest happenings with TCO10. If you haven’t checked out the TCO10 blog, view it here.

The TCO10 finals are a month away. Be sure to be available to check out all the happenings as we post them on TCO10 website. Four more TopCoder Champions to come…!

item.description: The TopCoder Issue Tracker (running in Jira) has been upgraded to version 4.1.2. You’ll notice a new look when you login as well as some useful new features. I particularly like the Activity Stream gadget as well as the enhanced … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The TopCoder Issue Tracker (running in Jira) has been upgraded to version 4.1.2. You’ll notice a new look when you login as well as some useful new features. I particularly like the Activity Stream gadget as well as the enhanced searching features that allow for adhoc filtering.

Feel free to customize your interface with your own dashboards and choice of gadgets.

Thanks,
Tony

item.title: Announcing 100 Apps in 100 Days!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: 100 Apps in 100 Days and more than a 100 reasons to compete! Reason number 47: 100 prizes for ideas! Join this competition sponsored by Alcatel-Lucent and Programmable Web. Create apps within industry verticals and on specific platforms: iOS (iPhone/iPad/iPod … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
100 Apps in 100 Days and more than a 100 reasons to compete!

Reason number 47: 100 prizes for ideas!

Join this competition sponsored by Alcatel-Lucent and Programmable Web. Create apps within industry verticals and on specific platforms: iOS (iPhone/iPad/iPod Touch), Android, Feature Phones, and Web.

Reason number 16: 100 cash prizes for completed apps!

Have some good ideas for apps but don’t have the time or budget to get them done? 100 Apps in 100 Days is your motivation!

Reason number 84: Win the chance to pitch your application to Alcatel-Lucent executives!

Have a creative mind and the skills to build apps for travel, healthcare, financial services, retail, and media? 100 Apps in 100 Days needs your help!

Reason number 7: Three trips will be given away to South by Southwest (SXSW) 2011!

Check out all the details here.

Reason number 1: Grand prize is a trip to the Mobile World Congress!

Best of luck to you and looking forward to seeing your apps!

item.title: Auto Quote Insurance Project – Bug Hunt Launched
item.dc:creator: silvasurfas
item.description: TopCoder is working with a client to rebuild the client’s auto insurance quote web site. As a part of this project, we have completely overhauled the frontend and backend. With all changes we’ve made, we need to validate that the … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder is working with a client to rebuild the client’s auto insurance quote web site. As a part of this project, we have completely overhauled the frontend and backend. With all changes we’ve made, we need to validate that the insurance quotes being generated are the same between the two sites. And we need your help! Click here to learn more!

If you’re interested act fast, the contest is running for less than 36 hours!

item.title: Write Recipes, Win Stuff!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: We are continuing to write recipes for the Algorithm and Marathon parts of the TopCoder Cookbook. To provide some extra motivation on this project, we are adding short-term rewards. The first 12 contributors to deliver an approved recipe for one … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
We are continuing to write recipes for the Algorithm and Marathon parts of the TopCoder Cookbook. To provide some extra motivation on this project, we are adding short-term rewards.

The first 12 contributors to deliver an approved recipe for one of these chapters, will win a TopCoder t-shirt. The t-shirt will be shipped out as soon as the review board approves the recipe – no waiting for the book to be published!

Each of the eligible recipes must be done by only one person from start to finish; with optional comments from other members. This means that you have either to finish a recipe you have already submitted in round 1 or 2, or write a recipe nobody has started yet.

We also want to remind you that the top 60 contributors on the Cookbook project receive a free copy of the Cookbook once it is published. So far it is virtually every competitor, so hurry up to grab your freebies!

See the list of recipes available for finishing and writing from scratch here.

As usual, all comments and questions can be posted to the forums or directly to TopCoder member Nickolas, here michaylova@gmail.com.

PayPal X is the only global payments platform open to third-party developers, … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder is proud to announce the official launching of PayPal X Contests powered by TopCoder; a community for developers interested in developing and competing with PayPal X technologies!

PayPal X is the only global payments platform open to third-party developers, and they want to tap into the minds of TopCoder’s best and brightest to compete! PayPal will be launching contests for all sorts of cool projects – from designing and building new apps, to testing, reviewing and working on their SDK’s. There will even be contests working on their mobile libraries and products!

Compete, get paid, and build up your skills developing on the Platform that can allow you to tap into the world’s most-loved way to pay and get paid – PayPal!

Join at http://paypalx.topcoder.com. Good luck!

item.title: TopCoder Community, Let’s Get Out the Vote!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: We’re asking all of you to help us with a chance to send a group of TopCoder admins and members to the ultra cool South By Southwest Interactive conference next March. Vote for the TopCoder presentation titled On Demand Software … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
We’re asking all of you to help us with a chance to send a group of TopCoder admins and members to the ultra cool South By Southwest Interactive conference next March.

Vote for the TopCoder presentation titled On Demand Software Development Platforms and if we get accepted we’ll send two TopCoder members to participate in a panel discussion with TopCoder admins and moderated by community management guru Dr. Karim Lakhani of the Harvard Business School. Registration is required.

Here’s where it gets fun: If we get selected, we’ll hold a community-wide vote to decide which lucky members get an expense-paid trip to go to SXSW in Austin TX, USA to represent the community on the panel!

So why are you waiting? Get going and vote for us now! On Demand Software Development Platforms

Tell your friends! Your vote is important!

item.title: Meet the July Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the July Coders and Designers of the Month! Algorithm: Anton[SUrSU] Anton[SUrSU] What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions? I have fun while solving interesting algorithmic and software design problems. I like analyzing different approaches and … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the July Coders and Designers of the Month!

Algorithm: Anton[SUrSU]


Anton[SUrSU]

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
I have fun while solving interesting algorithmic and software design problems. I like analyzing different approaches and techniques, studying new areas in Computer Science. And it’s a great possibility to realize my ambitions in competitions like TopCoder SRM’s.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I’ve been working on increasing my skills in algorithms and data structures for 2 months. TopCoder Algorithm Arena is a great world where I started to live. Besides algorithmic area I was involved in the development of the new platform for the large business intelligence application named CorVu. It was a significant practice for me.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
I`ve already had it . There are so many interesting areas in Computer Science where I would want to be a Professional and share experience with other people, give them my best practices.
Now Google Company is my dream. I`d like to work there.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
I don’t eat while solving problems.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
I like reading adventure stories and programming articles, traveling over the world and spending time with my dear girlfriend Jane.

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
Usually I invoke God’s blessing Luck, peace and quiet are enough for me.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
I am impressed by many TopCoder members. But my favorite players are Petr, UdH-WiNGeR, rng_58, tourist. I like to study their solutions which have a clear algorithm and high programming culture. It’s a good way to improve current skills.

Design: mekanizumu


Hometown Sichuan province

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
Work flexibility and free time.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Data Stewardship JSF Action Handlers 1.0.
This one involves JSF, which is very complex.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
I’d like to do TC as long as it’s good. I simply want to work at home.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
I don’t eat or drink while competing. That’s bad for the digestion system because the blood is in the brain, not in the stomach.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
I’d like to play a lot of basketball and ride a BIG motorbike while working on TC for a living.

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
I don’t have any lucky charm.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
romanoTC is my favorite co-pilot. He is very responsible and provide considerate support to all contestants.

Development: BeBetter

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
Sharpening my skill of programming.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
TC Direct software launch series and Jachin series. Both were hard.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
I would be an iron chef on food network. Maybe I watch it a little bit too much …

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
Aloe drink. it is refreshing.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Playing with my kids.

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
Nothing.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
bchops, mashannon168 and murphydog (copilot). They are very responsive and helpful in the competitions I am involved.

Studio: oninkxronda


oninkxronda and his wife during their out of town vacation at Cebu, Philippines

What is the major return you get from Studio competitions?
Great earnings, creative and design skills development.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
No specific project. I think it’s just a time management problem. I’ve been busy with my work at the same time as a lot of family events and gatherings.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
Managing my own business, a resort in my hometown, or a design studio for print, web, photography and advertising in Manila.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while designing?
Potato chips, dried mangoes and a glass of water.

When you’re not competing at Studio, what can we find you doing?
Spending time with my wife and daughter, working for Bleam and Bluewire, doing some freelance work and personal projects.

What is your lucky charm when designing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
I don’t have any lucky item…I think it’s my daughter, she inspired me most of the time.
I used to work late for studio contests and she always gives her goodnight kiss before she goes to bed and says goodluck daddy.

Who is your favorite Studio member or admin and why?
Everyone is nice, I guess Jess, Jessie and Adam are more approachable.

item.description: Want to go to the iOSDevCamp 2010 in San Jose, California? Then get your team together for the Alcatel-Lucent App Strike Force 1! Teams need to submit their idea for an app to be built at the event and if … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Want to go to the iOSDevCamp 2010 in San Jose, California? Then get your team together for the Alcatel-Lucent App Strike Force 1!

Teams need to submit their idea for an app to be built at the event and if their idea is chosen, the team will be flying high to San Jose to attend the event and build it. So get your team together and start brainstorming!

Prizes include the trip to the iOSDevCamp 2010, cash, and whatever your team wins at the event is yours! The contest is running now at Studio and will conclude on August 12. Check out all the details here.

item.title: TopCoder UML Tool 1.2.5 Released
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: An upgrade to the TopCoder UML Tool has been released. Please visit the tool’s homepage to download the latest. Thanks to Ghostar for managing the updates! Release Notes – TopCoder UML Tool – Version 1.2.5 Bugs [UML-518] – Code generation: … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
An upgrade to the TopCoder UML Tool has been released. Please visit the tool’s homepage to download the latest.

Thanks to Ghostar for managing the updates!

Release Notes – TopCoder UML Tool – Version 1.2.5

Bugs

  • [UML-518] – Code generation: Failed to generate C# struct correctly
  • [UML-519] – Code generation: Failed to generate abstract method correctly
  • [UML-521] – Code generation: Failed to generate C# property correctly
  • [UML-522] – Code generation: Failed to generate C# event property properly
  • [UML-523] – Code generation: Failed to generate C# sealed class properly
  • [UML-524] – Code generation: Failed to generate C# sealed method properly
  • [UML-527] – Code generation: Failed to generate Java extension of interface correctly
  • [UML-528] – Code generation: Failed to generate import statements correctly (Java)
  • [UML-529] – Code generation: Failed to generate interface’s method correctly
  • [UML-530] – Code generation: Some C# documentations are generated incorrectly
  • [UML-542] – Code generation: Failed to generate C# indexer class properly
  • [UML-555] – Disappearing method names / changes not persisting
  • [UML-557] – ‘&’ in recent files open list in Settings_config.xml
  • [UML-558] – Documentation panel is not updating
  • [UML-560] – Supress SAXException when opening files
  • [UML-561] – Copy and paste in sequence diagrams
  • [UML-562] – Code generation: Duplicate classes cause empty output
  • [UML-563] – Generic method signature parsing
  • [UML-564] – Code generation: Ensure indentation matches TopCoder requirements
  • [UML-565] – Code generation: Generic types

Environment Setup

  • [UML-559] – SAXException when opening string_filter.zuml file; Need to specify UML:ActionExpression in XMIReader_config.xml

item.title: Meet the June Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the June coders and designers of the month! Check out their interviews. Algorithm: Dembel Harbin’10, ACM ICPC Finals What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions? I just have fun solving problems on competitions. What was … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the June coders and designers of the month! Check out their interviews.

Algorithm: Dembel


Harbin’10, ACM ICPC Finals

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
I just have fun solving problems on competitions.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
For the whole month I’ve been having fun, having rest and staying away from business.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
I would be writer and create new imaginary worlds.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
Usually I don’t eat and drink.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Studying, reading, spending time with my friends.

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
Most important tradition is to have a shave before important competitions.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
Don’t think I have one.

Development: FireIce


FireIce

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
I can learn some new technology and solidify my current skills. I think the best way to grasp a new technology is to do it. Also I can earn some cash.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Well, all the projects I worked on last month are not very complicated. I think the biggest problem is to make the submission as perfect as possible with little time as I have a regular job to do.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
I’d like to setup a company that can be built to last:)

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
I don’t eat too much while competing. I usually like eating fruits, like watermelon, sugarcane etc.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Even I don’t compete at TopCoder, I like to stay at home, watching TV and movies, or go out to play basketball.

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
I don’t believe any lucky charm. I think when competing, you should do your best to eliminate every possible score-down item for your submission. I think a checklist will help you a lot.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
I like saarixx’s design. His designs are very clear and for any raised question, his responses are also very clear. And few designers will raise a Design Change thread to record the change raised in development.
This makes the forum clean. I don’t have much contact with admin. It was my honor to work with Andy (bchops) as Copliot. It is a special experience about the Software Development Process of TopCoder.

Studio: gh3ablo


gh3ablo sandboarding in a vast sand dune

What is the major return you get from Studio competitions?
Well, I get to learn new design/code techniques, learn how to correct my mistakes, and get to share what I’ve learned to others. Also what I really like about this is that when I have nothing and deadline is like 1 hour away, I get some sort of adrenaline rush – feels good, haha!.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I do consider the Submission Viewer Design contest as the hardest project I had to finish last month. There was a lot going on – I almost had no sleep because of this, but it was worth it! It was not perfect though ’cause it had a couple of things that needed fixin’, so on we went with the final fixes.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
One of my dreams is to become an CG animator in Disney/Pixar. It’s unlikely, but it’s free to dream.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while designing?
Potato chips, usually cheese flavored and a good cup of local brewed coffee.

When you’re not competing at Studio, what can we find you doing?
There are two things I like to do; a) Play video games, b) Chill on a beach. But sometimes B is not very accessible so, uhmmm… yep, probably playing video games.

What is your lucky charm when designing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
I often have my music with me as I work on stuff, mostly some popunk and (power) metal. Probably not a lucky charm, but it gets me in the mood.

Who is your favorite Studio member or admin and why?
I have some – adroc, silvasurfas, mcards13, iamtong; I like how they run contests/bugs and how they communicate with/help members.

item.title: Get Paid for Your Plug-in Idea!
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: Lotus Symphony is a suite of full featured productivity tools, including Spreadsheet, Document and Presentation. Lotus Symphony not only can be used as an office suite, but also a business application platform extended by its Eclipse based programming model and … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Lotus Symphony is a suite of full featured productivity tools, including Spreadsheet, Document and Presentation. Lotus Symphony not only can be used as an office suite, but also a business application platform extended by its Eclipse based programming model and SDK. Developers can use plug-ins to extend its functionality and integrate with other products/applications to form valuable solutions.

Come up with some creative plug-in ideas of business value and you could win! Submit more than one idea and more than one may win! See full contest details here.

item.title: Another Ilium Weekend with over $16,000 and 3,300 DR points in play!
item.dc:creator: silvasurfas
item.description: Yes, it’s another big weekend for Ilium development, help us reach our goal and be eligible for your share of the $5,565 and 660 TCO/DR points in bug races, or the $9,360 and 2,340 TCO/DR points currently offered in 2 … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: Yes, it’s another big weekend for Ilium development, help us reach our goal and be eligible for your share of the $5,565 and 660 TCO/DR points in bug races, or the $9,360 and 2,340 TCO/DR points currently offered in 2 assemblies. The Release Updates assembly is moving to a special timeline and compensation scheme: backed by an additional $2,300 in parallel ‘milestone’ bug races, we will extend the contest as milestones close, until the work nears completion. Development can be performed remotely or locally and we will provide an instance of a ready-to-go, dual-core, x64 development environment at no charge to you. A Test Scenarios opportunity is also available. More details in the forums. See you there!

item.description: With the completion of the Ilium Anonymous Checkout assembly (thank you!), TopCoder has opened up submissions for the corresponding Bug Hunt. Each contest in the Ilium Series of assemblies will go through a Bug Hunt, so now is a great … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: With the completion of the Ilium Anonymous Checkout assembly (thank you!), TopCoder has opened up submissions for the corresponding Bug Hunt. Each contest in the Ilium Series of assemblies will go through a Bug Hunt, so now is a great time to get familiar with the application. New today, you can also test every aspect of the web site remotely from your Windows XP 32bit laptop. Register here, and start submitting your bugs today!

item.title: New .NET assembly contest just launched for $3,000 first place prize
item.dc:creator: silvasurfas
item.description: TopCoder has just launched the GreatCleaners.com Anonymous Checkout Update assembly, part of the ongoing Ilium Series of assemblies. This contest is the application of several fixes to the existing GreatCleaners.com .NET 3.5 application. Primarily, we are merging in the latest … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: TopCoder has just launched the GreatCleaners.com Anonymous Checkout Update assembly, part of the ongoing Ilium Series of assemblies. This contest is the application of several fixes to the existing GreatCleaners.com .NET 3.5 application. Primarily, we are merging in the latest known good anonymous checkout feature, as built and tested in the Ilium Anonymous Checkout contest. Register now!

item.title: Win big money on a Module Architecture
item.dc:creator: silvasurfas
item.description: We’re reposting the Liquid Portal Forums and File Repository module architecture for a prize of $1800! This module is part of a system that uses an innovative technology stack, featuring DB2’s XML features on the backend, EXT-JS on the front … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: We’re reposting the Liquid Portal Forums and File Repository module architecture for a prize of $1800! This module is part of a system that uses an innovative technology stack, featuring DB2’s XML features on the backend, EXT-JS on the front end, hooked in to Lotus Connections for forum and content management. We’re planning more competitions that use Lotus Connection in the future, so this is your chance to get a head start learning this technology! Register now!

item.title: New Direct UI is open for business for Studio Contests
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: For TopCoder users that are managing contests, the next version of the Direct tool is available for use specifically for managing Stdio competitions. Besides basic browsing and awareness of your past and present contests, you can create/edit/view and launch your … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
For TopCoder users that are managing contests, the next version of the Direct tool is available for use specifically for managing Stdio competitions. Besides basic browsing and awareness of your past and present contests, you can create/edit/view and launch your Studio competitions.

Please note that Studio specification reviews have been turned off until further notice.

We hope you enjoy it and are looking forward to additional releases in the near future.

If you find any issues or have any suggestions you can log them by emailing DirectAssist@topcoder.com.

item.title: Announcing the $40,000 Alcatel-Lucent Location-Based iPad App Challenge
item.dc:creator: silvasurfas
item.description: If you are looking for an excuse to get in to iPad development, now is the time to do it! Alcatel-Lucent is asking You to come up with and build your killer iPad application featuring their Location Based Services APIs. … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: If you are looking for an excuse to get in to iPad development, now is the time to do it! Alcatel-Lucent is asking You to come up with and build your killer iPad application featuring their Location Based Services APIs. Winners will receive $10,000 each as well as having their applications featured on the openapiservice.com website and presented to top-tier wireless carriers! Fame, glory and $10,000 can be yours. Learn more.

item.title: We’ve reached 250,000 Members and Still Growing – Congratulations to the TopCoder Community!
item.dc:creator: silvasurfas
item.description: Today the TopCoder community surpassed one quarter of a million registered members around the world and we want to take this opportunity to say a big ‘thank you’ to each and every one of you who have contributed and helped … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Today the TopCoder community surpassed one quarter of a million registered members around the world and we want to take this opportunity to say a big ‘thank you’ to each and every one of you who have contributed and helped us reach this significant milestone. This is truly a shared success – congratulations to us all!

So we have a question: What does the number 250,000 mean to you? Sure, we all know that we could fill the Indianapolis Speedway with that number of people, and it’s the approximate number of distinct words in the English language – but what other fun numerical trivia comes to mind when you think of the number 250,000?

item.title: New Conceptualization Contest – Copilot Revamp Project
item.dc:creator: silvasurfas
item.description: TopCoder is embarking on a new phase where we are putting more structure around the engagement and management of copilots. This next phase is important in TopCoder’s growth so we would like the community to take part in the discussion … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: TopCoder is embarking on a new phase where we are putting more structure around the engagement and management of copilots. This next phase is important in TopCoder’s growth so we would like the community to take part in the discussion and shaping of the process. You can see the new contest live here. And here are some of the active discussions taking place.

item.title: Meet the April Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: silvasurfas
item.description: Congratulations to the Coders and Designers of the Month! We caught up with a few of them so be sure to check out their interviews. Algorithm: stjepan What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions? Fun, adrenaline, practice, … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the Coders and Designers of the Month! We caught up with a few of them so be sure to check out their interviews.

Algorithm: stjepan

stjepan's small hometown in winter (Prelog)


What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
Fun, adrenaline, practice, meeting people.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
For a very long time I was struggling with yellow color while I felt I could reach red. Performing poorly with almost no rating increase was very frustrating. Slow submissions and bugs kept me from going up, until I decided to solve some SRMs in practice rooms. I’ve managed to instantly overcome these problems and a nice rating boost appeared on my graph.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
Probably as a coder. I’m most excited about locations I’ve never been to.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
Usually a fruit, cookies or chocolate. Cappuccino is a must before night SRMs.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Hanging out with friends, playing football or basketball, studying. And coding, of course. Especially now as I’m very ambitious about the upcoming IOI in Canada.

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
There is a pair of marbles on my desk.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
No favorites!
rng_58. I have learnt a lot from his solutions. I also find his problem sets very nice.

Design: saarixx

saarixx snorkeling in Egypt


What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
Most of the time the design competitions are a full time job for me, thus of course I am mostly interested in high prizes.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
All design competitions in April (in which I’ve competed) were quite simple. The most difficult part for me was to design 3 Education components during the 4 days.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
I’d like to try a racing driver career. I am a fan of Formula 1 auto racing, but have never tried to drive myself in real life – just in computer simulators.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
When designing the components I prefer to separate eating and competing.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
After sitting the whole workweek in front of the monitors I try to recreate actively on weekend. Currently I prefer playing table/court tennis and badminton.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
My favorite PM is WishingBone. He always provides a great support in his competitions. Thanks, Jiazhi

Development: 7realm

Mountains in Crimea (Ukraine) where 7realm likes to spend time climbing the rocks


What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
An opportunity to do something as good as possible.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
All competition of last month were relatively simple. The only problem was to follow component forums because of the large number of competitors.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
It will be something related to mountains:)

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
I like to drink green tea.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Nothing like this, I rely only on my mind.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
As a developer I like to implement design works of saarixx because he provide good and clean design and forum support.

Studio: donot6

What is the major return you get from Studio competitions?
Beside the prizes, there are opportunities to work on various kind of projects.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
$1000 TC Direct – Contest Type Icon!!!

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
Farmer I’ll be working in my country, Thailand.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while designing?
Iced Coffee.

When you’re not competing at Studio, what can we find you doing?
Working on client projects, Photo shooting.

What is your lucky charm when designing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
I don’t have one, Still looking for it .

Who is your favorite Studio member or admin and why?
I don’t have one, everyone is great and helpful here.

item.content:encoded:
There are now specific contest types for Wireframes and Idea Generation. You’ll also notice a few naming tweaks on the other contest types that will hopefully make things a little clearer.

If you have an existing contest fee configuration, the Wireframes have been given the same rate as Web Page Design and Idea Generation has the same rate as Logo contests.

Enjoy!

item.title: Meet the March Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the Coders and Designers of the Month! We caught up with a few of them so be sure to check out their interviews. Design: argolite What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions? It’s my full-time … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the Coders and Designers of the Month! We caught up with a few of them so be sure to check out their interviews.

Design: argolite

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
It’s my full-time job, so it have to be the compensation.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I think that the most challenging projects are the ones looking into some new technology or new versions of existing technology. Recently we had an interesting architecture that worked with HTML 5. It was good to work on something new, but coupled with the fact that I have not worked on JavaScript in much detail in a while, made this the most challenging competition.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
probably switch to something like creative writing. I have done a bit of that a while back and really enjoyed it. The nice thing about work like that is that it can be done anywhere, sort of like my current job.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
With the amount of sitting involved in this work, I try to eat healthy as much as possible, but if it gets very intense, it usually means a lot of Pepsi and ice cream.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Trying to catch up on sleep and fresh air.

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
No lucky charms. I have learned that the best thing I can do to help in my competitions is get adequate sleep.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
No favorites!
There are a lot of PMs I enjoy working with, as they are good with their specs and responses.

Development: Yeung


Zhongshan. The scene of the city.

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
friends, technique, and prizes

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Ilium series. It uses the thing I never touch.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
A traveler around the world.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
yoghurt

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
sleep, watching movies, and traveling

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
No lucky charm.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
Dave (mess). Seems he has left. Because he was the admin who sent the Spring Festive blessing. The feeling is good. And I love his face. Cute.

Studio: picachui


My daughter enjoying a day at the beach.

What is the major return you get from Studio competitions?
I just love the competition spirit in Studio and enjoy competing with other Studio members. The competition prizes are great and help me earn while working from home.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
eAHR Wireframes- part 1 was a little hard. It was a bit difficult to understand the requirements.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
I will be a writer and travel around the world.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while designing?
Coffee, most of the time.

When you’re not competing at Studio, what can we find you doing?
Playing with or taking care of my 1.5 year old daughter.

What is your lucky charm when designing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
Nothing like that. But I always use IE browser to view the competition results.

Who is your favorite Studio member or admin and why?
I have not had much contact with the admins. I do have a lot of respect for my fellow studio competitors selvia_ettine, oton, systic and others and it is great competing with them. Even though I don’t know any of them personally, I feel they are my friends.

item.title: Next Generation Direct Preview
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: Our community is in the process of giving the Direct (Cockpit) tools a major overhaul. Tonight we released the first piece of it – a basic skeleton site that implements a few features. Visit the site. The functionality that you … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Our community is in the process of giving the Direct (Cockpit) tools a major overhaul. Tonight we released the first piece of it – a basic skeleton site that implements a few features.

Visit the site.

The functionality that you can test drive currently is:

  • Login
  • Top level dashboard view (notice the performance improvements)
  • Dashboard Calendar View
  • Navigate between projects using the sidebar controls
  • View Project’s Dashboard
  • View a Project’s list of contests with basic stats and status
  • …and some other features you’ll find scattered in

You’ll notice that most of the functionality is not released yet. Don’t worry, it’s on it’s way: Development Roadmap

You will also start to get a feel for the design and usability of the site. Feedback, as always, is much appreciated from everyone. If you would like to send in your feedback please email it to directassist@topcoder.com.

item.title: Announcing the 2010 TopCoder Open!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: TopCoder is proud to announce the 2010 TopCoder Open! $150,000 in Prizes! Six Competition Tracks! 100 Competitors WIN a Round-Trip All-Expenses Paid Trip to LAS VEGAS! Each year TopCoder strives to out do the year before and this year we feel … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder is proud to announce the 2010 TopCoder Open!

$150,000 in Prizes! Six Competition Tracks!

100 Competitors WIN a Round-Trip All-Expenses Paid Trip to LAS VEGAS!

Each year TopCoder strives to out do the year before and this year we feel confident that you’ll be wowed with the competitions, prizes, and excitement that is the TCO10!

The TCO10 has now begun with registration open for all tracks of competition. Be sure to visit each competition track details page and rules for all the information and registration deadlines.

The TCO10 six competition tracks:
* Algorithm Competition
* Design Competition
* Development Competition
* Marathon Competition
* Mod Dash Competition
* Studio Design Competition

The grand finale of the TCO10 will take place at The Mirage in Las Vegas, Nevada, USA October 11 – 14, 2010.

A special thanks goes out to all the talented members who designed and help create the TCO10 website which we think is awesome!

Logo design: rhorea and sigit.a
Icons design: djnapier
Storyboard design: leben
UI Prototype: Jooc
Leaderboard coding and Navigation edits to the Prototype: AjJi
Content coding: invisiblepilot
Wordpress skin coding: dweng
Assembly: isv

Reviewers:
Logo contests: rhorea
Icons contest: rhorea
Storyboard: greenspin
UI Prototype: invisiblepilot, selvaa89, bohuss, YeGGo
Assembly: snow01, cyberjag, BeBetter

We also want to thank our Event Patron NSA and first-time sponsor Yandex for being part of the TCO10.

Learn more about the TCO10 here.

item.title: What does the TCO mean for your contests…
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: The TCO 2010 online round has begun. You’ll notice some new banners and icons on the site. In terms of your contests, unless otherwise specified they will be included in the online qualifying rounds for the TCO. That means competitors … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The TCO 2010 online round has begun. You’ll notice some new banners and icons on the site. In terms of your contests, unless otherwise specified they will be included in the online qualifying rounds for the TCO. That means competitors have an additional incentive.

Bug Race Specifics

When you are creating new Bug Races be sure to set the TCO Points field on them like you did last year. If you don’t want it to be part of the TCO round for whatever reason, you have the option to set it to zero.

Since it is a required field, as you resolve existing Bug Races it will force you to set an amount. Set it to zero IF your Bug Race was posted prior to 9am EST today (March 29).

You have 3 point levels you can set – 10,20 or 30. Use your best judgment to determine the right setting that each Bug Race warrants.

item.title: Marathon Match 58 is Now Underway!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: TopCoder Marathon Match 58, IsolatedPrimes, has now begun. You have until April 7, 2010 at 13:00 UTC -4 to finalize your submission. Prime numbers are an integral part of many problems; perhaps most notably they appear heavily in encryption algorithms. … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder Marathon Match 58, IsolatedPrimes, has now begun. You have until April 7, 2010 at 13:00 UTC -4 to finalize your submission.

Prime numbers are an integral part of many problems; perhaps most notably they appear heavily in encryption algorithms. An isolated prime number is one that does not have very many other prime numbers nearby. In this problem, you have to try to answer questions like:
What is the smallest prime number x such that there are no other prime numbers in [x-10,x+10]?

Register and learn more here.

item.title: Congratulations to tourist, the New TCHS10 Champion!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: tourist needed just 44 minutes in order to solve all 3 problems in the Championship Round of 2010 TopCoder High School Tournament. He had to resubmit 1000-pointer, but even this did not prevent him from winning the tournament. He was … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
tourist needed just 44 minutes in order to solve all 3 problems in the Championship Round of 2010 TopCoder High School Tournament. He had to resubmit 1000-pointer, but even this did not prevent him from winning the tournament.

He was the first to submit in the match with impressive 247.80 points (2 minutes 43 seconds) on the 250-pointer, this ended up being the fastest correct solution on the Easy problem overall. However, the other competitors were close. During the first 5 minutes of the match there were 7 submissions on this problem, during the first 10 minutes there were 32.

tourist was also the first to submit the 600-pointer, it happened in the beginning of 24th minute for 444.61 points. It seemed like tourist would consolidate his lead, but other competitors were even faster. In the end of 24th minute exod40 submitted the 600-pointer for 465.72 points and took the first position leaving tourist behind. Three more submissions on 600-pointer followed on 25th minute and by its end tourist was only on 4th position.

Most important events in the match happend around 40th minute. On 39:36 neal_wu, who skipped the 600-pointer and went directly for 1000-pointer, submitted it for 591.09 and claimed the top spot. On 40:25 meret, who used the same strategy as neal_wu, submitted the 1000-pointer for 564.35 thus taking the second position. However, what was really surprising is the blazingly fast submission on 1000-pointer by tourist, 883.71 (!!!) points, he showed that it would be very hard to beat him in this match. It seemed that the first place would clearly go to him.

However, it was not so easy. On 44:05, tourist resubmitted the 1000-pointer, his new score was 720.82, but it still was much more than his nearest rival (neal_wu) had. But on 53:37, neal_wu submitted 600-pointer for very high 526.71 points (it ended up being the fastest correct solution on this problem). As a result, neal_wu appeared to be just 62 points behind tourist, so 2 successfull challenges would put him on top of standings.

Coding proceeded and more submissions on all problems came. By the end of coding phase, there were 83 submissions on 250, 48 submissions on 600 and
9 submissions on 1000. The top-5 looked as follows: tourist (1413.23), neal_wu (1361.0), ikicic (1332.05), exod40 (1299.14), lyrically (1185.09).

Challenge phase was not very eventful, but some important permutations happened within the top part of the table. ikicic’s 1000-pointer has been challenged, so exod40 moved to the third place. Additionally, exod40 gained one successfull challenge, so his score became 1349.14. At the same time neal_wu, who really needed challenged to overcome tourist, started with two unsuccessfull challenges and that lowered his score to 1311.0.

Therefore, exod40 moved to the second place and neal_wu became third instead of beating tourist. Of course, neal_wu didn’t want to agree with such result, so he tried to go for more challenges. But it was just not his day, the challenge on 09:56 was also unsuccessfull. On 14:28 he tried to challenged his rival exod40, but again unsuccessfully. He got his successfull challenge on 14:53, but it was not enough even to reclaim the second place.

Systests broke a lot of submissions on 250 and 600 pointers, but left the top competitors untouched.

tourist became TCHS10 Champion with a score of 1413,23. The second place goes to exod40 (1349,14), neal_wu is third (1311,0). The fourth and fifth places were taken by Japanese coders lyrically and rng_58 (1185,09 and 1088,05). The only other competitor who solved the 1000-pointer, meret, is on 6th place (1057,81).

Commentary provided by mystic_tc.

item.title: Write Your Recipe for TopCoder Cookbook!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Don’t miss your chance to get into the book! TopCoder is now starting the next phase of writing recipes for TopCoder Cookbook. The list of recipes to be written is available at here, and now we’re looking for members to … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Don’t miss your chance to get into the book! TopCoder is now starting the next phase of writing recipes for TopCoder Cookbook. The list of recipes to be written is available at here, and now we’re looking for members to fill the slots (recipes marked with a “-” on the list).

The contest for writing missing recipes has now started and will end at 13:00 GMT -4 on Monday, April 19, 2010. The format of this competition is as follows: during the competition anybody can submit any recipes. After the end of competition the review board will choose the best of the submitted recipes for each slot and possibly ask the author to do some final fixes.

The recipe submissions for this phase should be be posted to the forums referenced here:
Algorithm recipes
Marathon recipes

Each recipe should be posted as a separate thread. You can base your recipes on existing articles from TopCoder educational content, but must indicate this in your post. Content must otherwise be original.

Please see this forum for general discussion of Cookbook project. The Cookbook recipe writing standards can be found here.

item.title: TCHS10 Championship Round Has Arrived!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: The 2010 TopCoder High School Championship Round will kick off at 12:00 UTC -4 on Saturday, March 20, 2010 and it is sure to be a great round! Watch as the top competitors battle for their share of the $10,000 … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The 2010 TopCoder High School Championship Round will kick off at 12:00 UTC -4 on Saturday, March 20, 2010 and it is sure to be a great round!

Watch as the top competitors battle for their share of the $10,000 prize purse! Competitors neal_wu, tourist, rng_58, and meret have been in top places for each round so far but who will ultimately come out on top?

Join all the Championship Round competitors in the Competition Arena to see who will become our next High School Champion! You won’t want to miss this event to cheer your favorite coders on!

Who knows TopCoder best? We think you do! TopCoder is in the process of launching a new homepage and we’re asking our community to help us write the content.

We need you to help us explain what our competitive community www.topcoder.com/tc is all about to new and returning visitors.

Read more about the contest here.

If you have never competed on Studio before, that is not a problem, it’s easy! We need your help, so get over there and show us your technical and creative writing skills!!

Best of luck to you!

item.title: Meet the February Coders and Designers of the Month
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the February Coders and Designers of the Month! We are happy to hear from all of them this month. Algorithm: awakia Here is awakia at a Japanese-style pub “Izakaya”. There he can enjoy many kinds of foods and … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the February Coders and Designers of the Month! We are happy to hear from all of them this month.

Algorithm: awakia


Here is awakia at a Japanese-style pub “Izakaya”. There he can enjoy many kinds of foods and drinks. He is on the left with lab members.

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
TopCoder brings me exciting times! Algorithm competitions are like a refreshment of daily life. Discussions on the Twitter after the competition also make me fan.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Job Hunting!
Due to Lehman Shock, it’s tough time…

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
I would want to program a human, though I don’t know I can do that. If there were any projects like that, I would join the project.

I have no preference about place, so anywhere is acceptable.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
I eat nothing, but I often eat instant noodles after the competition.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Sleeping, playing badminton, talking with friends, writing report, or coding anyway.

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
I don’t have any lucky charm… But, as you may know, a piece of paper helps me a lot while competing.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
rng_58

He is high school coder, but his codes are like mathematical equations. I often read his code to study. Additionally, he sometimes sets SRM problems and they are all interesting. So I respect him.

Design: moonli

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
I learn a lot from TopCoder competitions, including algorithm and software skills and how to cooperate with others.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I think it’s “Interactive DDL Wrapper”, which is in a large scope, and I didn’t have enough time to work on it, it made me nervous at that time.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
Mostly a software engineer, in some place in my country.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
Tea made with fresh tea leaves and gum, which make me relax.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Gaming, mountain climbing, or cooking.

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
Honestly speaking, I don’t have a lucky charm, I just don’t believe in something like that.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
Haha, Jessie D’Amato Ford! Always good news comes in her email.

Development: Lunarmony


Beautiful sunset near lunarmony’s home.

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
Practice opportunities and earnings.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
There were no particularly hard projects. Fixing bugs in assembly competitions can get annoying, though.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
Any career that allows me to maximize my potential.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
I don’t think it is good to eat while working in front of a computer.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Well… virtually everything…

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
I don’t believe in such things.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
ACRush.

Studio: oninkxronda


Here is oninkxronda on a family trip to Hong Kong last year.

What is the major return you get from Studio competitions?
Aside from great additional earnings, I enhance my design skills and speed.

I’m having fun competing.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
It’s not really the hardest project, I think it’s more a situation…I was working on a t-shirt design last month with my daughter in the hospital.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
Well, I’d love to travel, taking photos around the world. All expenses paid.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while designing?
Jack’nJill Pretzel chocolate sticks and a glass of water.

When you’re not competing at Studio, what can we find you doing?
I’m working at Offshoring Inc. Monday to Friday, 7am to 4pm.

During weekend I play PS3 with my wife, having fun with my 2 year old daughter, teaching her how to read, write, draw, color, solve a puzzle and sometimes teaching her how to hold a computer mouse.

What is your lucky charm when designing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
I don’t really have any specific lucky charm or food item. I always have my energy drink that keeps me awake during late night deadlines.

Who is your favorite Studio member or admin and why?
I already met Jess and Jessie in Vegas, they’re nice and approachable.

TopCoder is actively seeking a high quality, experienced, full time Platform Manager to work on our ever-growing list of clients. If you know someone who is interested in working as a PM, tell us.

If they are hired by TopCoder, you get paid! The referring member (you)* will receive $1,000 for the full time PM that we hire based on your referral.

Everybody wins!

For more information on the position available go here.

*Only candidates who are legal residents of the United States and Canada are eligible for the referral fee.

item.title: Ilium Development Sprint
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: We are now releasing new site wireframes so members registered on our contests can begin to see what it is our TopCoder designers have been striving towards. For the last couple of months we’ve been running contests to design a … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
We are now releasing new site wireframes so members registered on our contests can begin to see what it is our TopCoder designers have been striving towards.

For the last couple of months we’ve been running contests to design a new e-commerce web site built upon Microsoft Commerce Server’s Sharepoint Commerce Services. While a large application, it has been broken down into more than 20 small components, and those components use standard Microsoft .NET technologies like .NET 3.5 and ASP.NET Web Parts.

Get involved and join us as we build this new, public facing, world-class web site! There’s never been a better time to bring your talent to our team of over 200 TopCoder members who have already participated.

For more information including dedicated project forums, VM information, and downloads, visit the E-Commerce Sites Project Hub.

item.title: BIG Ideas needed for the Computational Thinking Idea Contest
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: TopCoder just launched the TopCoder Computational Thinking Idea Contest and we’re counting on you for BIG ideas! We are interested in creating one or more new types of competitions that would appeal to grade school level kids (~ ages 12 … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder just launched the TopCoder Computational Thinking Idea Contest and we’re counting on you for BIG ideas!

We are interested in creating one or more new types of competitions that would appeal to grade school level kids (~ ages 12 through 18) who may not yet have discovered an aptitude or appreciation for mathematics or computer programming.

Back in December, we asked for some ideas along the same lines in this forum thread and got some good ideas.

We decided to run an idea generation contest for some more great stuff and will be giving away up to five prizes of $300 each for the idea submissions that we believe are good enough for us to actually follow through and build out.

Please read the full contest details here for all the important information.

item.title: Announcing the 2010 TopCoder High School tournament!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: TopCoder is excited to announce the 2010 TopCoder High School tournament! High school students from all over the world will be competing against one another for scholarship prizes and top bragging rights. Read more about TCHS here. Last year crazyb0y … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder is excited to announce the 2010 TopCoder High School tournament! High school students from all over the world will be competing against one another for scholarship prizes and top bragging rights. Read more about TCHS here.

Last year crazyb0y took home the grand prize but this year we are looking for a fresh new face to wow us with their talent and become our High School Champion! Do you have what it takes?


There is no separate registration required to compete in the TCHS10; you must be registered TopCoder high school member and the first round is February 27, 2010 at 12:00 UTC -5. Join us in the Competition Arena for the first showdown.

If you are new to TopCoder, be sure to read more about Single Round Matches (SRMs) here.

If you still have questions, be sure to get involved in the forums.

See the full schedule for the TCHS10 here.

Also be sure to read the official rules and regulations

Thousands can compete but only one can be the champion! Best of luck to you!

item.title: Meet the January Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to our coders and designers of the month for January. Enjoy their interviews! Algorithm: aurinegro Here is aurinegro in China at the ACM ICPC 2010 Finals. What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions? I have fun, … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to our coders and designers of the month for January. Enjoy their interviews!

Algorithm: aurinegro

Here is aurinegro in China at the ACM ICPC 2010 Finals.

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
I have fun, I learn, and sometimes I get a t-shirt

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I don’t know if the hardest, but the one that I dedicated most time lately would be training on an ACM ICPC team (Ni JiRaFa from Universidad Nacional de La Plata) for the World Finals that will be held this week on Harbin, China.

We did a mini Training Camp back at my apartment in Buenos Aires. We spent a week doing contest rehearsals every day and discussing problems.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
I’ve got an ever increasing interest for an academic career. Probably, getting a PhD and doing Scientific Research on Algorithms would be a good plan for me. Where? If I had to choose I’d like to live and work in Europe for some time.

Google sounds as an interesting option as well.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
I usually don’t eat anything while competing. I sometimes drink mate, a typical infusion very popular in Argentina.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
I don’t know, I could be doing many different things. I like to play football and basketball. Meeting with friends, going to the park. I started to swim last year. Sometimes I’ve got to study (I’m finishing a Computer Science degree). I really enjoy watching movies, I’m quite a cinephile. And, from time to time, I just like to do nothing at all.

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
I don’t have any item that I consider a source of luck. Some time ago, I used to get ready for the contest with a little anticipation, test that everything was working fine, set a quiet environment, listen to some music, and relax. But lately, I just grab the laptop and compete when I feel like doing it.

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
I must say is Petr. I always saw him as a model to follow. His codes are really clear, and he solves almost any problem.

When I started to compete at Topcoder, he was performing incredibly well, he took Ranking #1 from Tomek’s long streak, and won Google Code Jam. I guess he became my favourite from that time, when I was just starting with this.

Design: flying2hk

Pingyao, China – a very old town dating back to 827 B.C, inscripted by UNESCO as a World Heritage.

What is the major return you get from TopCoder competitions?
Flexible working schedule and great earnings.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
The first several XOWL components really took me a while to understand the overall architecture and how they fit together.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
Well, doing what J. K. Rowling has been doing I guess.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while competing?
Potato crisps + cold water.

When you’re not competing at TopCoder, what can we find you doing?
Mostly reading, or, sleeping

What is your lucky charm when competing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
Potato crisps, again

Who is your favorite TopCoder member or admin and why?
WishingBone – an idol in the Chinese TopCoder circle.

Studio: selvia_ettine

selvia_ettine (on right) with her sister.

What is the major return you get from Studio competitions?
The prizes are great! But more than that is the experience of collaborating with people from all around the world on a project and make everything possible.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Probably the Jachin Project Resource Tracker Dashboard Wireframe. Making the wireframe to be dynamic sized was complicated, but it was a new and good experience for me.

If you could have any career in the world, what would you be doing and where would you be working?
I would be an astronaut working in the International Space Station.

What can we find you eating and/or drinking while designing?
Tea, tea, and more tea…

When you’re not competing at Studio, what can we find you doing?
Playing my Nintendo DS.

What is your lucky charm when designing? For example, special shirt, stuffed animal, or food item?
I don’t really have any lucky charm. I do have a habit of biting my nails when working though

Who is your favorite Studio member or admin and why?
I like all admins and members. Everyone is very helpful.

item.title: Competition Reposts and New Versions of Components
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: Hi All, Just want to give you a quick update on a couple things that were added to Cockpit tonight. 1 . Any contest that is in a “failed” state (i.e. cancelled – blah, blah) will have a “Repost” option … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Hi All,

Just want to give you a quick update on a couple things that were added to Cockpit tonight.

1 . Any contest that is in a “failed” state (i.e. cancelled – blah, blah) will have a “Repost” option in the dropdown next to the contest. It’ll prompt you when you select it to confirm that you want to repost and tells you no additional fee is applied (the contest fee will be zero) . It copies the original contest with a start date of today + 48 hours. The contest will be in “draft” status. At that point you can treat it just like you would a new contest.
** This does not include Studio contests. Studio reposts should still be treated as new contests.

2 . You can create new versions of components in basically the same way you do the repost. Any component design or dev contest that is complete will have the options in the dropdown to create a new version of the design and/or dev. It will create a copy of the original contest and leaves the new contest in “draft” status. At that point you can treat it just like you would a new contest.

3. If you run into any issues please let us know. So that we can handle issues with some sort of order, please email them to internal-support@topcoder.com.

item.title: New Spec Review Process Is Live
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: We’re moving the rest of the software contest types over to the new spec review process as of now. This includes everything except for studio contests. Please discontinue using the TCSSPEC Jira project for spec reviews after your current reviews … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
We’re moving the rest of the software contest types over to the new spec review process as of now. This includes everything except for studio contests. Please discontinue using the TCSSPEC Jira project for spec reviews after your current reviews are complete. Studio reviews will remain as-is for now.

The process described below is still the same (it’s the same process you’ve been using for UI Prototypes and RIA Builds). Here is a full guide you can use for your reference as well as for your clients: http://www.topcoder.com/wiki/display/docs/Specification+Review+Guide

Spec Reviews will launch automatically when you activate your contests. They will not be created for component dev contests that are tied to a design. You will see the spec review show up as a project in OR that is linked to the contest. Members will see an opportunity on the existing Review Opportunities pages.

If you have a reason to not do a spec review or you need a non-standard spec review payment (currently set at $50), please let me know in advance of activating the contest and also let me know why so we can understand how to account for it in the process.
