item.title: Meet the December Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the Coders and Designers of the Month! Check out some interviews and be sure to congratulate them! Algorithm: abhilashr What is your favorite part of TopCoder? I really enjoy the contest format in TopCoder SRMs. There is an … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the Coders and Designers of the Month! Check out some interviews and be sure to congratulate them!


Algorithm: abhilashr

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
I really enjoy the contest format in TopCoder SRMs. There is an emphasis on speed and accuracy, besides problem solving, which makes competing all the more exciting. The short contest durations make it easy to drop in for a contest even on the busiest of days.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Well, no problem I attempted last month measures up to the amount of effort I had to put into some front end work on a website. Javascript, I can deal with, but CSS is man’s gravest mistake

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
Not that I’ve won so many to talk about, but a clear mind and an empty head certainly seems to do the trick for me At least in algorithm competitions, I’ve found that nothing helps more than clarity of thought during the contest.

What is the story behind your handle?
Not all ideas and gestures can be deep and profound. At times you just say no to creativity and type out your name in lower case with no spaces or periods like a mad man. That’s my handle

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
Having known myself for most of my life, I don’t find anything surprising about me anymore! But I’m sure people who’ve known me just for the past few years would be quite thrilled to know I used to do my fair share of mountain biking back when I was a kid. Boy, those were the days!

Design: saarixx


One of resorts in the center of saarixx’s city – Dnipropetrovsk

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
When I compete in design competitions full time, I like that my earnings are proportional to the spent time and effort. And I know that I will get a reward for each hour additionally spent on work.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
The hardest component designed by me and finished in December was TROL Order Locator. The requirements were quite difficult to understand. I and reviewer understood them differently, thus we’ve spent a lot of time on clarifications.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
IMHO, the main factor is time spent on exploring solutions provided by winners of previous competitions. This is applicable to most types of competitions: Marathon, Algorithm, Design, Conceptualization, Architecture, etc.

What is the story behind your handle?
My initials are SAA. I added RIX to them just to make it sound cool and funny, with no exact meaning. Then I googled for SAARIX and found that it’s not unique in the world wide web. To make it unique I added an additional “X” to the end. Thus my handle is SAARIXX, and if you find some web page with word “SAARIXX” on it – be sure it’s about me

Studio: abedavera

abedavera and his girlfriend Vera

What is your favorite part about Studio?
Open the “Congratulations” thread and see my name as a winner

What was the hardest project you worked on last month?
The hardest project was Generic Corporate Website Contest, 9 pages with full of tables, text, lists, icons, buttons, tabs, also the logo. But that was a great contest before new year 2010 for me!

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at Studio?
Just make it simple and clean, and create something different sometimes! ->tips to get the milestone prize

What is the story behind your handle?
abedavera means abe (my middle name, albertho) and vera (my lovely girlfriend).

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
Fulltimer at Studio Topcoder. Is that surprising??? lol

item.title: Reviewers Wanted!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Do you have experience with Perl? What about other programming languages? If so, we need your help! We are urgently looking for a Perl reviewer for the following project. The PERL WebComposer Search and Replace Script is a command based … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Do you have experience with Perl? What about other programming languages? If so, we need your help! We are urgently looking for a Perl reviewer for the following project.

The PERL WebComposer Search and Replace Script is a command based component that will be used to mass modify XML, XSL, and HTML files to search for a specific string sequence and replace it with another string sequence. The script should be able to search for fixed strings that may have some dynamic parts indicated by wildcard characters such as ‘*’ or ‘?’. The script will be run from the command line and will be chained with other scripts to perform its work.

Review compensation is $300 and $250.

Here are the contest details and also here.

We are always looking for new reviewers so if you’re down with Perl, Python or any other programming language new at TopCoder, check out the ongoing review and competition opportunities here.

item.title: NVIDIA CUDA Superhero Challenge 2: Interview with Winner Psyho
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to Psyho, the winner of the NVIDIA CUDA Superhero Challenge 2! Can you describe the problem and the ensuing thought process that became your successful solution? The problem we had to solve was a variation of a classic TSP. … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to Psyho, the winner of the NVIDIA CUDA Superhero Challenge 2!

Can you describe the problem and the ensuing thought process that became your successful solution?
The problem we had to solve was a variation of a classic TSP. The main difference was that the cities (in the problem statement planes play the role of cities) didn’t have a fixed position, but instead each day they were placed on a different random point completely independent of previous positions. And on each day we had to visit exactly one city and we could travel an infinite distance.

That change made it very hard to improve your solution in small steps, since if you changed the order of even only 2 visits, you get 2 compelely different positions and probably at least 1 of them is so far that it makes that change worthless and automatically discarded.

My solution used a simulated annealing optimization technique to gradually improve my solution. And in each step I tried to change the order of several visits in a greedy-like manner. You can read more about the solutions in the “Post your approach” thread.

Was there a ‘steep learning curve’ or did you find it easy to adapt to the requirements for this CUDA-specific competition?
Surprisingly, it turned out that CUDA is much easier to learn that I would have ever suspected. I guess I would need around 5 to 10 minutes to explain CUDA’s basics to any decent C++ developer with multi-threading experience. However, while it’s easy to write anything that works, it takes quite a lot of time to optimize it. In principle, writing for CUDA is very similar to standard multi-threaded programming, but the huge number of concurrent threads, and concepts like shared memory and blocks, create a few subtle changes.

Did you access the CUDA webinars provided by NVIDIA?
Yes – I’ve seen first three slides from here. They provide a great start, since after reading them I was pretty much ready for developing with CUDA. I haven’t watched the videos as from my perspective reading is a few times faster than listening. I have also quickly skimmed through official documentation but I haven’t really found anything useful besides the execution speed of operations.

There was one thing that was really missing from those slides. There should be a paragraph with common mistakes from developers. I wasted a lot of precious time on debugging, because I wasn’t following such basic guidelines like checking CUDA errors. It seems that few years of competing in algorithmic competitions completely spoiled me and now it’s natural for me, that I believe if something doesn’t work, I can find the mistake just by looking at my code.

What did you think of the testing environment – thoughts on the hardware?
I can’t really say much about the hardware. It was my first experience with computing power of GPUs in general. It definitely has a lot of potential, and it’s probably the future of computing in terms of power/cost. But currently it’s hard to draw the line between CPU vs GPU, because it depends entirely on the solved problem and optimizations used (like using SSE for CPU).

Where are you in your academic career these days? What are you studying and what are your future plans?
Oh, the fun part of the interview As I stated somewhere in the forum, right now I’m trying to finish my master’s thesis (something about poker AI). To be honest, I should have finished my studies about
2 years ago, but I never really cared about that. I was thinking a bit about going for a PhD, but since I’m so lazy, and I don’t have a “scientific mind” I decided it’s not for me. But on the other hand I don’t enjoy programming except for problem solving, so probably you won’t see me in any company – unless I could get a job with a decent salary where I could work remotely on interesting (and not tedious) problems. And not more than 2-3 hours a day (of course with full flexibility). If someone has such an offer for me then feel free to drop me an email

Do you have any new hobbies or interests when you’re not studying or competing in TopCoder?
Currently, except for my thesis, I’m in the middle of doing nothing I still participate in a wide variety of logic puzzles competitions, which I can recommend to anyone who likes doing SRMs from time to time. They also have their annual onsite competitions – much like TCO, but unfortunately not in Vegas From my perspective they’re much more mentally demanding than algorithmic competitions, but on flip side they test a much narrower set of skills. I’d say that the fact I was able to get to the “target” ranking in algorithms is almost solely because of those puzzle competitions. A few web pages I can recommend – OAPC site which had several competitions of great quality, USA official WPF site – with qualification tests for USA team, nikoli site – daily puzzles with ability to see how other people are solving, puzzlepicnic – AFAIK the work of fellow TopCoder members And hopefully I will be launching a similar site to nikoli somewhere in the next year, but that’s a distant future

item.title: Meet the November Coders and Designers of the Month
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to our November Coders and Designers of the month. They put on an excellent performance in November and are very deserving of this honor. Design: Luca What is your favorite part of TopCoder? The Design and Architecture competitions are … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to our November Coders and Designers of the month. They put on an excellent performance in November and are very deserving of this honor.

Design: Luca

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
The Design and Architecture competitions are my favorite. Also, the possibility to have a flexible schedule is a great thing.

My favorite part of the TopCoder site is this one.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
The “Presentation Engine Transport Module Architecture” was a really interesting project. We were required to create a framework and a model for a client-server Presentation standard, which had a professionally written specification.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
These days, it is more important to create complete deliverables, that include all the small details.

What is the story behind your handle?
My name is Lucian, but it is hard for non Romanians to pronounce it correctly. So I simplified it: Luca.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
It’s not really a “surprising thing”, but I can’t think of something else: I just got the driving license for motorcycles.

Development: azukun

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
When I signed up to the TC a year ago to participate in algorithm contests, SRMs momentarily became my favorite contest format with great possibilities to learn from other members. Six months later I tried development contests and now I’m proud to be a full-time developer for TopCoder with many advantages associated with this and my favorite part of the TC is a possibility to be one.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
This is Aphaea AutoAudit .net Audit Report Services without any doubts.
It is a rather complex component with many classes, dependencies, and a necessity to implement CRUD operations for small, but tricky DB schema aside from report processing.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
Hard work and ability to learn quickly.

What is the story behind your handle?
This is a sad story Originally I’ve used ‘Az’ as my handle everywhere, but when I was signing up for gmail, such address was already busy, off course. Since I was a fan of anime in those times I’ve used such japanized version and when I signed up to the TC, I couldn’t find anything better than to reuse same handle. Now I’m not so happy with my choice then, that’s why it is sad

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
You can see one surprising thing by looking on my profile, i.e. while Russia is a leading country in the algorithm contests for now, I’m the only .NET developer from my country and there is one more Java developer, that’s all! At least, it was sad and surprising for me.

Studio: oton

This is my desk while I worked on the last wireframe project in Studio.

Setup: iMac 20″ circa 2007, 2.4Ghz with 4GB DDR2 memory, HDD 320GB with 2TB Western Digital external drive and 1 TB Time Capsule for remote backup, Belkin USB hub, HP Deskjet 3920 printer, some design and development books (my favorite for IA projects are Jenifer Tidwell’s Designing Interfaces), DreamWeaver as main XHTML/CSS editor with their unbeatable sites caching features (sure I like other editor like Coda, but for this main reason I pick DW), Photoshop, Illustrator, Fireworks, one office chair with the left arm rest already broken, an iPod Touch 32GB (a gift from AOL contest) for some errands activities (game!) and musics, and a cup of tea or coffee (sometime) brought by my wife.

What is your favorite part about Studio?
Winning a contest with over 5 or more submitters. But I’d love it much more if the submitters were only me or the other submitter

What was the hardest project you worked on last month?
Gea Community Maps wireframe (Phase 1). I didn’t participate in Phase 2 and Phase 3 for this very reason

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at Studio?
Hard work and consistency.

What is the story behind your handle?
It’s my nickname. No story. Period. With smile

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
My daughter (3.5yrs) is always sneaking into my room, and asked me my opinion of her new creations or toys. I usually end up talking with her, or playing with her, and sometime postponed to work later.

item.title: $23,000 Gea Module Architecture Frenzy
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Attention sharks: This is the month to win extra prizes by participating in Gea’s Module Architecture Frenzy, which includes eight Module Architecture competitions for the Gea Community Maps project. In addition to the usual competition prizes, three overall winners will … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: Attention sharks: This is the month to win extra prizes by participating in Gea’s Module Architecture Frenzy, which includes eight Module Architecture competitions for the Gea Community Maps project. In addition to the usual competition prizes, three overall winners will receive $3,000 each. The winners will be determined by the accumulation of Digital Run points from the qualifying Module Architecture contests. On top of that, Gea is introducing a new type of contest based on the 4+1 model of architecture. Participants of this contest are given extra incentive when involved in the Module Architecture Frenzy. Learn about how to maximize your winnings this month here.

item.title: Good News at TopCoder and Win a T-Shirt!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: This week we announced that TopCoder(R) is increasing the Digital Run Rewards for every software and Studio contest going forward by 25%. This means there are more DR points available for every contest and more money going into the guaranteed … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
This week we announced that TopCoder(R) is increasing the Digital Run Rewards for every software and Studio contest going forward by 25%. This means there are more DR points available for every contest and more money going into the guaranteed monthly DR prize pools, which means larger Digital Run payouts and more reason than ever to compete. This is just one step in our ongoing effort to reward your participation in TopCoder competitions beyond the prize money won in any particular contest.

Part of this effort too is gaining more understanding of what drives you to compete. While participation in TopCoder contests remains strong, with the addition of new contest tracks and the anticipation of much higher volume, we want to stay ahead of the curve to make sure competing at TopCoder is as enticing and rewarding as it can possibly be.

We have attached a short survey which we would appreciate if you took the time to complete, and we invite you to provide us with any additional information or feedback in the space provided.

As an added incentive, we will be choosing twenty respondents at random and awarding a TopCoder t-shirt to each, just for completing the survey! You must complete the survey by Wednesday, December 16, 2009 to be eligible to win a t-shirt.

View the survey here.

Thank you for your assistance with this important process, and good luck competing!

item.title: TopCoder is Raising the Stakes: Digital Run Rewards Increasing by 25%
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: There’s more reason than ever to compete at TopCoder! Effective immediately we are increasing the Digital Run points in every competition track – including Studio – by 25%. This means more points are awarded per contest, and more money is … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
There’s more reason than ever to compete at TopCoder!

Effective immediately we are increasing the Digital Run points in every competition track – including Studio – by 25%.

This means more points are awarded per contest, and more money is available in the guaranteed monthly Digital Run Prize Pools.

The increases take effect with any new contest entered into the pipeline – contests that are already scheduled will go forward with their existing assigned DR points.

At TopCoder we always strive to reward quality participation beyond the prize money given to the winners of any particular contest. This increase is just one part of that ongoing effort.

You can learn more about the Digital Run here.

UPDATE: You will note that the pool for Design - which includes Conceptualization, Specification, Architecture and Component Design contests - is already up to $6,500, just 10 days into the month and even before these DR increases take effect. Now is the time to compete in these contests and win your piece of the December DR Pool!

item.title: More Good Stuff from the Best Buy REMIX Challenge

item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to all the members who competed on Remix Challenges to build the Best Buy Flat Panel Finder App.

From bestbuyjoe…

Awesome news! Last week and this week the Flat-Panel TV Finder that was constructed with the help of the TopCoder community is featured in the Best Buy Weekly Ad. I took a picture with my phone, so sorry if the quality stinks.

This is great news for the community and shows off the awesome work you’ve all done. Hopefully we see more examples like this in the near future!

This is just one of many TC success stories from the Remix Challenge, and we’re all proud and excited to show you the fruits of your labor!

item.title: Meet the October Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the October designers and coders of the month. We hope you enjoy their interviews! Algorithm: pieguy What is your favorite part of TopCoder? The algorithm competitions, of course. I wish there were more. What was the hardest project … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the October designers and coders of the month. We hope you enjoy their interviews!


Algorithm: pieguy

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
The algorithm competitions, of course. I wish there were more.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I’m currently designing a tile-based game (for fun). The hardest part is keeping the rules of the game as simple as possible without limiting the potential variety.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
I’d say solution testing. I’ve learned to test my solutions even after I submit. Several times I’ve discovered a bug after I submitted and had to resubmit, but 10% resubmit penalty beats the 100% incorrectness penalty.

What is the story behind your handle?
Love to bake it, love to eat it.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I memorized 400 digits of pi.

Design: zsudraco

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
I like these:
(a) Freedom to choose interesting tasks to work on.
(b) Freedom to arrange my working time.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
All the projects I worked on last month were simple. A relatively hard one may be the Mapping File and String Truncation API component; I needed to make an efficient binary search algorithm to loacate entries in a file.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
I just won several simple designs last month. And for simple components, skills may not be very important, just be diligent and work hard on every aspects as detailed as possible.

What is the story behind your handle?
I played ACM algorithm contests in college. There are several teams, the team names are “zsu” + a constellation name, “zsu” is the college name. And my team name is just zsudraco, I simply used that name as my handle. It is not quite meaningful.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I have a surprising accident several months ago, but it is not about TopCoder or information technology.

One night, I parked my car in a dark corner. When I was going to drive it back home, I just started the engine, and two guys came inside my car, … they robbed of my car.

Fortunately, I just had a light injury. More fortunately, several days later they had a car accident and left the car in road, and policemen called me to get back my car.

This accident gave me a big lesson that I want to share:
Do not park your car in dark corner; after getting into car, lock the doors ASAP.

Development: yext

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
Members can get involved in almost all stages of a project. I learned quite a lot when acting as developer, designer, architect, and co-pilot.

I’m a student but I can gain lots of experience before leaving school, this is great. Thank you TopCoder.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
It is “PPM Proctor Pages 1″. I had no experience on JavaScript or jQuery before this competition, and I spent much time learning them.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
As a competitor on assembly competitions, I think the most important factor to win is to get familiar with the system early. For example, most competitions I won on October are from the PPM series. Before those contests, I reviewed all PPM prototype conversion contests, and participated many Bug Races on PPM component deployment. Those helped me to understand the project better.

What is the story behind your handle?
I’ve been using this nickname for more than 10 years, but I cannot remember how I choose it.
I like this nickname because it’s easy to remember, easy to pronounce, and never a duplicate with others.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I’m working in “EAGLE” Lab in Zhejiang University. I wondered what does “EAGLE” stand for, and my advisor wrote:
innovativE softwAre technoloGy deveLopment cEnter

Then I thought my handle “yext” could be an abbreviation of “You challEnge eXtreme @ Topcoder”.

Studio: vcsenge

What is your favorite part about Studio?
Competition.. without long registration procedures and high fees. Studio offers a free and simple way for everyone to show his/her creativity and to win great prices.

What was the hardest project you worked on last month?
I liked the Univison competition series the most because we were allowed to use many photos and colorful graphic elements. This was the most creative part. But the hardest competition was the Newsweek Yahoo! Widget Competition – it is always a challenge to organize so many elements and information in such a small place.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at Studio?
Surprisingly, it is not to create the most creative, professional or up-to-date design but to find a look-and-feel the client likes and needs. This is the factor which makes Studio competitions so different from other competitions. The key is to find out what the client likes from the provided materials – and of course the forum help much as well.

What is the story behind your handle?
It comes from my name Varga Csenge.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I am only 45 kg still I shoot well with .45 pistols

item.content:encoded:
There’s $800 in prizes up for grabs in this contest to help conceive of the perfect iPhone application for Edmunds.com, the leading automotive information website.

Mobile usage is on the rise, and Edmunds wants to create an iPhone app that helps their Users with their car-shopping and buying while they are on the move. The app should utilize content, products and tools that currently exist on the site at Edmunds.com or new concepts that would be highly complementary to Edmunds’ exisiting suite of products and be consistent with its brand and value proposition.

Register now!

item.title: Great Results from the Best Buy Remix Challenge
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: bestbuyjoe posts over on the Remix Challenge site about some very positive results Best Buy is seeing with a couple of the apps built so far… As you know we started this journey between Best Buy and TopCoder earlier this … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
bestbuyjoe posts over on the Remix Challenge site about some very positive results Best Buy is seeing with a couple of the apps built so far…

As you know we started this journey between Best Buy and TopCoder earlier this year. We’ve run contests for multiple things, and two of them have been recently testing on BestBuy.com with great results!

The Best Selling Laptop Carousel and the Mobile Phones Accessory Finder have shown very promising early results in improving the site experience for our customers. The accessory finder can be found here. The carousel was in a test on BestBuy.com and we are examining complete results. I’ll post a link to it when it’s fully implemented.

Everyone involved should be extremely proud of what we’ve done so far. I think it’s a great representation of what can be accomplished with TopCoder.

I’m especially looking forward to our upcoming Best Selling Widget. This will allow us to get the power of Remix into the hands of people who may not be able to develop their own solution!

Congratulations to everyone who has competed so far! For more information on taking part in the Best Buy Remix Challenge check out the home page here.

item.title: Making your life easier when creating Component contests…
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: We have added some automation features to Cockpit surrounding the creation of Component Design and Component Development contests. Here is the summary: 1. When creating a Component Design contest, Cockpit will ask you whether or not you want to create … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
We have added some automation features to Cockpit surrounding the creation of Component Design and Component Development contests. Here is the summary:

1. When creating a Component Design contest, Cockpit will ask you whether or not you want to create the corresponding Development contest at the time you save.

2. If you are creating a Component Development contest separately, you will have the option to create it as “Dev Only” OR you can select an existing component that you have access to. This will include all generic components as well as any custom components that you have access to. The contest name field will populate with a dropdown list of matching components when you start typing.

Notes:

- Once you create a dev contest that is linked to a component, you cannot change it to Dev Only. If you need to do this, contact components@topcoder.com

- Once you create a component as Dev Only, you cannot link it to another component. If you need to do this, contact components@topcoder.com

item.title: Submission Viewer Now Supports Multi-Round Contests
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: If you are running 2 round contests, you can now select the first round as well as the final winners in the Submission Viewer. You must set the round 1 winners prior to gaining access to the round 2 submissions. … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
If you are running 2 round contests, you can now select the first round as well as the final winners in the Submission Viewer. You must set the round 1 winners prior to gaining access to the round 2 submissions. When selecting the final winners, you can choose from any round.

For your convenience, the top area that displays the rankings will show the milestone winners when you are on the Milestone view and the final winners when you’re in the Final or All view.

Payments are processed for both the milestones and the final submissions at the time you checkout with your final submission picks. There is no need to send milestone winners to Jess anymore.

item.title: Meet the September Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the September coders and designers of the month. These members did a great job last month and truly deserve this recognition. Read their interviews. Algorithm: kappahouse What is your favorite part of TopCoder? Everything but the moment when … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the September coders and designers of the month. These members did a great job last month and truly deserve this recognition. Read their interviews.

Algorithm: kappahouse

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
Everything but the moment when I see my name suddenly disappear from the list during system test.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
“TheCardLineDivOne” and “StairsColoring”. I still cannot solve them.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
Practice. I have been doing weekly practice competitions with nase, tomoro, rockey, s2k, yomura and taxmul, through which I was able to improve my skill.

What is the story behind your handle?
Comes from my nickname when I was in junior high school. “Kappa” is a Japanese legendary creature.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
Unfortunately, there is nothing surprising about me. If you still want to know something about me, I want to boast that I made my first successful challenge at my 42nd SRM last time.

Design: caru

Here is caru in his home town of Livigno, Italy.

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
I can live and travel where I really want and work when I like to. When I awake, I can decide when and how much I am gonna work. That’s cool!

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Lynx Calendar Facebook Manager component design. I had to study a lot, and the project was a little more complex than the others I did in the last month.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
Precision: usually that’s enough to win. Too many times positions are decided by distraction mistakes.

What is the story behind your handle?
Very simple: my surname is Caruso and many friends call me caru.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
Sometimes I am tempted to use my time to compete in Studio, because I feel a little more relaxed when dealing with graphics. I tried a few times without success (though I have to say that I didn’t do my best , so I will stick to the TC side for now. Maybe in the future…

Development: pulky

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
My favorite part of TopCoder is the TCO… I’ve been to Vegas several times and had so much fun. Hopefully I will be able to travel there next year.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
The difficulty was not primarily in the projects but in the decisions. It was pretty hard to decide which contest to commit to and be sure a good submission was feasible. I was very careful because I wanted to keep my reliability but sometimes going for the DR while keeping your reliability 100% is too hard.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
I never submit a solution that I don’t think is really, really good. This is not a good advice since it’s often “bad for business” (sometimes good enough is better), but this is mainly my strategy. I like to win, complete final fixes within 10 minutes and be ready to focus in a new competition.

What is the story behind your handle?
My handle has been my nickname forever… I don’t even remember why people started calling me pulky the first time

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
Since there were no big checks in the last TCO and I wanted mine, I “forced” Jessie (being annoying enough) to write it down for me and had Laurie (Facebook) pose for the picture (see above)

Studio: ujazz

What is your favorite part about Studio?
The results. They are unpredictable. Once I submitted work with a lot of creative ideas and good quality, and I thought about getting in the upper places but in the end I did not even make first 5. I think only to make projects with the best quality and have some fresh ideas.

What was the hardest project you worked on last month?
Design the storyboard for Insurance Town was hardest project. There was much work on details and concept was needed.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at Studio?
Do everything or do something new. Research before start. Look at best world ideas. Just start the project. Make more than one version. Have critical views to all things. Submit proper submissions to current contest not to else one like me

What is the story behind your handle?
My handle is pronounced like horror in Russian. Why? See next.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I played at local melodic death-metal band as front man – guitarist and growl-singer. m/

item.title: $20,000 NASA-TopCoder Challenge
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Mark your calendars for the NASA-TopCoder Challenge: Exploring the Next Frontier of Innovation. This marathon match will take place November 4 – 14, 2009 with prizes galore! - $20,000 in cash prizes! - Personalized limited edition t-shirts - VIP Invitations … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Mark your calendars for the NASA-TopCoder Challenge: Exploring the Next Frontier of Innovation. This marathon match will take place November 4 – 14, 2009 with prizes galore!

- $20,000 in cash prizes!
- Personalized limited edition t-shirts
- VIP Invitations for NASA shuttle launch

Be one of our Flight Software Engineers on this important mission!

From the forums announcement:

Announcing the $20,000 NASA-TopCoder Challenge!

We are very excited to offer you a chance to solve an important problem given to us by NASA’s Space Life Sciences Directorate. This 10-day marathon match will run from November 4 – November 14, 2009.

This is a historical opportunity to bring the creativity of the TopCoder community to the space program. The solutions developed will have the potential to have a direct impact on future human space flights organized by NASA and its partners. The winners of the competition can proudly state that they have had a real impact on human space flight.

The significance of this opportunity is further enhanced by the unique prizes we offering:

*A LARGE CASH PRIZE POOL. The total prize pool for this contest is $20,000.

*EXCLUSIVE VIP INVITATION TO NASA SHUTTLE LAUNCH FOR TOP SUBMISSIONS. 6 participants will get VIP access to one of the few remaining NASA shuttle launches. (Note: Winners will have to make their own way to the Kennedy Space Center for the launch.)

*A LIMITED EDITION NASA-TOPCODER T-SHIRT – WITH YOUR NAMES. We will print a limited number of TopCoder-NASA t-shirts for every single active participant in the contest. The handles of each and every active participant in the event will be written on the t-shirt.

We are also using this event as an opportunity to experiment with our platform to try to learn key lessons for how to improve and evolve in the future. We are working closely with researchers at Harvard Business School, London Business School and MLab. This will bring several unique features to the contest, which we hope drives a high level of participation – and also a diverse group of participants.

*1 IN 4 PARTICIPANTS CAN WIN CASH PRIZES: We are designing the contest in a way so that 1 in 4 participants will be eligible for the cash prize. Instead of the usual competing against the masses ? competition will be limited to virtual rooms of 20 individuals competing for a prize of $1,000/room. Five people in each room will be able to take partake in the cash prizes.

*SOME COMPETING IN TEAMS: Based on the feedback from the last experiment, we will have some competition rooms that will be team-based. In this situation in each group of 20 participants there will be 4 teams of five individuals competing to win the $1000 prize.

*LIMITED PARTICIPATION: We will limit the contest to 480 participants. We encourage all current, past and new members to participate. In the case of overwhelming demand, priority will be given to members with pre-existing TopCoder ratings (regardless of competition type).

We look forward to hearing from you!

item.title: Interview with NVIDIA CUDA Superheros iquadrat and b285714!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: The first challenge of the NVIDIA CUDA Superhero Challenge is complete and the winners announced. TopCoder took some time to interview the first and second place winners so check out what they had to say! Read Interviews. TC: How does … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The first challenge of the NVIDIA CUDA Superhero Challenge is complete and the winners announced. TopCoder took some time to interview the first and second place winners so check out what they had to say!

Read Interviews.

TC: How does it feel to win the NVIDIA CUDA Superhero challenge? Can
you explain how you approached solving the problem?

Iquadrat: It feels great to be one of the winners of the NVIDIA CUDA Superhero
Challenge! It comes to me a bit as surprise as I started exploring CUDA only in the second week of the contest. I had heard of it before but never got the chance to try it out myself.

In the first week, I explored some different algorithms to attack the CCL problem on the CPU only. Finally, I found the find-and-union algorithm most suitable as it needed only a single pass over all
neighbor relations. It works as following: Initially each pixel is assigned to a separate set (with its index as id of the set) by assigning itself as parent. Then, the pixels sets were joined according to the neighboring relation. The joining of two pixel sets was done by finding the ids of the pixels (the pixel that has itself as parent) and then making the pixel with the larger id the child of the pixel with the smaller child. In a final step, the set id is looked up for each pixel and written to the result array. On the CPU, this could already be calculated pretty fast using SIMD instructions to compute the neighboring relations. My fastest CPU-only version scored a bit over 13,000 points.

In week two, I explored the CUDA framework. On Monday I decided to buy a GTX 260 card as my laptop card did not support all the instructions I wanted to use. The most runtime consuming task was getting the data onto the GPU and from there back into the host memory. The copy time was more than the calculation time itself. I did not manage to interlave the data transfer with the computation on the GPU as this would have needed pinned memory. Copying the input vector to pinned memory first
wasn’t an option as this took too much time to be a benefit afterwards.

My algorithm for the GPU was very similar to the one on the CPU:

1) Copy the data to GPU.
2) Divide the image into 44×44 blocks. Each kernel copies its part of
the image into shared memory, then solves the CCL for this part.
3) Join the solved CCLs from the second step along the seams of the
blocks in the graphic card’s global memory.
4) Final pass, look up the final index of the pixels.
5) Copy the data back to host memory.

Because the pixel sets were joined concurrently, I used atomic instructions to prevent race conditions. So, the find-and-union for two pixels repeatedly tries to join the sets until it succeeds. The GPU solution scored about 38000 points on the intermediate tests, so it was about three times faster then the CPU algorithm, despite the overhead of copying the data form the CPU to the GPU and back.

Approx time distribution: Step 1 30%, Step 2 20%, Step 3 15%, Step 4 5%, Step 5 30%.

One of the main problems was the instability of the testing environment. Solutions sometimes failed test cases without apparent reasons. Because of this, it was very difficult to say if a failing test was because of a bug in the solution or an issue with the tester or hardware.

b285714: The CUDA superhero challenge brought me an excitement I haven’t felt for a long time. It feels great to compete with talented programmers world-wide.

I solved the problem by trying a lot of different alternatives to find the fastest one. This is achieved using BSGP, a high level GPU programming language built on top of CUDA hardware. The built in parallel primitives like reduce/compact helped a great deal in gathering optimization information.

I wrote all my submission entries in BSGP and hand translated them to CUDA for submission.

TC: What did you learn about CUDA from this competition?

Iquadrat: I learned much about the CUDA framework and the computation power of the
NVIDIA graphic cards as well as about the CCL problem and different ways to solve it.

b285714: A lot of new performance tricks, especially when dealing with large data.

TC: Would you recommend this series to others?

Iquadrat: Apart from the instability of the testing environment, the contest was very much fun! Therefore, I recommend the series to everybody who is interested in really massive parallel algorithms and unleashing the power of contemporary graphic cards — and already owns a GTX 260 or higher graphic card which is really needed to get exact timing results and get the most optimized code.

b285714: Surely yes.

TC: What advice would you give to other TopCoder members?

Iquadrat: Try a bunch of different algorithms, keep attention to the TopCoder forums and never give up

b285714: Try BSGP:) It would help your GPU programming experience.

Remember, the second NVIDIA CUDA Superhero Challenge competition starts November 23, 2009 so get practicing!

Read more here:
here!

The Challenge series of contests asks computer programmers to harness the parallel processing power of the NVIDIA(R) CUDA(TM) architecture to … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
NVIDIA Corporation and TopCoder, Inc., today announced the winners of the first CUDA Superhero Challenge at NVIDIA’s GPU Technology Conference. The Challenge series of contests asks computer programmers to harness the parallel processing power of the NVIDIA(R) CUDA(TM) architecture to solve some of computing’s biggest challenges. First place prize went to Micha Riser, of Zurich, Switzerland who earned a $2,500 prize for his winning solution, closely followed by runner up Hou Qiming of Beijing, China, who won $1,000 for his submission.

Read full article.

item.title: Meet the August Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the August Coders and Designers of the month! Check out their interviews. Algorithm: rockaustin2k6 What is your favorite part of TopCoder? SRMs are what I have only competed in TopCoder and i like them the most. Just before … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the August Coders and Designers of the month! Check out their interviews.

Algorithm: rockaustin2k6

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
SRMs are what I have only competed in TopCoder and i like them the most. Just before the arrival of the active contest, thousands of coders group together in TopCoder chat rooms, have fun talking to one another, and then the 1 hour 15 minutes of coding(with live summary of submissions) and finally, the challenge round (which I have never performed well). I find it highly interactive way of gaining knowledge as compared to contests of various Online Judges and others…

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I spent last month with few level 3 problems of division 1 related to graphs, level 2 problems of division2 related to Dynamic Programming and some questions of acm uva online judge related to Maths.Division 1 level 3 problems are the hardest and i touched them first that month. I could still remember the problem related to Euler cycles of SRM 144 division 1 hard and my dp solution related to lcm for SRM 160 division 1 hard.

The trickier lcm problem was that given an integer S (S<=52), you needed to decompose it into several integers (>=1) such that sum of them is equal to S and their lcm is maximum. Going with the obvious recursion of single state { f(s) = for all 1<=i<=s max(lcm(i,f(s-i)) }, was giving a wrong answer. This was to be done carefully to avoid wrong answers (they are what I hate most).

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
I think speed with accuracy (getting least debugging and logical errors) and little bit of typing speed matters most.

What is the story behind your handle?
Coding is fun. I find TopCoder very attractive and interactive but came to know about it so late (after high school). What I am now is because of my hard work, contributions of my brother imrankane2005 and seniors (fameoflight,R0N,humblefool)[All TopCoder handles], batch mates, present study conditions of my college(IIIT Allahabad), highly encouraging Sanjeev Sir (faculty member of the college,Assistant Professor) and, of course, my parents.

Tell us one surprising thing about you?
I am the follower of islam yet don’t (can’t) eat meat.

Design: viviz

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
Competition makes software design more interesting, and you can discuss your solution with all the designers/deveopers from all over the world, you can improve your skills, it’s exciting.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I believe there are no easy competitions. Every competition is hard.

The hardest part of each project is the REQUIREMENT Specification is unclear, we need to talk with Architecture/PM for more details with much more time.

And as a non-native english speaker, it’s hard to writing Component specifiaction and UML documentation without any spelling/grammar errors.That’s why I always got punishment in scorecard 4.1.6

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
You should read each part of RS very carefully, each requirement listed in Logic Requirement should be taken into consideration.

After you get a general solution of your design, you need to consider the corner of each algorithm AND
public API configuration elements. The exception is handling dependency components etc.

Addtionally, make your design very flexible is also important. Then write your detailed documentation. Don’t forget to provide a comprehensible demo in CS for both reviewer/developer to understand the usage of your component: e.g.

If it’s a WCF Service component, you’d better provide a about how to generate client, how to host your service, how to access WCF service via Client. If it’s a windows service component, you’d better provide a demo how to install/uninstall the service. For any Demo part, you should provide sample input and discuss what’s the expected behavior of each Demo action. The one word is

What is the story behind your handle?
vivi is my english name, I use the first character of my family “zhang”, so it’s viviz. No special story^^

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
Seems no special thing makes me surprising…

Development: snow01

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
Everything, I am involved in =). Prizes, DR Points, DR Ranking, Assembly Competitions.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I think the Cockpit Release 4 assembly. I spent almost 24 hours on one single bugr – just to fix it with 2 lines of code. Obviously the fix required me to read the code of flex sdk.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
1) Pick a specific area and stick to that – like I picked “cockpit” assemblies. After 1-2 competitions, you would be having edge than anybody else. There are contests which others would finish in 3-4 days and I have taken only 4-6 hours to finish.

2) Reviewer comments are quite important too. Even if your submission is half complete, do the submission – it is going to give some learning for next contest.

What is the story behind your handle?
“snow” is nick name of my beloved.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I love watching a lot of movies, lot of sleep and lot of work. Surprisingly it is hard to fit all 3 in a single day, even any 2 too =).

Studio: djackmania

What is your favorite part about Studio?
Being a winner.

What was the hardest project you worked on last month?
Ferguson.com “Professional” iPhone Application, I finished the project “outdoor”.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at Studio?
Passion, passion, passion.. and push to the limit…

What is the story behind your handle?
The fans (mania) of my nickname in the Old Javanese spelling (d+jack)

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I’m not a graphic or web designer, I’m an electrical engineer

item.title: $2000 in Bug Races – Help with Childhood Disease Research and Build Electronic Health Records while Watching TV!!
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: Over the past year, the TopCoder membership has designed and built a highly structured, robust medical records application called EHR. This application is used by a large children’s hospital and childhood disease research center to track the care and treatment … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Over the past year, the TopCoder membership has designed and built a highly structured, robust medical records application called EHR. This application is used by a large children’s hospital and childhood disease research center to track the care and treatment of their patients. Patients of this center typically see many providers in several clinics on a single visit – for example a physician, a physical therapist, and a nutritionist – and as the campus is very large, this application is crucial for centralizing medical information.

The winning components and assemblies have been assembled and integrated, but we are not quite finished. There are several updates, additions and changes to make before the application can be used. Fortunately, none of them are new – all are more of what’s been done already. Therefore we have split the work into 30+ bite-sized portions, which are together worth nearly $2,000. Some tasks are trivial, some are larger, some are mere SQL and others require Facelets experience. None require more than a few hours. And all are grouped together by skill – so if you enjoyed one task, you can find several more exactly like it attached to the same ticket. Work on as many or few tasks as you like – or as you can squeeze in during commercials!

Pre-configured Virtual Machines are available for working on these tickets.

For more information, use the public BUGR filter , or contact axiom, restarter, or bchops.

Discuss this topic in the forums here.

Good luck and thank you!

item.title: Just Launched: $1500 MIT Climate Collaboratorium Portal Configuration Tournament
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: The MIT Center for Collective Intelligence is running a $1500 tournament with 14 possible winners! The purpose of this tournament is to provide members of the TopCoder community with an opportunity to learn a little about Java Portlet technology and … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The MIT Center for Collective Intelligence is running a $1500 tournament with 14 possible winners!

The purpose of this tournament is to provide members of the TopCoder community with an opportunity to learn a little about Java Portlet technology and the Liferay platform. This contest is in preparation for more competitions over the next several months (and hopefully many more in 2010!).

The goal of these contests is to help us build the MIT Climate Collaboratorium, a new platform for crowd-sourcing climate change policy.

We’re looking forward to your involvement, and hope that this an opportunity for many of you to learn some new technology, and get involved in an exciting project to develop a unique and important tool for our species.

item.title: $5,000 AgentMatching Marathon Match!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: TopCoder is excited to announce the AgentMatching Marathon Match! TopCoder has a customer that needs your help. They are looking for an algorithm to better predict which of their real estate agents will successfully close a property with prospective customers. … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder is excited to announce the AgentMatching Marathon Match!

TopCoder has a customer that needs your help. They are looking for an algorithm to better predict which of their real estate agents will successfully close a property with prospective customers. The client has provided historical data consisting of thousands of agent – customer pairings. One of the key challenges to this problem is that it may take up to seven months for the agent to close the real estate deal. Thus, this problem will require you to develop novel machine learning techniques accounting for the fact that the training data contains real estate leads which will be closed in the future.

Whoever is able to predict which leads will be closed will walk away with the $2,500 prize! You have until Thursday, August 27, 2009 at 1:00 p.m. EDT (UTC/GMT -4) to fine tune your solution.

Check out the AgentMatching problem statement here.

Register to participate in this competition in the Active Contests list here.

View all of the details here.

item.title: Meet the July Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the July Coders and Designers of the month! Enjoy their interviews. Algorithm: tourist What is your favorite part of TopCoder? Competition! The spirit of competition is what I really love. It’s amazing when you can compare yourself with … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the July Coders and Designers of the month! Enjoy their interviews.

Algorithm: tourist

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
Competition! The spirit of competition is what I really love. It’s amazing when you can compare yourself with the best coders all over the world.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Last month I just prepared for IOI 2009 at our training camp. But, if speaking about problems… it was difficult for me to settle my nerves when I saw that my rating is 2999

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
You must code everything correctly, but also fast enough. Usually practice helps to achieve that all.

What is the story behind your handle?
Oh… I don’t actually remember that. I was about 11 when I first registered with this handle.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
My favourite programming language is Pascal. I can code better and faster in Pascal, and I’m usually coding in C++ just for TopCoder or when I need to use STL in my code. Maybe the problem is that Pascal is my ‘native’ language

Design: hpana
What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
The ability to choose the work is the greatest. I didn’t have this ability at any of my jobs.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I only participated in a few specification contests. The hardest and largest up to now was PPM Operations Administrator Module Specification. By the time I finished it I was dreaming activity diagrams.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
Working hard and from the beginning is the most important factor.

What is the story behind your handle?
It’s the concatenation of my name and the company that I work for.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I have a Phd in chemistry.

Development: gjw99
What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
Getting practiced in different technologies/frameworks.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
Writing a purchase order related design for my company’s portal.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
Take an all-round view of the project and be careful.

What is the story behind your handle?
“gjw” is the abbreviation for my name. 99 is the year my grandfather died.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
My head is big -_-

item.title: Join TopCoder & MIT: Compete for Something Bigger
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: Many people believe that global climate change is one of the most important problems currently facing humanity. If we don’t solve this problem, our other problems may not matter much, because we may not be here to have them. Left … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Many people believe that global climate change is one of the most important problems currently facing humanity. If we don’t solve this problem, our other problems may not matter much, because we may not be here to have them. Left to their own devices, scientists, journalists, politicians, businesses, and consumers will certainly do something about this problem. But the inefficiencies, delays, and distortions of traditional mass media, political decision-making, markets, and scientific publication mean that the results will almost certainly not be as good as we might hope.

Fortunately, however, in just the last decade or so, a new way of solving global problems has become possible. Examples like Wikipedia, Linux, and of course TopCoder, illustrate how it’s now possible to combine the work of many in ways that would have been impossible only a few years ago.

We believe this new approach can be used to help solve the problem of global climate change, and our goal is to create the platform for doing so. We seek to develop a global, on-line community—called the Climate Collaboratorium—in which thousands of people around the world will create, analyze, and ultimately select detailed plans for what we humans can do about global climate change. Together, the MIT Center for Collective Intelligence and the global community of TopCoder are going to build this platform.

The first step is the conceptualization contest, which is running right now. Then, the MIT Climate Collaboratorium moves through the TopCoder process, providing you the opportunity to compete on multiple contests both for prize money, and for something more.

If the project is successful in its grandest ambitions, it will lead to the creation in a few years of a societal institution that is comparable to (though perhaps somewhat smaller than) Wikipedia. It will be an on-line community used routinely by scientists, politicians, journalists, and anyone with a professional interest in climate change. It will be a standard resource for educators, students, and any citizens who want to learn about climate change. And it will be a place where any citizens who care can either express their opinions about climate change directly, or delegate their “proxy” to others who will vote on their behalf. In short, it could become a combination of a kind of simulation game for climate change, a Wikipedia for controversial topics, and an electronic democracy on steroids.

We can’t do it alone, but we think we might have a pretty good shot with your help.
 


 
Compete in the $1500 Conceptualization Competition
 
Register for TopCoder

item.title: Meet the June Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the June Coders and Designers of the Month! TopCoder interviewed the winners so enjoy the conversations! Alogrithm: knightry This picture is from the ICPC Finals from Sweden this year, where knightry’s group won a competition at one of … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the June Coders and Designers of the Month! TopCoder interviewed the winners so enjoy the conversations!

Alogrithm: knightry

This picture is from the ICPC Finals from Sweden this year, where knightry’s group won a competition at one of the events and they all got those sweet viking helmets.

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
Definitely the great selection of problems in all the practice rooms. I love going to a practice room and trying to complete the set as if I were in a real contest, then seeing where I would have placed if I had actually competed. It’s also great having the ability to see how tricky problems can be solved by referring to the editorial or other code in the practice room. It’s a really good system you guys have set up to learn new things.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I’m helping my advisor with a new quantum algorithm he’s developing for the discrete logarithm problem, but at every new thing I learned, I found 10 more things in abstract algebra I needed to understand first. For the first couple weeks, it felt like trying to learn to swim in the middle of the ocean.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
The ability to analyze a problem and strip away the non-essentials. TopCoder problem writers are good at masking problems behind clever stories, and you have to know how to break a problem apart to determine which strategy should be used at the appropriate time.

What is the story behind your handle?
My school mascot is the Knights, so a few years ago I was looking for a new email address. I had 2 criteria: 1) It involved the word knight and 2) it didn’t have any numbers. After a few tries on gmail, I found one I liked that wasn’t taken, and since then I’ve been using it everywhere.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I love to play sports, which I find is a bit uncommon for people in computer science. My current favorite is ultimate frisbee, though I really enjoy tennis and golf, too. I was also on the men’s rowing team as an undergraduate.

Development: Yeung
What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
To know more people from different country, to learn more techniques, and most important is to earn money.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
SP-14 Card Event Client Service 1.0. I never see any component has so many pending issues before submission.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
Be careful in details.

What is the story behind your handle?
No story. It is my name.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I want to shave my head bald. It is too hot now.

Studio: iamtong

What is your favorite part about Studio?
Honestly, seeing my handle when the winners are announced!

What was the hardest project you worked on last month?
No projects are easy here! For last month, my hardest project was “REMIX Challenge : Mobile Phones Website Tournament”! As 2 of my submissions got past R1, I had to finish both for R2, but spent most of my time designing 2 sets of different 3d icons to use in each design, when there were 5 pages to work on for each design. I ended up with nothing because I failed to submit for R2. T-T

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at Studio?
A good understanding of the project, some research, offer a client as much of a solution as you can, and a bit of luck!

What is the story behind your handle?
I am “Tong” – my nickname.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I studied computer engineering, I should be over on the other side, but I love being here – in the Studio

item.title: New Bonuses for Ferguson.com Idea Generation!
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: As part of the new Ferguson.com, TopCoder has launched an Idea Generation contest to let you, the members, come up with the best way to match potential customers to their home décor style. We have several excellent ideas submitted so … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
As part of the new Ferguson.com, TopCoder has launched an Idea Generation contest to let you, the members, come up with the best way to match potential customers to their home décor style. We have several excellent ideas submitted so far and we’d like to gather several more before the contest ends tomorrow. So, in addition to the current $500/$250/$250 prize structure, we’re now offering two bonus payments:

1) $100 to the most original idea – Think outside the box. Come up with something unique. Even if it’s not a top 3 winner, we want to reward you for your creativity.

2) $150 to the most complete submission – Idea Generation contests are simply that: ideas. However, the more detail you can provide the closer we are to being able to implement that idea. Aspects of ‘completeness’ here might include a fully explained concept, details such as benefits, risks, future direction, etc, a rough UI design, and any calculations or algorithms that might be needed.

Please check out the competition here:
http://studio.topcoder.com/?module=ViewContestDetails&ct=1001006

Good Luck!

item.title: Meet the May Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the May Coders and Designers of the Month! TopCoder took a minute to ask them all a few questions so enjoy their interviews. ,Algorithm: wrong What is your favorite part of TopCoder? I participate in some algorithm competitions … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the May Coders and Designers of the Month! TopCoder took a minute to ask them all a few questions so enjoy their interviews.

,Algorithm: wrong
What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
I participate in some algorithm competitions and most of their forms like ICPC. But TopCoder’s SRM is not. TopCoder’s SRM’s form is original. I like SRM and its originality

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I think the hardest problem is “MazeWandering” in SRM 440 Div1 Medium. First, I was positive that the maze is graph and is not tree. At that time, I couldn’t solve the problem in Coding Phase. Later, I realized that the maze was tree. But I couldn’t solve the problem without the other coder’s help.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
I think that the most important thing is not to make trifling mistakes. I often make trifling mistakes. Because of this, I sometimes get “Wrong Answer” or “Failed System Test” for easy problems.

What is the story behind your handle?
Like I said before, I sometimes get “Wrong Answer” by trifling mistakes. Not to repeat a mistake, I decided to name my handle “wrong”. So I can check if I make a trifling mistake when I saw my handle.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I’m 16-year-old high school student in Japan, and I’m studying English at school. Now I’m writing these sentences with a dictionary. You may be surprised by poorness of these sentences :-] Someday I will surprise you by speaking English fluently!

Design: saarixx

saarixx at the Grand Canyon after the TCO

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
When I compete in design competitions full time, I like that my earnings are proportional to spent time and effort. And I know that I will get a reward for each hour additionally spent on work.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
This was Preference Center Admin Publication Services design. I can’t remember when I drew such large class diagrams before

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
IMHO, the main factor is time spent on exploring solutions provided by winners of previous competitions. This is applicable to most types of competitions: Marathon, Algorithm, Design, Conceptualization, Architecture, etc.

What is the story behind your handle?
My initials are SAA. I added RIX to them just to make it sound cool and funny, with no exact meaning. Then I googled for SAARIX and found that it’s not unique in the world wide web. To make it unique I added addition X to the end. Thus my handle is SAARIXX, and if you find some web page with word “SAARIXX” – be sure it’s about me

Development: isv
What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
I like competing in SRMs and assembly competitions. The former bring real fun and the the latter provide good expirience with building the applications. I also like reading forums which give a good grasp of what the TopCoder community is, what are the new initiatives from the company, whether they are successful or not and so on. Watching how the community and the company evolve is really interesting.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I’ve been working on assembly competitions for a single project mostly and the main problem was resolving various inconsistencies between requirements, components, prototypes which were introduced at various stages of the project.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
In short, have a plan for solving the problem and be fast and accurate when implementing that plan.

What is the story behind your handle?
This is just acronym for my full name.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I bought my first PC at the age of 28.

Studio: Trial_and_Error

What is your favorite part about Studio?
Not to mention the financial reward, Topcoder had really helped me enhance my design skills and build up my self-belief. Winning is definitely not easy here because I know I’m competing with a lot of talented designers around the world. But the moment you see your name being selected as winner, there’s a different feeling of pride. Now that’s priceless.

What was the hardest project you worked on last month?
Without blinking an eye, I’d say it’s the “A Day in the Life – Flash Animation Contest” . I just thought that the time is very limited for me because I also have a day job to attend, and could only work for my submission as soon as I get home. But I’m really determined to win so I just sacrificed some sleep just to get through it.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at Studio?
Understanding the client’s requirement is a very essential factor to start right in the competition. Yeah at first you’ll get rejection, but make sure you learn from those mistakes to be able to deliver a better design the next time.

What is the story behind your handle?
Nothing serious – it was just the first thing that came to my mind because initially everything was just a trial for me — if I’m gonna be successful in every competition.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I play the guitar and I’m a frustrated rockstar.
