item.title: Meet the April Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the April Coders and Designers of the Month! Check out their interviews. Algorithm: Radient What is your favorite part of TopCoder? There are a lot of algorithm competitions in the world, but only TopCoder’s SRM has a peculiar … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the April Coders and Designers of the Month! Check out their interviews.

Algorithm: Radient

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
There are a lot of algorithm competitions in the world, but only TopCoder’s SRM has a peculiar step it called ‘challenge phase’. I think it’s so good for me. I sometimes take a mistake in my programming codes unexpectedly, but I seldom or never check it again. TopCoder makes me think again and write codes carefully. And it also gives me a chance to read the other coder’s programming code. It’s a perfect textbook of algorithm and coding skills.

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
“Palindrome Phrases” in Single Round Match 439 on 30th, April. I took a close look at this problem and thought once and again. In fact, I already experienced some problems that was similar to this problem, but I cannot still understand this problem type.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
Actually, I’ve never been a winner of the competition. But I think that to solve the problem without any mistake is extremely important. Even if someone solves a problem soon, if that solution has just a mere mistake, finally it spends lots of time for correction. To make a perfect solution all at once is so hard, but it will be powerful weapon in a competition, I guess.

What is the story behind your handle?
When I was in a middle school, I was absorbed in play a card game it called ‘Magic: the Gathering’. In that game, there was a card it named ‘Radiant, the archangel’ and I liked that card so much. Therefore when I decided to make a handle for TopCoder, I recollected that card’s name. But I couldn’t know its name exactly. After all, my handle had been ‘Radient’ not ‘Radiant’. Yes, it was just a typographical error. Nevertheless, I love my handle name so much. It’s so unique, isn’t it?

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I’m Korean, but I’m now here in Osaka, Japan. I had been studying in a foreign country since April, 2009. So I was ranked in Korea as well as Osaka University in Japan. ‘April’ is a word with two meanings for me. The one is beginning to study in a foreign country, and the other is being an algorithm coder of the month in TopCoder!

Design: Bramandia

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
As a designer, my favorite part is to think about the design, e.g. what the classes should be, what design patterns to use, how each class interacts one another, etc. I also enjoy the drawing part, e.g. interacting with the UML Tool .

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
I think the hardest project was “Budget Stacker Consumer Survey Management v1.0″ in which the requirements were not clear. This requires many clarifications in the forum.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
An important factor is not to be afraid of losing. There might be 2 or 3 or even more good designers registered for the same design. Just go on, don’t afraid to lose, consider winning/losing as a natural part of the process. At worst, we could learn from the winning submission.

I guess determination is the next factor. As a software designer, we need to read the requirements, understand them, ask questions if necessary, finally we need to submit a working design. These need a lot of efforts. Determination would help us to struggle till the deadline .

As we go along, experience matters a lot since it allows us to work more efficiently and allows me to do more design in the same period of time.

What is the story behind your handle?
There is no story about it. It is simply my first name which happens to be pretty much uncommon. It might be unique across the globe, but I don’t claim that .

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I am Indonesian, married and expected to have a child soon. Hopefully this is surprising enough .

Development: elkhawajah

What is your favorite part of TopCoder?
Competiton ( I love the thrill of it )

What was the hardest project or problem you worked on last month?
none All of the projects I worked on fall in my field of expertise.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at TopCoder?
It is the ability to deal with adrenaline/fear/euphoria that goes into competing.

What is the story behind your handle?
No special story behind my handle, it is my surname

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
I hate computers!

Studio: djnapier

What is your favorite part about Studio?
Apart from the obvious benefit of Studio (the opportunity to earn serious money), my favourite part is knowing that the work I do is valued by the client. Having them select your work out of many entries gives a great sense of confidence and pride in the work that you’re doing.

What was the hardest project you worked on last month?
It’s a tie between two projects – both were hard for very different reasons:
1) A website storyboard project with 8 pages of layout to be done. It was hard because maintaining a consistent style across many pages, can be hard to do, especially in a conceptual space where you sometimes come up with a nicer solution halfway through the project and have to readjust what you’ve already done. However the reward on this project was worth it.

2) It was nearing the end of the competition window for TCO and I was hovering at the bottom of the top 10. There were a few smaller jobs where I had to step back and say ‘This really needs my attention and focus otherwise I’ll never get there’. Normally on small jobs, not a lot of time goes into planning and researching them, but if I didn’t put in effort and it turned out I needed to on these projects, I would have regretted it.

What do you think is the most important factor to win a competition at Studio?
I think the important thing is to realise that you’re not designing for you, you’re designing for someone else. Sure you can influence the style, but always think of what the client is trying to convey. Also, any feedback you receive is really important – take it in, apply it, and then use it as a springboard for refined and fantastic design.

What is the story behind your handle?
Nothing too special – just my initials and my last name. I feel that having a handle like ‘coolguy45′ is great and I understand privacy, but it misses a big opportunity to market yourself. I think it makes users a bit more approachable, taking down that digital wall.

Tell us one surprising thing about you.
Oh there’s a few surprising things about me – I can lick my left elbow, but not my right (apparently “impossible” to do); I was born with a sixth finger on my left pinky (no bone, but it had a fingernail! – was removed at birth but still have the scar to show) & I can balance objects on my nose. Circus Freakshow – where do I sign up?

item.title: AOL/TopCoder Sensations Developer Challenge Winners to Be Announced at the TCO09
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: AOL today announced that the AOL/TopCoder Sensations Developer Challenge will culminate at the 2009 TopCoder Open (TCO) on Monday, June 1 – Thursday, June 4, 2009 in Las Vegas, NV where the winning accessibility application developed by competition participants will … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded: AOL today announced that the AOL/TopCoder Sensations Developer Challenge will culminate at the 2009 TopCoder Open (TCO) on Monday, June 1 – Thursday, June 4, 2009 in Las Vegas, NV where the winning accessibility application developed by competition participants will be announced. AOL teamed with TopCoder, Inc., leader in online programming competitions, skills assessment and competitive software development, to encourage third party development of targeted value-add features for the disability community. Features developed will leverage core functionality surfaced through AOL application programming interfaces (APIs). Read full story here.

item.title: The O’Reilly Media “TopCoder Cookbook”, written by… Who else?!
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: TopCoder is working with O’Reilly Media to develop a “Cookbook” about TopCoder, describing the problems & techniques used by TopCoder members when participating in the various types of TopCoder competitions, and who better to write it than the members of … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder is working with O’Reilly Media to develop a “Cookbook” about TopCoder, describing the problems & techniques used by TopCoder members when participating in the various types of TopCoder competitions, and who better to write it than the members of the TopCoder community itself?

The first stage is an open call to the TopCoder members to create draft “recipes” for the TopCoder Cookbook. Each recipe describes a solution to a problem frequently encountered by TopCoder members when participating in a TopCoder competition. This can include – but is not limited to – use of tools, competition formats, process, navigating the web sites, or common types of competition submissions, patterns, requirements, and so on. Any issue that you have encountered and solved when competing on TopCoder could be the subject of a recipe.

Credit will be given to recipe ideas accepted into the book, as well as a portion of the author payments, as described in the TopCoder Cookbook project description.

TopCoder and O’Reilly are both very excited about this experiment, and hope that many of you will join the effort.

Let the writing begin!

item.title: Announcing Facebook as TCO09 Sponsor!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: TopCoder is thrilled to announce Facebook as a TCO09 sponsor! Facebook is hiring brilliant engineers who like to build. Because we’re growing so quickly, there is enormous opportunity for individuals to have an impact and to grow as our service … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder is thrilled to announce Facebook as a TCO09 sponsor!

Facebook is hiring brilliant engineers who like to build. Because we’re growing so quickly, there is enormous opportunity for individuals to have an impact and to grow as our service and our company grows. What matters here is what you contribute, not your credentials.

No one has ever done what we are trying to do at such speed and scale, and we do it all with less than two hundred engineers. Our active user to engineer ratio is over 1,000,000:1… and growing, and you just won’t get that personal impact at any other company.

We’ve got 200 million users around the world so far, but we have so much more to do and build… and that’s where your kung fu comes into play. Come build with us, we’re hiring.

Apply here.

Read more here.

item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: We have a client who is looking for the TopCoder community to help name their company! The name will be for an online only electronics retailer, a one-stop online shop that gives you the ability to hunt for what you … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
We have a client who is looking for the TopCoder community to help name their company! The name will be for an online only electronics retailer, a one-stop online shop that gives you the ability to hunt for what you want at a price that’s right for you by having options to purchase new, used, refurbished, and more.

The contest is to create a company name and define an associated domain name.

Let’s hear those ideas!

item.content:encoded:
The second Remix Challenge Idea Generation contest has ended, and we’ll be looking over the 11 submissions this week and announcing winners on Friday May 15th.

Next up is the Musical Instruments Idea Generation contest, which runs until May 18th.

Best Buy now has a full-on Musical Instruments Store set up inside select Best Buy locations. We’re not talking about a few guitars and some keyboards but also top of the line guitars, drums, keyboards and DJ gear. A selection for everyone from beginners to professionals, making the Best Buy Musical Instrument Store a major retailer of rock gear in the country. We are looking for ideas that drive customer awareness to the Best Buy Musical Instrument selections.

Learn more about Best Buy Remix Musical Instruments challenge, then submit your ideas and win $500!

item.title: pulky is the TCO09 Assembly Competition Champion!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40

item.title: Best Buy Remix Challenge Launches with First Idea Generation Contest
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: Think you can build a better Best Buy? We do, and we’re launching the Remix Challenge to prove it! TopCoder and Best Buy are proud to announce this exciting new series of contests. Over the coming months, we’ll be building … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Think you can build a better Best Buy? We do, and we’re launching the Remix Challenge to prove it!

TopCoder and Best Buy are proud to announce this exciting new series of contests. Over the coming months, we’ll be building applications in a variety of categories, using the Remix open API for BestBuy.com’s product catalog to help find solutions to specific challenges.

Each challenge will begin with an Idea Generation contest, where you will be presented with a problem or issue pertaining to customer experience in a particular category. How would you help a customer through the many decisions they need to make when purchasing a flat panel television? How would you better present the wide array of accessories that are so important when buying a laptop PC or mp3 player? How would you improve the shopping experience for Best Buy’s wide selection of movie & video game titles, or build awareness about Best Buy Rewards Points , or sell more ink & toner for printers?

Learn more about the Remix Challenge and compete now!

item.title: TCO09 Sponsor SNIA-XAM Hosts Application Idea Generation Contest!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: The SNIA XAM Initiative is proud to join with TopCoder to sponsor the first SNIA coding challenge. There are two competitions scheduled to run for this event: an application Idea Generation contest followed by the Prototype contest for developing of … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The SNIA XAM Initiative is proud to join with TopCoder to sponsor the first SNIA coding challenge. There are two competitions scheduled to run for this event: an application Idea Generation contest followed by the Prototype contest for developing of the best ideas. Idea Generation is the contest to brainstorm and propose ideas for tools and solutions based on the XAM Specification. The Prototype contest will be from June to August with winners being announced at SNIA’s Storage Developers Conference (SDC) in Santa Clara, CA from September 14 -17, 2009. For more information on SDC please go to http://www.snia.org/events/storage-developer2009/.

Read more about the contest and register here.

item.title: Meet the March Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to our March Coders and Designers of the Month! TopCoder sat down to interview these honored members and we hope you enjoy! Algorithm: dkorduban Here is dkorduban at SEERC’2006 How does it feel to be the Coder of the … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to our March Coders and Designers of the Month! TopCoder sat down to interview these honored members and we hope you enjoy!

Algorithm: dkorduban

Here is dkorduban at SEERC’2006

How does it feel to be the Coder of the Month?
I’m very pleased.

What is your favorite hobby besides TopCoder?
Can’t say I have one particular hobby. Besides math-related stuff I like reading, different outdoor activities and a whole bunch of small fun pastimes. Say, collecting sugar packets or paper folding.

What is one thing that you have learned at TopCoder that has helped you in other areas of your life?
Quick-Typical-DP-Problem-Solving-Skill, if consider ACM-style competitions as other area of my life. More seriously, I’ve learned to follow KISS principle as often as possible. It really helps in many areas.

Design: Standlove

What brought you to TopCoder?
I originally competed in the ACM contests, after I am retired, I heard TopCoder from WishingBone.
At that time, I was still interested in the algorithm contests and still had the passion to improve my skills, but after doing a couple of contests at TopCoder, my passion faded away and I felt that I would probably never be good at it.

Later I switched to the Component contests, and it turns out that I can live an independent life by doing it.

How does it feel to be the Coder of the Month?
It’s not the first time for me to be the Coder of the Month. But this time is probably because of the architecture competitions I won.
So it’s still a new experience to me, and I am glad that I come back with some new skills that I have learned in the last few months.

What is your favorite hobby besides TopCoder?
Read and Think. I’m not quite good at it actually, but I am enjoying it more and more, and I think I’m improving on it too, though very slowly.

What is one thing that you have learned at TopCoder that has helped you in other areas of your life?
Sometimes after I submit my submission, I think my submission is perfect.
But after the review results comes out, it turns out that the reviewers don’t agree with me at all.

In the beginning, it was really a tough time for me to open the review cards and do the appeals.
I got nervous and sometimes even angry about it, but after years of competing, I gradually start to take it easy.

And I start to take it easy too when I see people having different views or life styles than mine in my other areas of life.

Frankly speaking, I am not quite sure whether I learned it from my TopCoder life or my other areas of life, but I think I only have one life here, and I don’t really need to cut it into two parts.

Development: pinoydream

Here is pinoydream after the Formula 1 Race in Singapore, in September 2008. TopCoder paid for that!

What brought you to TopCoder?
My friends introduced me to TopCoder (Thanks to them! ) and around Feb of 2007, I registered and ever since I’ve been joining competitions on my spare time. What keeps me going is the challenge of every contest and the reward that you receive from it.

How does it feel to be the Coder of the Month?
It feels great! Nice to know that hard work pays off.

What is your favorite hobby besides TopCoder?
Besides TopCoder, I play basketball, computer games, and hanging out with friends. I’m also a photography hobbyist.

What is one thing that you have learned at TopCoder that has helped you in other areas of your life?
No pain, no gain.

Studio: billow

Billow at Grand View Garden in Beijing.

What brought you to Studio?
A friend sent me a link to a studio contest (a logo contest) and I submited one and became “cannon fodder”. Not a good start point, but I still went on because I like creative jobs!

How does it feel to be the Designer of the Month?
It was really great. Wow~ hard to believe! Thanks, fellows!

What is your favorite hobby besides Studio?
Favorite? That must be watching videos on youtube!

What is one thing that you have learned at Studio that has helped you in other areas of your life?
I think it’s “Detail makes difference”. Sometimes the whole design is good but not enough. It’s the detail that make things perfect.

item.title: Announcing IEEE-USA as Sponsor of TCO09
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: TopCoder is excited to welcome first-time Platinum Sponsor IEEE-USA to the 2009 TopCoder Open! IEEE is the world’s largest technical society, bringing members access to the industry’s most essential technical information, networking opportunities, career development tools, and many other exclusive … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder is excited to welcome first-time Platinum Sponsor IEEE-USA to the 2009 TopCoder Open!

IEEE is the world’s largest technical society, bringing members access to the industry’s most essential technical information, networking opportunities, career development tools, and many other exclusive benefits.

No matter where you live, IEEE is there, with more than 300 local IEEE sections, 1,300 technical chapters, and 300 annual IEEE conferences worldwide. As a member, you’ll have the opportunity to attend your local section or chapter meetings, volunteer for leadership positions, or attend a conference to meet industry leaders and practitioners, encounter the latest research, and present your papers to an international audience.

Join the World’s Largest Technical Professional Association.

IEEE membership helps support the IEEE mission of promoting the engineering profession for the benefit of humanity and the profession. Membership also enables affordable student membership, funds university program accreditation and helps introduce technology careers to young people around the world.

You make a difference when you join IEEE.

JOIN IEEE

Read more.

item.title: Registration Open for Experimental Marathon Series!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Registration is now open for the Experimental Marathon Series! Cash prizes and trips to the 2009 TopCoder(R) Open are up for grabs! This is the first of a series of Experimental Marathon Matches that TopCoder is running in coordination with … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Registration is now open for the Experimental Marathon Series! Cash prizes and trips to the 2009 TopCoder(R) Open are up for grabs!

This is the first of a series of Experimental Marathon Matches that TopCoder is running in coordination with Harvard Business School. The structure and rules for these events are a departure from anything that TopCoder has run in the past, in that we will be exploring how change effects the way individuals collaborate and share information about approaches and code.

The competitions will all involve solving a computational biology problem. This first problem is related to genomics. We believe that the TopCoder community may have an interesting take on these problems and could potentially come up with breakthroughs that benefit science beyond TopCoder.

The competitions each will involve solving a computational biology problem. This first problem is related to genomics. We believe that the TopCoder community may have an interesting take on these problems and could potentially come up with breakthroughs that benefit science in general.

In this Experimental Marathon Match, members who register for the event will automatically be assigned into one of three groups. Read more about the groups here.

Registration is now open until April 13, 2009 at 9:00 a.m. EDT (GMT/UTC -4).

Register here.

The competition will run from 1:00 p.m. EDT (GMT/UTC -4) on April 13 through 2:00 p.m. EDT (GMT/UTC -4) on April 27, 2009.

Harvard’s Professor Lakhani has been active in the forums discussing these Experimental Marathon Matches. His handle is karimlakhani and you can find further discussion here.

Please read the rules before registering.

item.title: Announcing the Winners of the $100,000 Ribbit Killer App Challenge!
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: Ribbit today announced the winners of the $100,000 Ribbit Killer App Challenge. The choice was tough, as many apps pushed the envelope of integrating Ribbit’s voice, telephony and messaging API. Overall, we looked for apps that achieved innovative interactions with … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Ribbit today announced the winners of the $100,000 Ribbit Killer App Challenge.

The choice was tough, as many apps pushed the envelope of integrating Ribbit’s voice, telephony and messaging API. Overall, we looked for apps that achieved innovative interactions with Flash — and integrated Ribbit’s features to make significant impact on the way we communicate.

Congratulations to rominirani, senagbe, joedeveloper, and dhbellol – who each won a $15,000 Grand Prize. And to villmer, whose Lucid Viewer app won both its category and the Killer App Challenge “Best in Show” award, for a total of $30,000!

See the announcement here.

item.title: TCO09 Updates!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: The 2009 TopCoder Open is as exciting as ever! Slowly but surely the large group of competitors that started off in this competition have been getting narrowed down to the top finalists that will soon be making their way to Las Vegas! … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The 2009 TopCoder Open is as exciting as ever! Slowly but surely the large group of competitors that started off in this competition have been getting narrowed down to the top finalists that will soon be making their way to Las Vegas! Keep up-to-date with the action of all the competitions!

Algorithm:
TCO09 Algorithm Round 4 will take place on Saturday, March 28 at Noon EDT (GMT/UTC -4). See what time it starts in your area. This round will feature 120 coders all hoping to make it to round 5 and one more chance at that trip to Las Vegas! Don’t miss the excitement of this round!

Marathon:
The final round of the Marathon Competition is now underway. This two week long competition will give us our top ten finalists! Want to see what they have to solve to make it to Las Vegas? You can register for Marathon Match 52 and compete along side them!

Mod Dash:
The Mod Dash is an all new competition onsite. The leaderboard is looking tense and the top eight point getters are winning a trip to Las Vegas! The onsite Mod Dash championship will consist of three rounds. Each round will consist of 6 consecutive Mod Dashes. Competitors will have 10 minutes to solve the presented bug or enhancement. The first competitor to correctly solve the problem will win the Mod Dash and 100 points. But there’s a catch – each competitor who successfully solves the Mod Dash AFTER the winning submission will reduce the winner’s score by 10 points.

At the end of three rounds, the competitor with the most points will be the 2009 Mod Dash Champion!

Studio:
There are many TCO-Eligible Studio Competitions going on right now. If you have not been to Studio lately, hop over there and check out the awesome designs that the members are submitting.

Online Competitions:
The online competitions leaderboard’s are getting exciting! Check out who is in the lead and who has projects still going.
Architecture Leaderboard
Assembly Leaderboard
Component Design Leaderboard
Component Development Leaderboard
Specification Leaderboard

If you find your name at the top of a leaderboard, are from a country that does not participate in the visa waiver program, and have not asked for a visa invitation letter from TopCoder yet, please do so immediately! Email jmpld40 for assistance. For more information on this matter, go here.

item.content:encoded:
Here is your chance to get your ideas in front of Millions of viewers a month. The ESPN arcade is looking to TopCoder members to come up with new ideas for games. All you need is an idea, a simple image representing the idea, and a brief write up. If ESPN decides to build your game you will get $250 and millions of people will see your game.

ESPN will pay for EVERY idea they like, so it’s not too late to jump in!

The deadline is Monday March 23rd at 4pm EDT. You can submit as many ideas has you like.

item.title: Meet the February Coders and Designers of the Month!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the February Coders and Designers of the month! TopCoder got to interview them and catch a glimpse of their lives outside of TopCoder. Algorithm: tsebayoth What brought you to TopCoder? I was looking for some practice to ACM … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the February Coders and Designers of the month! TopCoder got to interview them and catch a glimpse of their lives outside of TopCoder.

Algorithm: tsebayoth

What brought you to TopCoder?
I was looking for some practice to ACM ICPC, some friends showed me TopCoder, and told me that it was a way of learning.

How does it feel to be the Coder of the Month?
I was surprised by your choice and felt rewarded by my dedication on the study of algorithms.
Like we usually say here in Ceará/Brasil, “This is so much money”, meaning this is something that I really appreciate.

What is your favorite hobby besides TopCoder?
Solving algorithm problems on online judges! Just kidding. In fact, I like to play the saxophone, go to church, and go out with my girlfriend.

What is one thing that you have learned at TopCoder that has helped you in other areas of your life?
In TopCoder we try to improve our knowledge on algorithms, increase our rating and earn respect among other coders, so we learn that to achieve that we need dedication, effort and patience. This principle applies for everything we do in life.

Component Design: saarixx

saarixx on vacation in Port Aventura, the amusement park in Spain.

What brought you to TopCoder?
ragetrue recommended me to visit TopCoder’s web site about three years ago. This happened during the Ukrainian national programming competition. I visited it in 2 months after this event. First, I tried Algorithm competitions. They were found to be unsuccessful for me. But then I participated in the Intel Multi-threading Marathon competition, placed second and won a good prize. This event heavily raised my interest in TopCoder in general.

How does it feel to be the Coder of the Month?
It’s great (especially taking into account that my performance in February gave me a good chance to become a TCO design champion)!!!

What is your favorite hobby besides TopCoder?
I like watching Formula-1 racings and my favourite TV shows (“The Big Bang Theory”, “My Name is Earl” and “Two and a Half Men”), playing tennis (both table and court) and soccer with my friends.

What is one thing that you have learned at TopCoder that has helped you in other areas of your life?
At TopCoder I understood that I should not be afraid of new technologies. When I started with TopCoder, I hadn’t known C# and Java. But during design competitions I learned them and realized that one week can be enough to learn some specific technology like WCF, WPF or JPA good enough.

Development: assistant

assistant enjoying lobster in Sydney

What brought you to TopCoder?
haha posted an introduction to TopCoder on a BBS. It mentioned the outsourcing model of TopCoder and I felt it interesting. After a few tries, I began to enjoy the competitions.

How does it feel to be the Coder of the Month?
This is a big surprise.

What is your favorite hobby besides TopCoder?
Reading, enjoying movies and traveling.

What is one thing that you have learned at TopCoder that has helped you in other areas of your life?
Don’t be afraid to lose. If you don’t try, you already and always lose.

Studio: djnapier

Here is djnapier outside the stadium that hosted the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia.

What brought you to Studio?
I went to a summer program for Mathematics in early 2005 and although I’ve never done any maths at that level since, another attendee (a coder on here) suggested I should enter the TopCoder Open logo competition (I think I came 4th that year?). Fast forward a few years, with an education qualification and few years working experience under my belt, my skills are a bit more refined which has brought about more success at TopCoder.

How does it feel to be the Designer of the Month?
Very rewarding – many times it has been frustrating to come third or not even get placed but in those instances it’s because the client just has a different idea of what they want vs. your vision for the project. So to be acknowledged as Designer of the Month is a personal reward for persisting with it.

What is your favorite hobby besides Studio?
I really enjoy music and photography and wish I had time to refine my skills in those areas too (alas there are only 24 hours in a day!). I would love to be a DJ someday as I have great respect for those who can get a dancefloor rocking. Sometimes I need to get away from the computer and do nothing design-related which is a great unwind.

What is one thing that you have learned at Studio that has helped you in other areas of your life?
Organisation and time-management! Wow, what a kick in the butt it has been. Trying to get a submission that will pass screening in on time can take its toll – especially living in a different time-zone. Waking up at 3.30AM to find a submission fail has been tough but ultimately rewarding (not only because I was able to fix and resubmit – but slowly learning to double check everything and submit only once!).

item.title: Announcing SNIA XAM as TCO09 Sponsor! Take part in their survey!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: TopCoder(R) is very excited to announce first time Silver Sponsor SNIA XAM as part of the 2009 TopCoder Open! SNIA XAM has put together a brief survey and will be giving away 20 prizes to randomly selected members who fill … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder(R) is very excited to announce first time Silver Sponsor SNIA XAM as part of the 2009 TopCoder Open! SNIA XAM has put together a brief survey and will be giving away 20 prizes to randomly selected members who fill out the survey. See the survey here.

SNIA XAM Initiative:
The Storage Networking Industry Association (SNIA) is a not-for-profit global organization, made up of some 400 member companies and 7,000 individuals spanning virtually the entire storage industry. SNIA’s mission is to lead the storage industry worldwide in developing and promoting standards, technologies, and educational services to empower organizations in the management of information. The SNIA XAM (eXtensible Access Method) Initiative has recently released an industry standard, XAM API, and a software developer kit to implement this standard.

The SNIA XAM Initiative is proud to welcome the world’s top programming talent to tap into your ideas and test your programming skills to accelerate the creation of tools and solutions based on XAM. Living in an era of rampant information explosion and the need to manage, secure, and access vast amounts of data is exceeding the capabilities of traditional data technologies based on file systems and databases.

XAM Standard Solves Vendor Lock-in and Traditional Technology Limitations
The XAM standard puts power back in the hands of IT by providing a common interface for applications to seamlessly interoperate across XAM-enabled fixed-content or SAN storage devices. The XAM standard empowers IT and service providers to deploy a variety of storage media from multiple vendors and even migrate content from one storage platform to another.

XAM solves key problems for specialized storage and write once, read many devices providing long-term data retention by storing information in non-modifiable format on disk. Unfortunately, these systems require integration with applications that write to them. This forces datacenters and service providers to be locked-in to one vendor’s fixed-content platform, or incur the cost of integrating applications across multiple fixed-media platform interfaces.

XAM Features:
*XAM stores content as “objects” that consist of data and annotated metadata. An example is an X-ray image that is stored as the data component, while the patient’s name and other medical record details are stored as attached metadata. Metadata could be stored in a uniform format that can be indexed and searchable by independent tools. Also, metadata can help record and save important contextual information about the data, which may be used to interpret and make use of the data many years later;

*Metadata and data fields inside a XAM object can be defined as modifiable or non-modifiable. Changes to a field marked non-modifiable will result in a new version of the XAM object being created in the underlying storage device. This allows XAM objects to meet authenticity and chain of custody tracking requirements for e-discovery and medial environments.

*XAM generates a globally unique name (address) for each object, which is independent of the current computing environment, organization, location, or technology. As a consequence, objects may move around freely in time, changing their physical or technological location, all transparent to their current owner. This property is a fundamental enabler for transparent information lifecycle management (ILM).

The Topcoder SNIA XAM coding challenge offers developers the opportunity to:
*Create innovative ideas and applications for XAM
*Create innovative tools to speed the implementation of XAM
*Inspire developers to participate in industry standards development
*Create XAM vendor modules for new platforms, low cost platforms and cloud computing
*Integrate XAM libraries and XAM VIMs into operating systems and other relevant data computing stacks

Some idea categories for applications are the USA’s approach to Electronic Health Records, the ability to move user created data across various social media sites, enabling federated searches across Web-based digital libraries, metadata organization to improve the quality of results in an e-Discovery case, and improve how national governments and libraries will preserve data for future generations.

The SNIA XAM Initiative has created a community of resources to rapidly immerse yourself in understanding XAM, getting questions answered, and working with the XAM software:
*SNIA XAM Developers Group
*SNIA XAM Initiative
*SNIA XAM 1.0 Final Technical Position Specifications
*SNIA XAM SDK Working Draft Release

SNIA XAM wishes all the TCO09 competitors best of luck!

item.title: TCO09 Updates!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Algorithm Competition: The first round of the 2009 TopCoder Open Algorithm Competition will take place on Saturday, March 7 at Noon EST (GMT/UTC -5). Log in to the Competition Arena to chat with the competitors and watch the action! See what time … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Algorithm Competition: The first round of the 2009 TopCoder Open Algorithm Competition will take place on Saturday, March 7 at Noon EST (GMT/UTC -5). Log in to the Competition Arena to chat with the competitors and watch the action! See what time the match starts in your area.

Registration Is Still Open! If you have not registered for the TCO09, you still have time! Registration is still open for the following competitions: Architecture, Assembly, Component Design & Development, Mod Dash, Specification, and Studio Design. Don’t delay because registration will close on Thursday, March 19 at 9:00 a.m. EDT (GMT/UTC -5). Register here. Remember, registering once for the TCO09 allows you to compete in any of the competitions still open. Be sure to check the rules and regulations before you register and compete.

Member Videos: We have a number of member videos on our TCO09 channel but we want more! The shirts may have all been sent out but there is still hope for a few more winners! Join our group and send in your video today so yours can be part of our vote!

Thanks to all of you that have already sent in your videos. We think they are great! Best of luck to everyone for the rest of the TCO09!

item.content:encoded:
On Wednesday, March 4 at 11:00 a.m. EST (GMT/UTC -5), registration will end for the 2009 TopCoder Open Algorithm Competition. If you have not registered, you can do so here. Please remember that when you register for the TCO09 once, you can compete in all tracks of competition. However please be sure to read the competition rules and regulations first.

The third and final TCO09 Algorithm Competition Qualification Round will take place on Wednesday, March 4 at 9:00 p.m. EST (GMT/UTC -5). See what time it starts in your area. If you have not already advanced to Online Round 1 and have registered for the TCO09 before 11:00 a.m. on March 4, 2009, then you are eligible to participate in the final qualification.

The Algorithm Competition is heating up as the Online Rounds are coming soon! Best of luck to you!

item.title: Congratualtions to the Ribbit Killer App Challenge Checkpoint 3 Winners!
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: We’re in the homestretch now, with just over a week to go until the conclusion of the Ribbit Killer App Challenge. On March 12th the contest will end, and the judging team will decide on who will win the five … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
We’re in the homestretch now, with just over a week to go until the conclusion of the Ribbit Killer App Challenge. On March 12th the contest will end, and the judging team will decide on who will win the five $15,000 Best in Category prizes, and the $15,000 Best in Show Grand Prize.

One TopCoder member is going to win $30,000, will it be a new submitter, or one of today’s checkpoint winners?

Congratulations to rominirani, merhl, sah2ed, wkozi and villmer – each of whom has won a $1000 checkpoint prize. Three of these were brand new submissions, and two were updated and enhanced apps that had won at earlier checkpoints.

Check out all the winning apps below, and the check out the Killer App homepage for more information on this exciting competition!
 
 

$1000 Checkpoint 3 Winners

 
 
Killer App: “Save a Life”
by: rominirani
Description: This application addresses a need to reach out to Blood Donors in case of a blood requirement.

Using this application you can:
1) Maintain your contacts with their blood groups/phone numbers.
2) Contact them in case of a blood requirement via a Telephone Call, SMS or send a status via Twitter.
3) Search Red Cross locations in your city and call any of them directly from the application.
 
 
Killer App: “AIR iPhone”
by: merhl
Description: The AIR iPhone is a desktop application created with Adobe AIR and Adobe Flex 3, it simulates the UI of the iPhone. It has the capabilities to make calls, receive calls, check voicemail, add contacts and even send voice messages, all using Ribbit.
 
 
 
 
 
 
Killer App: “Diall.me”
by: sah2ed
Description: Diall.Me is a Ribbit platform powered app that allows users to make phone calls, send text messages and record voice messages to one or multiple recipients directly from a web browser. Although Diall.Me will be available as a browser-based application, desktop and handheld device versions that plug into existing platforms/application are planned for development for people that have enormous trouble giving up old habits.
 
 
Killer App: “Yeaah Widget”
by: wkozi
Description: Yeaah is acronym for ‘Yet Another virtuAl pHone application’. Place a widget on your Facebook profile and enjoy it. Widget allows contact with you without giving any of your data (phone number, email address). You alone decide how other users can contact with you.
 
 
 
 
 
 
Killer App: “Lucid Viewer”
by: Villmer
Description: Lucid Viewer is a platform for developing and distributing immersive technology projects. It is a virtual reality toolset empowering artists and entrepreneurs with a unique palette of technologies to create highly creative and distinctive projects. With the integration of the Ribbit voice technologies, I hope to further integrate the real world with the virtual one.

item.title: Cockpit Version 2 is Here
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: Direct users logging into the cockpit this week will notice a new look and better user experience for launching and monitoring contests, as well as a better submission viewer for browsing your designs and choosing your winners. Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Direct users logging into the cockpit this week will notice a new look and better user experience for launching and monitoring contests, as well as a better submission viewer for browsing your designs and choosing your winners.

Logging in is the same, just use your Topcoder handle and password from the TopCoder Direct home page. If you have existing projects, they will be viewable in the “My Projects” tab – and you can browse your designs and choose a winner in a much improved Submission Viewer widget (viewing is best done in the fullscreen mode).

We’ve still got some bugs to work through, and we’re adding new enhancements to the cockpit literally every day, so if you have any issues you need assistance with, or if you’d like to give us some feedback on your experience with version 2, send an email to directassist@topcoder.com and we’ll be there to help you through.

item.content:encoded:
As scheduled, the administration window for TopCoder Single Round Match 436 was unintentionally conflicting with the TCO09 3rd qualification round. SRM 436 will now take place on Wednesday, March 11, at 7:00 a.m. EDT (UTC/GMT -4 hours). We sincerely apologize for the short notice of this schedule change.

Also be aware that as of Sunday, March 8, 2009, TopCoder will be switching over to Eastern Daylight Time (EDT) (GMT/UTC -4). All competitions posted after Sunday, March 8, 2009 will be in Eastern Daylight Time.

Be sure to check the SRM details and the start time in your time zone.

item.title: Welcome to TopCoder Direct!
item.dc:creator: jack hughes
item.description: Have you ever thought: Why is it so difficult to find people that can help me in the digital world? I know I have to use digital media (web, mobile IM, email, etc.) to find, present to and connect with … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Have you ever thought: Why is it so difficult to find people that can help me in the digital world? I know I have to use digital media (web, mobile IM, email, etc.) to find, present to and connect with my customers and business partners to make my business more effective, I just don’t know how best to do it and don’t seem able to find the best people to help me. I know there are tons of tools, gadgets, etc. to help me out, but none of them do the thing I need most: none of them listen to me and help me get what I need done. With the internet and communication being what they are today, shouldn’t there be an easier way to connect with people that can help me hone my message, connect with *my* customers and get the work I need done to engage my customers in the digital world?

If you have, then all we can say is: Boy, have you come to the right place!

As the world becomes more and more digitally based (web, mobile, email, IM and who knows what’s next), finding, communicating and interacting with your customers and business partners requires whole new sets of skills. The task can be daunting. Finding the right people with the right skills is tantamount to finding a needle in a haystack. Pick wrong and you won’t just make your wallet quite a bit thinner, you’ll waste precious time that could have been used getting it right. TopCoder has turned this paradigm upside-down. No longer are you going to have to go find the people who can best get your work done, they’ll find you.

Since 2001, TopCoder has been building one of the largest and most active communities of software developers and creative designers anywhere. So far, we’ve admittedly been a little selfish in sharing these folks with the rest of the world. Once you get in here you’ll see why you can’t really blame us: This is one of the most talented, interesting and helpful groups of people you’re likely to find (for instance, this website and everything on it has been designed and built by them). But, as they say, ‘you can’t keep a good person (or, in our case, about 170,000 – and growing – of them) down’. TopCoder Direct is your way to get involved.

How it works

We start with a really big community and add a dose of competition. Turns out, passionate people love to compete. What are they competing for? A whole host of things (money, skill development, recognition, fun), but, with a little help in defining a competition, some of them would love to compete for you. Through a series of competitions, you’ll build logos, web sites, mobile apps and pretty much anything digital you can imagine.

It all starts in what we call TopCoder Direct. Direct – as its name implies – takes out the middle and puts you in immediate touch with the community. Whether you’re trying to build or change your website, building a web based ordering system for your customers, need to do a presentation for a customer or a new flyer or marketing piece, Direct is your center of operations. It will allow you to get help, post competitions, see results of competitions and interact with the community.

What do you use it for? Ultimately, anything: Logo design, web site and page layout and design, icons, powerpoint presentations, flyers, product catalogs, customer service and database systems and mobile applications to name a few. Want a banner or series of banners for a new product or general marketing campaign? Direct. Want a new website because the old one is tired (embarrassing?)? Direct. Want to let customers order directly through your web site or via their phone? Direct.

Now there is a lot more to TopCoder and Studio than just Direct. There are forums, blogs, big tournaments and events and a host of other ways to get involved. We hope that you’ll get involved in as much as you’d like.

We need you.

One of the tenets of TopCoder is that without our community, we are nothing. By asking you to join, we don’t just want your business, we want your input. Do we have it all figured out? Not by a long shot. Letting the community know what of your experience is positive and what is negative is the only way we have to make everyone’s experience better. Don’t be afraid to post in the forums: http://studio.topcoder.com/forums or shoot an email. If you don’t like something or think it can be done better, let us know. We have a long way to go and need your help in getting there.

Please bear in mind that TopCoder Direct is in beta. We can’t guarantee that stuff won’t break, that we won’t lose your stuff. What we can guarantee is that there need to be many new features and Direct will go through many changes.

I’m not prone to ‘speak’ for the community. Like any community, there are many diverse interests and opinions and we respect them all. In this case, though, I’m confident that I can speak for the community in saying: Welcome! We’re glad you’re here. We can’t wait to get started!

item.title: Announcing the $10,000 Linden Lab Marathon Match!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: TopCoder is excited to announce the $10,000 Linden Lab Marathon Match! First prize is $5,000 and the match is now underway! You have until Noon EDT (GMT/UTC -4) on March 25, 2009 to perfect your final submission. JPEG 2000 is … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder is excited to announce the $10,000 Linden Lab Marathon Match! First prize is $5,000 and the match is now underway! You have until Noon EDT (GMT/UTC -4) on March 25, 2009 to perfect your final submission.

JPEG 2000 is an image format meant to be an improvement over the original JPEG format. Linden Lab, the creator of Second Life, uses this file format heavily via the OpenJPEG library, an open source project. While these images have very good image quality for their file sizes and can be decoded as they stream across a network channel, a drawback has been that they are computationally expensive to decode. Because almost all of the textures in Second Life are encoded via JPEG 2000, the decode performance is very important to millions of Second Life users. Your task in this problem is to build on the OpenJPEG library, improving its decode speed. Participants may submit code written in C++.

Check out the entire Linden Lab problem statement here.

Register to participate in this competition in the Active Contests list here.

View all of the details here.

item.title: $5,000 FundingPrediction Marathon Match!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: TopCoder has a customer that needs your help. They are looking for an algorithm to better predict which of their clients will successfully convert loan requests into funded loans. They have provided historical data consisting of millions of records, spanning … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
TopCoder has a customer that needs your help. They are looking for an algorithm to better predict which of their clients will successfully convert loan requests into funded loans. They have provided historical data consisting of millions of records, spanning three years, and representing billions of dollars in loans. One of the key challenges to this problem is that it may take up to five months for the company to hear whether a loan is funded or not. Thus, this problem will require you to develop novel machine learning techniques accounting for the fact that the training data contains loans which, while not funded yet, will eventually be funded.

Whoever is able to best predict which loans will be funded will walk away with the $2,500 prize! You have until Monday, March 2, 2009 at Noon EST (GMT/UTC -5) to fine tune your solution.

Check out the FundingPrediction problem statement here.

Register here.

View more details here.

item.title: January Coders and Designers of the Month
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: Congratulations to the January Coders and Designers of the Month! TopCoder caught up with them to find out how it felt to receive this honor and learn a bit more about them. Algorithm: Yasuh What brought you to TopCoder? In … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to the January Coders and Designers of the Month! TopCoder caught up with them to find out how it felt to receive this honor and learn a bit more about them.

Algorithm: Yasuh

What brought you to TopCoder?
In 2007, I found an article that introduced a person who joined TopCoder. I was very interested in ICPC, and wanted to solve problems online, so I decided to join TopCoder.

How does it feel to be the Coder of the Month?
Unbelievable! I’m very surprised to hear that, and very happy now.

What is your favorite hobby besides TopCoder?
I like scuba diving, so I go to Okinawa twice a year. It is very fun to dive into the sea and play with fish.

What is one thing that you have learned at TopCoder that has helped you in other areas of your life?
Think again before doing something. SRMs are more difficult than ICPC because coding phase and system phases are completely separated. So I have to think and think again about the algorithm and my source code.

Design: Urmass

Photos are of Urmass at his computer and with his professor.

What brought you to TopCoder?
A couple of years ago I participated in the ACM Collegiate Programming Contests where such prominent TC members as real_vg and dmytro also participated. They introduced me to TopCoder.

How does it feel to be the Coder of the Month?
I feel myself very excited. This prize inspires me to improve my skills.

What is your favorite hobby besides TopCoder?
I like music. I have a lot of records and I also play guitar.

What is one thing that you have learned at TopCoder that has helped you in other areas of your life?
Competitions really help to tighten up my discipline.

Development: utlovey

Photos are of TongJi University and on vacation with his girlfriend.

What brought you to TopCoder?
My classmate introduced the TopCoder to me and I think joining it is the best way to improve my skills.

How does it feel to be the Coder of the Month?
Very surprised and excited. I feel lucky to be chosen as the coder of this month.

What is your favorite hobby besides TopCoder?
I like playing soccer and watching soccer match since my childhood. It brings me perseverance and a lot of happiness.

What is one thing that you have learned at TopCoder that has helped you in other areas of your life?
Value your time and work efficiently. I think it is the most important thing what I learned in TopCoder.

Studio: srinivasc

What brought you to Studio?
One of my colleagues referred this website for a competition and I was impressed with TopCoder competitions.

How does it feel to be the Designer of the Month?
I was excited and I want to participate more aggressively in TopCoder competitions

What is your favorite hobby besides Studio?
Playing Chess

What is one thing that you have learned at Studio that has helped you in other areas of your life?
That which does not kill you makes you stronger … LOL

item.title: Ribbit Checkpoint 2 Winners Announced – Still $95,000 in Prizes up for Grabs!
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: The Ribbit Team is excited to announce the winners of Checkpoint 2 of the Killer App Challenge! wkozi and dr_zeus have both won $1000 first prizes for their apps, and amiune, areyoukovi, ValD and velorien have all won $250 Second … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The Ribbit Team is excited to announce the winners of Checkpoint 2 of the Killer App Challenge!

wkozi and dr_zeus have both won $1000 first prizes for their apps, and amiune, areyoukovi, ValD and velorien have all won $250 Second Prizes. Congratulations!

Checkpoint 3 is coming in 10 days and there’s $5000 on the line, then we head into the final stretch when we’ll be awarding five $15,000 Best in Category prizes plus the $15,000 Best in Show Grand Prize. One TopCoder member is going to win $30,000!

If you haven’t yet submitted, it’s not too late. While the front runners here certainly have a head start, any flash/flex Killer App submitted before the Checkpoint 3 deadline will be eligible to win. And in fact, we’ll be giving away a sweet Ribbit T-Shirt to anyone who submits before February 23rd.

Check out the Killer App home page for all the details.

$1000 First Prize Winners

Killer App: “Yeaah Widget”
by: wkozi

Description: Yeaah is acronym for ‘Yet Another virtuAl pHone application’. Place a widget on your Facebook profile and enjoy it. Widget allows contact with you without giving any of your data (phone number, email address). You alone decide how other users can contact with you.
 
 
 
 
Killer App: “InSite Voice Support”
by: dr_zeus
Description: Contacting any large company’s customer service department should be easier. We already have to visit the company’s website to find the right phone number. Wouldn’t it be great if we could make the call directly in the browser and right on the same webpage? Even better, what if it were free? 
 
 
 

$250 Second Prize Winners

 
 
Killer App: “SocialPhone”
by: amiune
Description: A simple facebook app that allows you to talk with your facebook contacts all over the world wherever they are with just a click. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Killer App: “Ultimate Local”
by: areyoukovi
Description: Looking for your favorite restaurant or finding a local watering hole shouldn’t add to your busy day. Ultimate local will help everyone from the consummate explorer to the geographically-challenged find local businesses quicker and more easily.
 
 
 
 
Killer App: “Customer Support Widget”
by: ValD
Description: A website widget that allows users to leave their support requests and check status of their requests. Sales/support can call back those users in an organized manner. This widget challenges the traditional concept of the “Contact Us” page, and is a compact solution that includes both support request and support calling functionality.
 
 
 
 
Killer App: “Call Scheduler”
by: velorien
Description: A lightweight desktop application useful for scheduling calls. It can be minimized into system tray and it will pop out whenever a scheduled call is due, prompting the user to take action. While a call is in action, it allows the user to see what other scheduled calls are near, in a configurable timeframe, so that he may plan accordingly.

item.title: Bug Bash Weekend: More Bugs, More Money, More Prizes!
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: Update: We’ve announced the winners here. The 24-Hour Bug Bash was a moderate success, but we think maybe we didn’t give you enough time – so we’re launching another one, and this one runs through the entire weekend! The rules … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Update: We’ve announced the winners here.

The 24-Hour Bug Bash was a moderate success, but we think maybe we didn’t give you enough time – so we’re launching another one, and this one runs through the entire weekend!

The rules are the same: go to the Active Bug Races, look for the Flex issues with [BUG BASH] in the title, and submit a fix. If you need help setting up an environment, check out this page, or ask for help in the forums.

The more you can fix, the better.

Any solution submitted between now and 9:00am ET Monday morning will be eligible, and our top five prize money winners will once again receive a sweet TopCoder T-Shirt and their choice from one of the two fabulous prizes pictured here!

(If you won in the first Bash & win again – we’ll see what else we’ve got in the prize closet for you!)

Go get ‘em!

item.title: Fabulous Prizes up for grabs in the 24-Hour Bug Bash!
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: The 24 Hour Bug Bash has ended and we’re tallying up we’ve announced the winners, but we’ve got more bugs that need fixin’ and more prizes to give away, so we’re launching a second event!: The Bug Bash Weekend. See … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The 24 Hour Bug Bash has ended and we’re tallying up we’ve announced the winners, but we’ve got more bugs that need fixin’ and more prizes to give away, so we’re launching a second event!: The Bug Bash Weekend. See the post above for more information.

The bug races just got a lot more interesting!

Not only is every bug race now eligible for TCO points in the new “Mod Dash” competition track, but there’s a bunch of these things we want fixed really badly, so we’re throwing something extra into the pot!

We’ve identified a group of bugs as part of the 24 Hour Bug Bash, mostly related to the Flex Cockpit.

We’re going to give the top five earners on these over the next day a TopCoder T-Shirt (like this one) and your choice of either the fabulous water bottle or the fabulous coffee mug seen here!

We’re starting the Bash right now, and it ends at 3:00pm Eastern Standard Time tomorrow, Thursday, February 12. (Yes, that’s 25.5 hours – but who’s counting?)

All fixes submitted before the deadline that pass review will be eligible, and the top five prize winners on Bug Bash Bugs will win. Just look for the bugs with “Bug Bash” in the title and… get bashing!

Update: Winners Announced here

item.title: Announcing the 2009 TopCoder Open!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: You have all been waiting and now it is here! Registration is NOW OPEN for all NINE tracks of competition of the 2009 TopCoder Open. The new TCO will feature NINE tracks of competition, including ALGORITHM, ARCHITECTURE, ASSEMBLY, COMPONENT DESIGN … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
You have all been waiting and now it is here! Registration is NOW OPEN for all NINE tracks of competition of the 2009 TopCoder Open.

The new TCO will feature NINE tracks of competition, including ALGORITHM, ARCHITECTURE, ASSEMBLY, COMPONENT DESIGN and DEVELOPMENT, MARATHON, MOD DASH, SPECIFICATION, and STUDIO DESIGN.

With $150,000 in prize money, 100 trips to Las Vegas, and so many chances to win, register now!

*Please note that you only need to register once for the TCO09 in order to participate in any track of the tournament.*

See all the details here.

Have you joined the TCO09 group yet and sent in your video? If you have, great! If not, what are you waiting for! The call for videos is still going!

TopCoder wants a video of you and all our 180,000 plus members! This is a way for us to bring you all to the event in Vegas. Here is what you have to do:

1. Make a video stating your handle, your name, and where you are from. You can say it in your native language, in English, or both!
2. Upload your video here.

item.title: How to Compete Well in Conceptualization and Specification Contests
item.dc:creator: silvasurfas
item.description: By MiG-29 TopCoder Member A TopCoder member’s point of view, writing to members, of the Conceptualization and Specification contests. It includes tips and secrets for what to do and how to compete well. “The TopCoder software development methodology is mostly … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
By MiG-29
TopCoder Member

A TopCoder member’s point of view, writing to members, of the Conceptualization and Specification contests. It includes tips and secrets for what to do and how to compete well.

“The TopCoder software development methodology is mostly based on the usage of open community members. Many low level steps of software building have been opened to the development community. Anybody can participate in designing and coding software components, making the software GUI, assembling and testing final applications. But now, a new exciting possibility is available – making application Concepts and Specifications of business requirements. It means, the community members are able to work with TopCoder customers from the very beginning of the project. The output is a high level picture of the project – so your ideas and concepts will be the initial requirements for architects, designers, coders, assemblers and testers!”

Read the full article

item.title: vijay03: Getting Started on TopCoder
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: By vijay03 TopCoder Member While there are lots of resources here on TopCoder, we wanted to highlight this blog post from TC member vijay03, who wrote last February in his own blog about getting started in Algorithm competitions. “Programming contests … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
By vijay03
TopCoder Member

While there are lots of resources here on TopCoder, we wanted to highlight this blog post from TC member vijay03, who wrote last February in his own blog about getting started in Algorithm competitions.

“Programming contests are a way of identifying people good programming ( and general computer science ) talent. Companies pay good money to easily identify top talent for their company. Plus Topcoder acts as a sort of mediator between companies who want some custom software built quickly and developers who are willing to take on projects.”

Getting Started on TopCoder

item.title: We’ve Got Lots and Lots of Bugs
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: Normally, that’s not good news. But for you it means we’ve got almost $6,000 in prize money available in the Bug Races – the quickest and easiest way to make money at TopCoder! There are almost 50 bug races going … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Normally, that’s not good news. But for you it means we’ve got almost $6,000 in prize money available in the Bug Races – the quickest and easiest way to make money at TopCoder!

There are almost 50 bug races going for Cockpit v2.0.

Some are bugs, many are quick enhancements like changing colors, adding buttons and removing scroll bars, and a few bug races are to try some cool things out in flex like adding peek panels, page folds, lightboxing, and WindowShades.

The more we get done the more we will launch. The technologies are Flex and Java and full build environment instructions and source is available.

If you haven’t tried out the Bug Races yet, there’s no better time to jump in and start making quick fixes for quick cash!

item.title: crazyb0y is the TCHS09 Champion!
item.dc:creator: jmpld40
item.description: The 2009 TopCoder High School touranment finalized on January 24, 2009 and crazyb0y from China came out on top earning him $3,000 in prize money! Congratulations to crazyb0y and all the high school members that participated in the competition. TopCoder … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The 2009 TopCoder High School touranment finalized on January 24, 2009 and crazyb0y from China came out on top earning him $3,000 in prize money! Congratulations to crazyb0y and all the high school members that participated in the competition.

TopCoder caught up with the new TCHS09 champion for a brief interview.

How does it feel to be the 2009 TopCoder High School Champion?
I feel REALLY lucky. The other coders did a great job as well. I made some mistakes on the HARD, but luckily it failed on sample. Finally was the room assignment (I started challenging after five minutes).

What brought you to TopCoder?
I can’t remember why I participated in my first SRM, but after it, I decided to continue. Maybe it was the unique competition environment which brought me to TopCoder.

What are your favorite hobbies besides TopCoder?
I have a lot, like ping-pong, movies, bicycling, …
But I don’t play computer games.

What do you wish to study after high school?
Shanghai Jiao Tong University

What is one thing that you have learned at TopCoder that has helped you in other areas of your life?
You can challenge everyone (even a target) regardless of your current position.

item.title: We Just Couldn’t Wait…The 2009 TopCoder Open Begins!
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: (updated with live contest links…) The 2009 TopCoder Open is here! Well, not officially, but we were just too excited to wait. We have launched a few competitions this weekend that are TCO–point eligible. That means if you compete in … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
(updated with live contest links…)

The 2009 TopCoder Open is here!

Well, not officially, but we were just too excited to wait. We have launched a few competitions this weekend that are TCO–point eligible. That means if you compete in these contests, you are already beginning your quest for those trips to Las Vegas, Nevada in June!

When we officially launch the TCO09 next week, you will still need to register for the event in order for these competition points to count, but don’t worry, we’ll remind everyone who competes in any of these early TCO events when it’s time to register.

Among the eligible competitions are the AOL Galleries Front End assemblies that build a Struts based front end over the existing Galleries service. The actions are already coded. Competitors will be creating JSP code and integrate the front end with AOL’s OpenAuth API.

Plus – we’ve launched three conceptualization contests as part of the Sensations Developer Challenge Saturday. Not only are there TCO points for these contests, but the winners of these contests will also be eligible for a share of the $25,000 Sensations Bonus Prize, which will also be awarded at the TCO.

Here are the three Conceptualization contests:

Conceptualization SDC – Imagine
Forum

Conceptualization SDC – My Parents’ E-Mail Client
Forum

Conceptualization SDC – Super Click
Forum

Good Luck!

Now, we’ve extended the Sensations Developer Challenge Idea Generation contest for … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
We’re looking for ideas for applications to assist computer and Internet users with disabilities – and we’re going to build them through the competitions of the 2009 TopCoder Open.

Now, we’ve extended the Sensations Developer Challenge Idea Generation contest for two more days, and we’ve thrown some bonus prizes into the mix!

In case three trips to the TCO in Las Vegas and $7,500 in prizes wasn’t enough, AOL will be giving an iPod Touch to five submitters to this contest, selected at random after the new deadline Tuesday, January 27th at 2pm ET.

We’re serious about getting lots of great ideas to get the Sensations Developer Challenge off to a great start – so check out the contest details, and give us your ideas! Your contribution might not only win you a great prize, it could make a difference in the lives of many. What are you waiting for?

Register Now!
