item.title: A Brief Introduction to Assistive Technologies
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: Thomas Wlodkowski is the Director of Accessibility at AOL, and an Advisory Board member for the Sensations Developer Challenge. He blogs today about the assistive technologies he himself uses in his daily life. While surfing through the Sensations site, you … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Thomas Wlodkowski is the Director of Accessibility at AOL, and an Advisory Board member for the Sensations Developer Challenge. He blogs today about the assistive technologies he himself uses in his daily life.

While surfing through the Sensations site, you will see references to technologies that you may not have ever seen or used personally. But without assistive technologies like screen reader software, alternative keyboard devices, voice recognition software and other products, people with disabilities couldn’t access computers and the Internet.

So, with this in mind, I thought a series of posts to put some context around how people with disabilities access and use mainstream technologies might be helpful. Since I happen to be blind, I’ll focus on my view of the world when accessed via a computer.

Read the full post.

item.title: Ribbit Killer App Challenge Checkpoint 1 Winners Announced… Checkpoint 2 is Just Around the Corner
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: Congratulations to our first winners of the Ribbit Killer App Challenge. TC members lucky4me, areyoukovi, merhl and aminue won early prizes for their Flash&Flex applications which take advantage of the Ribbit Voice Platform. Checkpoint Two is coming up on February … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to our first winners of the Ribbit Killer App Challenge. TC members lucky4me, areyoukovi, merhl and aminue won early prizes for their Flash&Flex applications which take advantage of the Ribbit Voice Platform.

Checkpoint Two is coming up on February 2nd, and it’s not too late to submit – even if you haven’t registered or submitted to this challenge yet. There’s $3000 in prizes available for our Checkpoint 2 winners, and of course you still have a shot at one of the $15,000 1st prizes at the end of the contest – or the $30,000 Best in Show prize!


More information on the Ribbit Killer App Challenge

Here are the winning applications of Checkpoint 1:

Congratulations to all our winners, and remember, all submitters are free to continue to develop your application and resubmit by February 2nd – or submit something entirely new!
 
 

$1000 First Prize Winner

 
 
Application Title: RibbitFox
Category: Social Networking & Communication
Developer: lucky4me

This Firefox extension enables phone calls in one click from any phone number on any web page. A Small phone marker appears next to phone numbers when you browse web pages, one click on the phone marker will start the call.

Link: Ribbitfox Firefox Add-on
 
 

$250 Second Prize Winners

 
 
Application Title: Ultimate Local
Category: Social Networking & Communication
Developer: areyoukovi

Link: Ultimate Local
 
 

Application Title: AIR iPhone
Category: Wildcard
Developer: merhl

Link: AIR iPhone
 
 
 
 
 
 
Application Title: AIRfare
Category: Business and Productivity
Developer: merhl

Link: AIRfare
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Application Title: SocialPhone
Category: Social Networking & Communication
Developer: amiune

Link: SocialPhone
 
 
 
 
More information on the Ribbit Killer App Challenge

item.title: TCO ’09 Competition Kicks Off Early with Announcement of Sensations Developer Challenge
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: Three trips to the 2009 TopCoder Open in Las Vegas, Nevada are on the line, along with $7500 in prize money in the first competition of the Sensations Developer Challenge. This contest to come up with ideas for Accessibility applications, … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Three trips to the 2009 TopCoder Open in Las Vegas, Nevada are on the line, along with $7500 in prize money in the first competition of the Sensations Developer Challenge.

This contest to come up with ideas for Accessibility applications, which will be developed through TCO competitions and presented at the TopCoder Open in June. The winners (up to three) of this idea generation contest will not only win a trip to the TCO, but will be eligible for a share of a $25,000 Sensations Bonus Prize, which will be awarded to the contributors of the best app!

Since development of the apps will take place through online TopCoder competitions, winners of any contest associated with the Sensations Developer Challenge will not only win the prize money and TCO points for that individual contest, but will eligible for a share of the Accessibility Bonus if that application wins!

AOL & TopCoder have teamed to bring this exciting accessibility initiative to the 2009 TopCoder Open!

Guided by input from a diverse community of individuals and organizations working on the forefront of accessibility, the Sensations Developer Challenge will utilize all software development & Studio tracks of TCO’09 competition to challenge you to build solutions for improved usability of mainstream internet-based products by people with disabilities.

Every stage of development will happen through competition, and we’ll present the winning apps — and announce the winners of the $25,000 Sensations Bonus prize — live in Las Vegas at the TopCoder Open in June!

item.title: TCHS09 Online Round 2 Problem Set & Analysis
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: By Nickolas TopCoder Member Round 2 of 2009 TCHS Tournament had 334 participants, and 250 of them were to advance to the next round, so a good time on easy guaranteed advancement. The problem set was relatively easy but quite challengeable, … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
By Nickolas
TopCoder Member

Round 2 of 2009 TCHS Tournament had 334 participants, and 250 of them were to advance to the next round, so a good time on easy guaranteed advancement. The problem set was relatively easy but quite challengeable, and the challenge phase was pretty eventful this time.

The match was won by tourist, due to impressive time on all problems and 3 successfull challenges. exod40 with 5 challenges took the second place, and neal_wu came third.

  • Read the full Problem Set & Analysis

item.title: SRM 432 Problem Set & Analysis
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: By nika TopCoder Member Happy new year ! The first SRM in 2009 attracted 1143 coders. Div 2 easy was easy as always. Div 1 easy / Div 2 medium was not so standard and confused lots of coders. Div … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
By nika
TopCoder Member

Happy new year ! The first SRM in 2009 attracted 1143 coders. Div 2 easy was easy as always. Div 1 easy / Div 2 medium was not so standard and confused lots of coders. Div 1 Medium was tricky – like many other mediums. Hard problems in both division were solvable and about 20 coders in each division proved it.

Div 1 was won by Petr, who had the fastest solution for hard and earned 25 points in challenges. He was closely followed by WSX and Ostap. Both of them made succesfull challenges and needed one more to win this match and their rooms were full of wrong mediums, but they didn’t use their chance. Great result anyway.

Div 2 was won by Alex_KPR, who had good times on all 3 problems. He was followed by hellodj and newcomer adrianoo07.

  • Read the full Problem Set & Analysis

item.title: TCHS09 Online Round 1 Problem Set & Analysis
item.dc:creator: gvsushaver
item.description: By Nickolas TopCoder Member Round 1 of 2009 TCHS Tournament attracted 399 competitors, which is more than twice the number of participants in 2008 TCHS Tournament. With at most 500 advancers to Round 2 it was enough to get a … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
By Nickolas
TopCoder Member

Round 1 of 2009 TCHS Tournament attracted 399 competitors, which is more than twice the number of participants in 2008 TCHS Tournament. With at most 500 advancers to Round 2 it was enough to get a positive score to advance, and nearly 90% of the participants managed to accomplish this. The round was much easier than a regular HS match, and some competitors were done with all 3 problems in as little as 20 minutes.

decowboy took the lead after the coding phase due to the fastest total time on the problems, with tourist and Zuza closely following. The challenge phase brought neal_wu +25 points and the win. decowboy and tourist took second and third places, respectively.

  • Read the full Problem Set & Analysis

item.title: SRM 431 Problem Set & Analysis
item.dc:creator: silvasurfas
item.description: By ivan_metelsky TopCoder Member The last SRM in this year gathered together not so many participants – 1088, 488 in Div-I and 600 in Div-II. In Div-I almost everybody solved the easy problem (partially because of good example cases). However, … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
By ivan_metelsky
TopCoder Member

The last SRM in this year gathered together not so many participants – 1088, 488 in Div-I and 600 in Div-II. In Div-I almost everybody solved the easy problem (partially because of good example cases).

However, the other two problems were quite tough. This resulted in small number of solutions and only 4 coders solved all three problems. qizichao was much faster than anybody else (1st on the Hard and 3rd on the Medium overall) and got his first SRM victory with more than 300 points gap. zhuojie and Petr took second and third places, respectively, with very close scores. Both of them would have scored more, but resubmitted their Hards.

  • Read the full Problem Set & Analysis

item.title: TopCoder Direct Beta is Live!
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: You now have the power to directly access our Global Community of software developers and graphic artists, who are ready to compete to design your web project. In this beta release, you can use TopCoder Direct to launch competitions on … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
You now have the power to directly access our Global Community of software developers and graphic artists, who are ready to compete to design your web project.

In this beta release, you can use TopCoder Direct to launch competitions on TopCoder Studio for logos, web page designs, print work, and much more. You simply describe what you need designed, offer a prize amount you’re willing to pay then launch a contest, and our community will submit their designs to compete for your prize. At the conclusion of your contest, the winning design you choose is available for download immediately.

A set of easy to use widgets give you the ability to create a project, launch competitions, monitor their progress, view your submissions, then choose a winner and download your new design immediately. As TopCoder Direct grows, you’ll be able to launch larger projects to have full web sites and applications built, software components and eventually everything that the TopCoder Community does now for our enterprise customers, all without the need for assistance from TopCoder staff.

Becoming a TopCoder Direct member is free, you’re only charged when you launch a competition, and when you download your winning design(s). You decide the prize money your design is worth, and it’s easy enough to browse other competitions on Studio to get a better idea of the prize purse you should offer to ensure the highest number of quality designs. You only pay the prize if you’re satisfied with the submissions at the end of the competition. More on how to use TopCoder Direct

The Studio Cup

Depending on what type of competition you decide to run through Direct, there is an administration fee that is charged when you launch.

This fee covers not only the admin costs for TopCoder to host the contest, but it also funds the “Studio Cup”, a monthly prize pool for our competitors which grows in value as each new contest is launched. Competitors earn points for placing in the top five of any contest on TopCoder, and at the end of each month the point leaders take home a share of the guaranteed prize pool. So every contest you launch carries a number of Studio Cup points as an added incentive to compete – in addition to the first prize money you’re offering.

As a member of the TopCoder Community, you take an active role in the process of scoring and rating our competitors for the Studio Cup. Since there is no better judge of the quality of designs for a customer than the customer himself, we ask you to help us score the submissions by indicating your Top Five designs at the end of your contest. You are only responsible for purchasing your first prize winner (and any other submissions you choose to purchase), but your selection of a Top Five is the biggest factor in how our competitors will finish in the Studio Cup rankings, and the best incentive for them to compete often and submit top quality design work.

TopCoder Direct is in beta, so we’re working out some kinks here and there. Be sure to visit here for more information.

Good luck and have fun!

item.title: Your TopCoder Direct is Waiting
item.dc:creator: tonyj
item.description: The TopCoder Direct version 1.0 Release is the tool you’ll use to access our community. Once you’ve registered for a free TopCoder account, Direct version 1.0 will allow you to launch competitions on TopCoder Studio for logos, web page designs, … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The TopCoder Direct version 1.0 Release is the tool you’ll use to access our community. Once you’ve registered for a free TopCoder account, Direct version 1.0 will allow you to launch competitions on TopCoder Studio for logos, web page designs, print work, etc. A set of default widgets give you the ability to create a project, launch competitions, monitor their progress, view your submissions, then choose a winner and download your new design immediately. As we add new widgets and functionality, you’ll be able to launch larger projects to have full web sites and applications built, software components and eventually everything that the TopCoder Community does now for our enterprise customers, all without the need for assistance from TopCoder staff.

For more information about how to use the Direct, visit here.

This is a beta release, so there may be some bugs here and there, but we’re working around the clock to perfect the process and adding new functionality every day. If you want to alert us to a bug, or if you need special assistance, send us an email at directAssist@topcoder.com.
